XML.Hansard-Body: The Legislative Assembly met at 9.30 am.
Mr Speaker (Hon. John Mickel, Logan) read prayers and took the chair.

Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, tomorrow I will have the great pleasure of launching a new book on the history of the Queensland parliament. The Ayes Have It--The History of the Queensland Parliament 1957-89 will be launched in the Legislative Council chamber at 1 pm.

Long awaited, The Ayes Have It has been an ongoing project supported by the Queensland parliament since 1995 which has now been published as part of the parliament’s 150th anniversary celebrations. The book is a fascinating account of the Queensland parliament during three decades of high-drama politics. Beginning in the late 1950s, it examines in detail the Queensland parliament from the days of the ‘Labor split’ of that time, through to the conservative governments of Premiers Nicklin, Bjelke-Petersen and Ahern, and ending with the fall of the National Party’s government, led briefly by Russell Cooper in December 1989.

Focusing on parliamentary politics, the book discusses the representatives and personalities who sat in this chamber during this time. It explores their priorities and political agendas as well as the many and varied controversies. The Ayes Have It has been researched and written by John Wanna and Tracey Arklay. I invite all honourable members to join me and the authors in the Legislative Council chamber to launch this book at 1 pm tomorrow.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.33 am): I thank the member for Thuringowa. Today we recognise Vietnam Veterans Day. On this day we reflect on the gallant contribution made by representatives of all our armed services in this theatre of war. We also reflect on the members of our armed services who paid the ultimate sacrifice. We reflect on the tragedy of the loss of young life and the grief suffered by the families and friends of these young service people. This war saw our national government commit not only regular service personnel but also conscripted young men. Five hundred Australian servicemen lost their lives in Vietnam, while some 3,000 were wounded, injured or were victims of illness.

Vietnam Veterans Day is held on this date because today also marks the anniversary of the Battle of Long Tan, which saw a terrible loss of life of Australian soldiers during this terrible war, with 18 killed and 24 injured on this day. This was the first major war event widely covered by television. Day after day Australians had the images of the horror of the conflict beamed into their living rooms. While this enhanced our understanding of the events of the day, it no doubt added to the trauma suffered by loved ones waiting at home. We all remember the gruesome images that we witnessed and we all remember the yearning for the war to end and for our young service men and women to be brought home to be reunited with their families.

Vietnam veterans have had more difficult circumstances to endure than other returned service men and women. Significant sections of Australian society opposed our involvement in this conflict. Upon return, less appreciation of the contribution of these young men and women was afforded to them than was the case at the end of the two great wars. I am pleased to say that increasingly this wrong is being righted in Australian society with the passage of time. Our Vietnam veterans today correctly occupy a highly respected place in our society, as they should. I join with others today and say that I am honoured to pay my respect to those veterans today and call on this House to reflect on the contribution that these men and women made on our behalf.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.35 am): Today I can announce 30 new art projects to be funded by the Queensland government right across the state. These projects between them will receive almost three quarters of a million dollars in Queensland government funding towards music, dance, design, theatre, writing festivals and cultural history. A new theatre work delving into the history of the Australian South Sea Islanders, an exhibition by kidnapped journalist Nigel Brennan and overseas performance opportunities for Queensland bands are among the 30 projects funded under this program.

Our government offers funding for many different arts projects across Queensland, and I am always struck by the richness, diversity and creativity of the successful applicants, many of whom come from regional, remote and rural parts of our state. This round of funding will explore our cultural history, with a new music theatre work delving into the history of Australian South Sea Islanders in Bowen, which will premiere as part of the 2011 Queensland Music Festival.

The Mount Morgan social history collection will develop a permanent display about the region’s Indigenous community, while the Museum of Brisbane will research and present an exhibition profiling the city’s Asian-Australian identities. Funding will go towards developing a number of new theatre productions, as well as funding to tour successful Queensland productions nationally.

In contemporary music, we are helping to fund national and international tours by Queensland based musicians. Writers will benefit from the project ‘Travelling Suitcases’, with a rich range of resources and artefacts about Queensland authors and illustrators available for loan to schools, public libraries and writers groups across the state.

Funding is available as part of Arts Queensland’s grant program, which supports high-quality art projects that support the goals of the Queensland Arts and Cultural Sector Plan 2010-2013. I congratulate all of the recipients and I would encourage all members of the House to support those artists who have been successful in this round.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.37 am): One of the most important and, in my experience, rewarding aspects of my job is talking directly to Queenslanders about the issues that matter to them. But in a state as decentralised as ours there are obviously some Queenslanders who do not often get the opportunity to put their questions and concerns directly to the state’s decision makers. Equally, for Queenslanders in less remote areas, I know that work and family commitments can make it hard to find the time to get along to events like community cabinets. This is where our government’s nation-leading people’s question time session comes in.

I am pleased to advise the House that later today we will be holding another live online session. It will be the fourth people’s question time we have held this year. There are no limits on the kinds of questions Queenslanders can ask. If it matters to them, we want to hear about it. The Minister for Transport and the Minister for Main Roads will be joining the Treasurer and me on the panel for this session. So for those Queenslanders who might have a great suggestion for improving public transport or our road network or have an issue, question or a complaint, this will be a great opportunity for them to raise it.

There is still time for people to submit their questions and suggestions for discussion. They just have to follow the links from the Premier’s website. This session will also have an innovation--a Facebook page to engage more Queenslanders, particularly young Queenslanders, in people’s question time. Already 127 questions have been submitted online, and I encourage others to join us online from midday today.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.39 am): On the subject of participative democracy, I am pleased to advise the House that earlier this year, as members will recall, my government took the initiative to give Queenslanders the chance to be involved in talking about shaping their future, particularly in relation to population growth. The Queensland Growth Management Summit brought together more than 200 Queenslanders to debate and discuss ideas for managing growth and protecting the lifestyle we all love. We were joined by thousands of online viewers and hundreds more who had their say via live questions and surveys. The summit was a true forum for dialogue, discussion and debate. In all, summit participants generated around 1,400 ideas to ensure our future sustainability, prosperity and liveability.

I am delighted to advise the House that the summit has been nominated for the 2011 Reinhard Mohn Prize for Revitalising Democracy through Participation. This award will be awarded by the German based foundation, Bertelsmann Stiftung. Founded in 1977, this foundation has invested around $666 million in over 700 projects which have demonstrated outstanding community involvement and outcomes. The 2011 prize--which is a substantial financial prize--will be ultimately decided by the foundation, but it will take into account the comments and support of people who have visited their website. So I urge those Queenslanders who were involved in the summit on the issue of population growth to go on the website and say what they thought of it. Links to the 2011 Reinhard Mohn Prize are on the Growth Management Summit website and comments and ratings must be completed by 22 August.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.40 am): As I outlined yesterday, this is Queensland’s Seniors Week. This afternoon I will have the pleasure of announcing the winners of the 2010 Premier’s Awards for Queensland Seniors. These awards recognise Queenslanders aged 60 and over whose volunteer work has had a significant impact on their community. Queensland’s seniors support a range of charities, community organisations and worthy causes which make a real difference to the lives of many Queenslanders. These people are the real ‘legends’ in Queensland life and it is only fitting that, as a community, we should honour them.

This year marks the 25th year of the awards program and over 450 Queensland seniors have received a Premier’s award since their introduction in 1986. Awards will be presented to 15 recipients at the ceremony this afternoon. This year an additional recipient will also receive a certificate of recognition for their outstanding work in community safety. The 16 winners, which include six Indigenous recipients, will be recognised for their invaluable contribution to Queensland.

The theme of Seniors Week--Positively Ageless--reinforces the enduring benefits of a positive attitude to life. The winners of the Premier’s Awards for Queensland Seniors this year embody that theme, with the incredible passion, energy and commitment they display in their lives. The Premier’s Awards for Queensland Seniors offers us all an opportunity to say thank you to our seniors, particularly those who are volunteers. On behalf of all members of the House, I offer our thanks.

Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health) (9.43 am): Dental health is an important issue for all Queenslanders. Already the Bligh government has demonstrated its commitment to improving oral health by introducing fluoride in 2008. This vital public health measure will help to reduce levels of tooth decay by up to 40 per cent and benefit the oral health of all Queenslanders. We provide the most generous dental services in Australia, with 45.3 per cent of the population--more than 1.9 million people--eligible for public dental services.

Last financial year, the Bligh government funded public oral health services to the tune of approximately $166 million. Last year, Queensland public oral health services delivered 472,701 occasions of service to adults and 457,272 occasions of service to children aged zero to 15. On an average day in Queensland, there are 1,881 adult dental appointments and 1,804 child and adolescent dental appointments, and 916 children and adolescents complete dental treatment.

Demand for public oral health services is increasing due to population growth, ageing of the population and greater numbers of people retaining their natural teeth. Moreover, Queensland children have long had the poorest oral health in the nation. The AIHW Child Dental Health Survey in 2004 confirmed that Queensland children had more filled teeth, extractions and decayed teeth than any other state or territory. The Bligh government’s introduction of fluoride will make inroads to redress this but it will take time.

We are also implementing measures to educate Queenslanders of all ages about the importance of good oral health and how to achieve this. A great example of this is the toothbrushing program being run by Queensland Health’s Logan-Beaudesert Oral Health Service. This initiative is successfully working to help over 16,000 children across 43 primary schools and 65 day care centres adopt and maintain better oral hygiene habits. To date, Queensland Health has handed out 16,600 free toothbrushes to children and conducted 2,300 education sessions across the district.

Dental services for children must be a key priority, not only for us as a government but particularly for parents and members of our local communities. The great work our dental professionals do is very important, but there is one thing it does not replace--that is, it is important that parents play a role in educating their families about good oral hygiene and establishing good oral health routines.

Having said that, even children with the best oral health will still need to have their teeth looked at and tended to from time to time, and that is something important that we all need to work towards. It requires a three-pronged approach: ensuring families are taking responsibility for their children’s oral health and being proactive in this; implementing public health measures such as water fluoridation; and introducing new approaches to healthcare innovation. That is why I was pleased last week to visit Jimboomba State School to open a new $786,800 super-sized dental van, one of six vans being progressively rolled out across Queensland. In fact, the school captains assisted me to cut the dental floss ribbon we had there.
Mr Hinchliffe: Why didn’t you bite through it?

Mr LUCAS: You are supposed to put it between your teeth, not bite it. These new vans are the flagship of a $14.15 million program to modernise our public oral health fleet, helping to increase our capacity to treat those eligible for public dental services by providing oral health services for patients of all ages across the state. They are equipped to deal with all types of routine oral health services. These vans are also totally mobile, allowing them to be taken to places where there is limited or no local access to oral health services currently. They are also designed to assist in providing services to special needs patients, with access for wheelchair bound and physically impaired patients. The five remaining super-sized vans will be rolled out over the next six to 12 months and will be allocated to Darling Downs-West Moreton, Metro North, the Sunshine Coast, Townsville and the Gold Coast health service districts. Under this new program, up to 50 new replacement single surgery vans and four new replacement self-drive mobile dental clinic vehicles will also be built.

Unfortunately, the government’s efforts to improve the oral health of Queenslanders are being hampered by those opposite who are continuing to help block vital funding in the Senate. The federal government’s dental program would have delivered an extra $52.8 million to Queensland and would have provided an extra 187,000 dental consultations and treatments. Queenslanders waiting to receive these dental services cannot access this funding because Liberal and National senators have blocked this funding in the Senate.

Yet the hypocrisy in this area is astounding. Those on the other side of the House have repeatedly made statements and repeatedly written to me about dental health, like the members for Caloundra, Dalrymple, Callide and Southern Downs and even the member for Surfers Paradise. It is time the Liberals and Nationals in Queensland ended their hypocrisy and stood up to their colleagues--
Mr McArdle interjected.

Mr LUCAS: Yes, and it is correct--and I thank the member for Caloundra for pointing this out to the House--that John Howard took away the federal public dental funding in Queensland. I thank the honourable member--
Mr McArdle interjected.
Mr LUCAS: I do thank the member for Caloundra for pointing out that John Howard took away public dental funding, and Queensland was the only state--
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Both sides of the House! There is too much crossfire.
Mr LUCAS: I know the member for Caloundra keeps on raising it and I am happy to acknowledge that he is saying that John Howard took away--
Mr McArdle interjected.

Mr LUCAS: I am happy to acknowledge the member for Caloundra’s suggestion that John Howard took away public funding for dental treatment at a state level and Queensland was the only state that kept that funding up. That is why we spend about the same amount of money as New South Wales and more per capita than any other state in Australia.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (9.49 am): Actions always speak louder than words. Yet another international company has voted with its feet and moved to create a permanent home base here in Queensland. Digicel Pacific, part of the Irish owned Digicel Group, is a mobile phone network provider currently operating across Oceania, Central America and the Caribbean. After negotiations with the government, we have beaten Auckland and Sydney, and have secured to Brisbane Digicel’s decision to relocate its regional headquarters from the South Pacific to Eagle Farm, in the electorate of the shadow Treasurer.

The company has already started recruiting and expects to create up to 29 full-time jobs in the near term. Its decision to relocate to Brisbane means we will be the regional home for a company that operates in 32 markets worldwide, has 5,500 employees and investments exceeding $4 billion. Within our region, Digicel Pacific’s current markets are Fiji, Nauru, PNG, Samoa, Tonga and Vanuatu, and the company has recently been awarded a licence to operate in Tahiti. It is the biggest telecommunications company across the Pacific Island, with more than 1.7 million customers and employing more than 900 people.

Digicel Pacific has recognised the growth potential of the Queensland economy, the pro-business policy settings, low business taxes, the skilled workforce and the lifestyle benefits which only Queensland can offer. Its choice of Queensland adds to our reputation for attracting high-growth, entrepreneurial companies and acknowledges our state’s expertise in ICT and professional services.

Digicel’s arrival also represents good prospects for Queensland based ICT and telecommunications companies to supply wireless applications and other niche technologies to them into the future, particularly into its expanding market in remote areas such as PNG. It is our proactive work that will continue to grow Queensland’s reputation as an ideal investment location and a great place to do business. While others will go to extreme lengths to talk down the merits of the Queensland economy, the facts tell a different story. The decision by Digicel is a further endorsement of Queensland’s reputation as a first-class destination for investment. Again, actions speak louder than words.

Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (9.51 am): The construction industry is doing it tough around Australia as it still struggles to recover from the global financial crisis. However, a helping hand has been provided by this government, which is providing more support to the industry than any other state in Australia. We have a massive $17.1 billion infrastructure program protecting 106,000 jobs. The Gillard government has also been keeping the Australian construction industry afloat through the Building the Education Revolution and other stimulus programs.

We have two levels of Labor governments making extraordinary efforts to keep construction workers in work and stimulate the economy. However, in an article in the Sunshine Coast Daily on 11 August, the member for Maroochydore demanded the Bligh government urgently do more for Sunshine Coast construction workers. I note that Mayor Abbot also made some gratuitous remarks. I point out to the mayor that this government is committed to the biggest public construction project on the Sunshine Coast. It seems to have escaped the mayor’s attention that the Sunshine Coast has the biggest public building project in the history of the Sunshine Coast to look forward to--the 9,000 jobs created by the Sunshine Coast University Hospital. One wonders what Mayor Abbot is doing to mirror such activity by the state government and whether he took the same steps to create jobs in the construction industry the way his colleagues on the Gold Coast have done.

However, the hypocrisy and opportunism from the member for Maroochydore rankles the most because of her disgraceful attempt to gain credit for something she opposed. The member for Maroochydore and her party opposed our record Queensland infrastructure spending. Her LNP federal colleagues opposed the BER. They said that it was a wasteful program even though a recent independent report found that it achieved its economic objectives. The LNP prefers to waste people’s lives rather than spend a few dollars.
The Sunshine Coast is well and truly on the Bligh government’s radar to assist the building industry. From 2013 the Sunshine Coast will have Australia’s--
Ms Simpson: Half a billion dollars on the Traveston Dam pipeline and there is no Traveston Dam. What a waste!
Mr SCHWARTEN: What about the railway line to nowhere--like you are!
Ms Simpson: You are putting it into the pipeline to nowhere. Put it into the hospitals.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Maroochydore!
Mr SCHWARTEN: The railway line to nowhere.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The minister will continue with his ministerial statement.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I will go back to it, Mr Speaker. The member for Maroochydore and her party are opposed to our record Queensland infrastructure spending. Her LNP federal colleagues opposed the BER. They said it was a wasteful program, even though a recent independent report found it achieved its economic objectives.

The Sunshine Coast is well and truly on the Bligh government’s radar to assist the building industry. From 2013 the Sunshine Coast will have Australia’s biggest construction project when 9,000 jobs will start to be delivered on the Sunshine Coast University Hospital project. In a Sunshine Coast Daily article on 24 July, the hospital project was hailed as a job saviour of the Sunshine Coast. However, the university hospital would not even be on the radar if the member for Maroochydore or other members on the Sunshine Coast had their way and cut the Capital Works Program as they propose to do. Until that happens, 1,150 jobs are totally dependent on this state government on the Sunshine Coast--again opposed by the four members on the Sunshine Coast who are opposed to our capital works borrowings.

From next year there will be hundreds more jobs at a private hospital at Kawana fast-tracked by this government. Further, the Gillard government has spent $421 million on projects in 213 Sunshine Coast state schools and $64 million on 221 social housing dwellings--again delivering many jobs to the people of the Sunshine Coast.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (9.55 am): It is important that I set the record straight in relation to the recovery of costs associated with government providing water security to the south-east of the state through the South-East Queensland water grid. What I am about to read is the ministerial media statement issued to the Courier-Mail and reporter Steven Wardill last evening. It is the news you did not read this morning, so I would like to read it now into the public record. It began with this clear statement of fact--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: No planning or pre-construction costs associated with the Traveston Crossing Dam proposal will be passed on to consumers through water prices.

The South-East Queensland Water Grid cost the Bligh Government $7 billion to construct and was a necessary investment to provide water security within the region for generations to come. The expenditure would have been $9 billion had the Traveston Crossing Dam been built.
The Government has been very transparent in its plans and has previously outlined details of the first five years of a 10-year price plan to recover the costs of the Grid.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Seeney interjected.
Mr Dickson interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my left will cease interjecting. I will give you leeway if the ministerial statement is drifting into abuse of a particular member. At the moment, as I understand it, this is a ministerial statement placing something on the record.
Mr ROBERTSON: Correct. That price path was released nearly 12 months before the Traveston Dam was cancelled. I return to the statement--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That plan effectively caps the bulk water price increases in any year. While we may be able to review prices in the final years of the price path, it is too soon to make changes ...
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: given that we are still charging below cost for bulk water supplied to the council run water retailers. It continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In December last year, the ... Government wrote off $265 million in non-recoverable project costs associated with the Traveston Crossing Dam proposal. No Queenslander is paying any costs of Traveston Dam in their water bill and no costs were ever scheduled for the first five years of the price plan.
This year alone, the Government has incurred a $407 million loss to provide bulk water to the council-run water retail entities.
Charging less to provide bulk water than what it cost is why the commitment to the first five years of the price plan must be maintained ...
Had the Bligh Government not been subsidising this price, we would expect to see the effects of Traveston Crossing Dam immediately in pricing.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: It is anticipated that in five years the cost of the water grid project could be approaching break-even point. It continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: At that point, the absence of Traveston Crossing Dam costs may be taken into consideration, which may result in lower price increases for the second five years of the plan than previously anticipated ...
But all factors affecting the price of bulk water, including population growth interest rates and capital depreciation and operating costs of the water grid also will need to be considered.
XML.Hansard-Body: To suggest, as the Courier-Mail did this morning, that South-East Queensland households are being hit with massive water price hikes to pay off a dam that will not be built is, quite simply, wrong. From the statement I have just read out, for whatever reason or purpose it appears to have been ignored by the Courier-Mail .

Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (9.59 am): The Bligh government is strongly committed to creating a safe and secure environment for passengers and staff travelling on Brisbane’s rail networks. To that end, we have a dedicated police Railway Squad who are tasked with providing a visible uniform police presence on the Queensland Rail Citytrain network.

By working with Queensland Rail’s transit officers, the police Railway Squad aims to create an environment that promotes passenger and staff confidence in their personal safety and security. They are also responsible for the delivery of proactive initiatives to deter, detect and prosecute offenders for offences occurring on the rail network.

Last year the squad was involved in 178 operations, targeting criminal offences and good order behaviour on the network. During this period the squad conducted 27,669 hours of network patrols and issued 3,304 infringement notices. They do a great job in difficult circumstances. I commend the squad for its professionalism and commitment to commuter safety.

I am pleased to inform the House today that the Police Commissioner has allocated an extra 10 police officers to join the Railway Squad to further enhance commuter safety. The allocation of these additional officers takes the strength of the Railway Squad to 64 members and means an enhanced focus on providing a safe service for more than 66 million passenger journeys on the network each year. The unit already includes a dedicated intelligence unit, a crime prevention coordinator and a firearms explosive detection dog capability. Five officers will become operational this financial year with the remaining five coming on line in 2011-12.

This government is delivering on its commitment to a safe and secure Queensland. In this year’s budget we announced funding for an additional 203 police officers as part of our commitment to employ a minimum of 600 extra police officers during this term of government. We have allocated more than $270 million to upgrade, refurbish and replace police stations and facilities, vehicles and equipment. These new Railway Squad officers will mean a safer journey for Queenslanders travelling on Brisbane trains.

Hon. RG NOLAN (Ipswich--ALP) (Minister for Transport) (10.01 am): The Bligh government is passionately committed to public transport and, of course, is committed to the safety of passengers and staff on the public transport network. Passengers should be reassured that South-East Queensland trains and rail stations are safe and that incidents are rare. Over the past five years, the number of incidents has remained steady despite a large increase in public transport usage. According to official police figures, for every 175,000 trips taken, one incident is reported. But one incident is one too many and we want to remain ever vigilant.

We already have 6,800 CCTV cameras, 54 Railway Squad police and up to 110 transit officers keeping our trains and stations safe. Throughout the day, trains and stations are patrolled by transit officers and the Railway Squad. After 7 pm on Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights, every train carries security guards.

I warmly welcome the extra 10 police officers who will be assigned to the Railway Squad over the next year. These officers will bring the number of Railway Squad officers to 64. In addition, 10 senior network officers are currently being trained and will be deployed next month. The new transit officers will have extra powers to search and detain offenders and also ban repeat offenders. Our front-line officers are supported by an extensive network of CCTV cameras. I am advised the clean-up rate for crimes on the rail network is good with these cameras assisting police to identify and track down offenders.

We have a commitment to ensure rail staff work in a safe environment. The suggestion that our employees and contracted security guards are told they are to be hands off is quite simply untrue. They are trained to diffuse potentially volatile situations in a non-physical way, but are also well within their rights to intervene to defend themselves or passengers if a situation turns violent. I am pleased to report that customer service satisfaction levels for security and safety on the TransLink network are at the highest levels since the surveys were first conducted three years ago.

The Bligh government is very serious about public transport security. While the rate of incidents is fortunately low, we are deploying more transit officers and more police to ensure passengers and staff can go about their business safely.

Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Infrastructure and Planning) (10.04 am): Last week I had the pleasure of launching the North West Regional Plan in Mount Isa--a statutory plan to guide social and economic growth in the north-west over the next 20 years. With local leadership from the member for Mount Isa and the region’s five mayors we have developed a blueprint which strikes the right balance between the north-west’s social, economic and environmental needs. This will ensure development is appropriate to the region. It will ensure a sustainable economy. It will provide well planned and coordinated infrastructure and services.

This is the most recent regional plan and is evidence that Queensland is leading the way in managing growth. In partnership with the Gillard government we are moving this great state forward. As already mentioned by the Premier, in March the Bligh government hosted the Queensland Growth Management Summit, the first of its kind in Australia. A key strategy to managing Queensland’s population is to promote growth in our regions. To this end, the Bligh government announced on 1 June 2010 an additional $4,000 for first home buyers in regional areas. We have also made plans to support this population growth with strong local economies and jobs with a Queensland regionalisation strategy.

Julia Gillard also understands the importance of Queensland’s regions and has committed heavily to those areas. In contrast, Tony Abbott only has eyes for Sydney and would rob our regions of the investment they deserve. Let me list some of the commitments the Gillard government has already made to Queensland’s regions. They include: $200 million to flood proof Townsville’s roads, while Abbott would watch the city sink in the wet season; $95 million for the Calliope Crossroads near Gladstone, and nothing from Abbott; $54 million for the Blacksoil interchange near Ipswich, and nothing from Abbott; $50 million to the Gladstone Port Access Road, and nothing from Abbott; $48 million to the Townsville Convention and Entertainment Centre, $18 million more than Abbott; $40 million for the Bruce and Capricorn Highway intersection, and nothing from Abbott; and $14.4 million to the Cairns Base Hospital, $7 million to the Mackay GP superclinic and $5 million to the Emerald GP superclinic, all of which will receive nothing under Abbott.

This list could go on and on embarrassing that wannabe Prime Minister every step of the way. We know Tony Abbott will cut vital funding to our regions and that is why Tony Abbott is a risk the Queensland economy can just not afford.

Hon. KL STRUTHERS (Algester--ALP) (Minister for Community Services and Housing and Minister for Women) (10.07 am): The Bligh government is on track to deliver the biggest social housing investment Queensland has ever seen. On top of our Queensland Future Fund we are on track to see 3,000 new social housing dwellings built by the end of this year with the help of the federal Labor government’s stimulus package. This $1.2 billion investment in the Queensland economy is contributing to 12 straight months of job creation. We have created more jobs than any other state over the last four months alone. By the end of the last financial year our investment in conjunction with the federal Gillard government had generated more than 1,600 jobs in the Queensland construction industry.

More than 2,700 dwellings are already underway and due to be finished by the end of the year. In the Far North, around 50 per cent of construction jobs have vanished since August 2008. We have offset that with $51 million worth of housing projects, which are creating more than 320 jobs. In the Wide Bay-Burnett region, 38 per cent of construction jobs disappeared. We are investing another $62 million to help keep another 380 workers employed.
Mr Cripps interjected.

Ms STRUTHERS: Let me tell you about the Gold Coast. Listen to this. About 17 per cent of construction work dried up since August 2008. We have offset that with $71 million worth of projects creating 370 jobs. On receiving a letter from me about this stimulus package on the Gold Coast, what did the LNP member for Fadden have to say? He took the trouble to ring my office yesterday. What he did say? He said the stimulus package--and I have to spell it because it is unparliamentary language--was c-r-a-p. He did not say it once. He definitely had his cranky pants on. He said it four times. That is what he thinks of the stimulus package. He and his colleagues in the federal parliament, what did they do about the stimulus package? They opposed it in the federal parliament.
Opposition members interjected.
Ms STRUTHERS: They denied Queensland 1,600 jobs. They denied Queensland over 4,000 new units of social housing.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The House will come to order!
Ms STRUTHERS: These are the people who want to run this country.

Mr SPEAKER: Order! The House will come to order! I say to the minister: you cannot put unparliamentary language into somebody else’s mouth. I just offer that as a warning to the whole House. If something is unparliamentary, it is unparliamentary.
Ms STRUTHERS: I am happy to say the word, Mr Speaker.

Mr SPEAKER: I do not want you to say it. It is unparliamentary, and it is unparliamentary to try to intrude it into this House by quoting someone else. It also aids the chair if when ministers are giving a ministerial statement they give a statement. What causes disorder in this House is when the ministerial statement starts to attack another member and that other member responds, quite naturally. I then am forced into either trying to listen to the ministerial statement or giving the member who feels offended the chance to defend themselves. So I say to all ministers that it helps the House if when they are giving a ministerial statement they do so and then allow the opposition member to respond if they are under attack.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Disability Services, Support to Live at Home
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. A PALASZCZUK (Inala--ALP) (Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs) (10.10 am): Research from quality publications such as the journal of Child: Care, Health and Development suggests that the environment in which people live can play an important role in promoting self-determination and independence. People with a disability who continue to live in their own communities can have improved quality of life and reduced social isolation.

The Bligh government is committed to helping Queenslanders living with a disability retain their independence and remain active members of their community. For six years now we have been providing drop-in support services in the Brisbane area. We are providing over $500,000 in funding each year. This can be for things that appear simple to us--making dinner, having a shower or getting ready for the next morning for a medical appointment. However, to people with a disability these tasks can seem overwhelming.

In Brisbane we have had outstanding success, allowing over 40 people the often minimal support they need to stay living in their own homes. Today I am pleased to announce that I am expanding this project state-wide, investing $2.5 million to allow more than 140 people with a disability to remain living in their own homes. We will direct this funding into a number of regional and Brisbane based non-government service providers so they can deliver the essential support that is needed.

Where is this funding going? In Brisbane, $100,000 is going to the electorate of Ashgrove. In Yeerongpilly, $250,000 is going to the Cerebral Palsy League. In Central Queensland, $219,000 is going to Rockhampton and there is $50,000 for the Central Highlands and Western Queensland Family Support Association. In the south-west, $100,000 is going to Focal Extended at Ipswich and in Toowoomba--where is the member for Toowoomba North?--$250,000 is going to the Cerebral Palsy League. On the Gold Coast, $350,000 is going to Accommodation Network Pty Ltd at Tweed Heads. On the Sunshine Coast--where is the member for Nicklin?
Mr Wellington: Right here!
Ms PALASZCZUK: On the Sunshine Coast, $350,000 is going to Advanced Care Australia to help it.
Mr Wellington: Hear, hear!

Ms PALASZCZUK: In Mackay, MADEC will receive $175,000, as will services in the member for Thuringowa’s electorate, also worth $175,000. Members in Cairns and Far North Queensland will see $400,000 being channelled to the Far North Queensland Independent Living Support Association.

This is good news for the people of Queensland. It is great news because we believe in improving people’s quality of life. We believe in ensuring that people with a disability get the support that they need to lead rich and rewarding lives, not just in South-East Queensland but right across the state. We believe in creating inclusive communities but, most importantly, we believe in looking past the disability and focusing on people’s abilities.

Hon. KJ JONES (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability) (10.13 am): The mysteries of Queensland’s underwater history are set to be unveiled as part of a major survey of our state’s shipwrecks to be undertaken over the next five years. Our coastline is littered with untold stories under the sea, many dating back centuries. Through a state-wide survey to start in Moreton Bay later this year, we hope to discover more about the historic sites off Queensland’s coast to provide a clear picture for the public about the mysteries on our ocean floor. The survey will be carried out by the heritage branch of the Department of Environment and Resource Management, which has recently taken over management of Queensland’s historic shipwrecks from the Queensland Museum.

We know that there are more than 1,000 historic shipwrecks or abandoned vessels along the state’s coast, as well as in our rivers and bays. But in most cases data on these shipwrecks is often scant and often inaccurate. Every one of these ships is an archeological site which can tell us much more about the lives of past generations of Queenslanders and others who have visited our shores. Through this survey we will tap into the broad range of skills and equipment within our heritage, marine sciences and marine parks units to locate as many wrecks as possible and determine their significance.

We know that there is a wealth of information about unidentified shipwrecks among interested members of the community, historical researchers and diving groups. In the first stage of this survey we will be calling on members of the public, research organisations and these diving groups to help build our knowledge of historical sites, starting with Moreton Bay. Following this, the department will next year commence targeted field operations using technology such as side-scan sonar to confirm actual locations for mapping and preservation.

We want to ensure Queensland’s precious maritime heritage is properly managed and, where appropriate, made accessible to the general public. This survey is an exciting step toward better understanding our state’s underwater history so we can protect our historic shipwrecks for future generations to appreciate.

Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (10.16 am): Anyone who has visited a Queensland school trade training centre would be aware of their importance. These centres are providing new employment pathways for students who would have once fallen into unemployment. To see this one only has to look at Tagai State College on Thursday Island, which I had the pleasure of visiting some time ago. The state college has centres for excellence in marine science, art, culture and language for students from pre-prep to TAFE. Over the last two years Tagai students have entered university, TAFE and employment in record numbers. Under the college’s service guarantee, every graduating year 12 student must be in university, vocational education and training, or paid employment within six months of finishing school. We are seeing better results in literacy and numeracy, higher retention rates and improved transition into meaningful education, training and employment.

Since 2007 the number of Tagai year 12 students going to university has doubled, with 75 per cent of students having gone on to university, entered vocational education and training or undertaken further study. The Queensland government continues to work with the local Tagai community to build on these great results. The next stage of this partnership is the $1.5 million TagaiSkills Trade Training Centre. The new trade training centre will help ensure students in the Torres Strait have access to a broad range of training opportunities across a total of 17 islands in the Torres Strait.

The Trade Training Centres in Schools project includes a new building and construction facility, upgrades to the existing hospitality centre at Tagai State College and other matters. The all-weather construction area and engineering workshop is completed, with 20 students currently undertaking training. A major upgrade of existing hospitality facilities will also create an industry standard commercial kitchen with a restaurant. The centre will offer Torres Strait students certificate III qualifications in engineering, construction, cookery and hospitality through partnering with the Tropical North Queensland Institute of TAFE.

The Liberal National Party would close this centre and cancel local training programs. Mr Abbott and the Liberal National Party would not have the guts to visit Thursday Island and tell them truthfully of their plans to cut these services. The Bligh government wants to give every Queenslander a flying start to education and life. Under the Liberal National Party education and training cuts, we will end up with uneducated, untrained and unemployed young Queenslanders.

Hon. CA WALLACE (Thuringowa--ALP) (Minister for Main Roads) (10.18 am): Hot on the heels of the Premier’s Queensland Growth Management Summit and the regionalisation forums around the state, Townsville is poised to take its place as our state’s second capital. Indeed, on Friday my director-general and senior executives will head north for top-level talks on roads and transport. You could say that Capital Hill will come to Castle Hill, and roads will be high on our agenda.

The Bligh government is rolling out a record number of new projects in the north. We are building the infrastructure that is needed to meet our future growth. It makes sense to encourage more people to live and work in the north to ease the pressure down here in South-East Queensland and to build stronger regional economies. This year alone, we are spending $48 million on the Douglas Arterial Road--480 local jobs over the life of the whole project. We are building extra lanes on Kern Brothers Drive--$3 million and more jobs. As the member for Hinchinbrook knows, work is well underway on a $115 million upgrade of the Cardwell Range Road--around 420 local jobs.

As the minister for infrastructure announced this morning, the great news is that the Gillard government will commit to the $200 million completion of the Townsville Ring Road. That is 1,500 jobs for locals, working on a road that will meet the needs of North Queensland drivers for the next 30 years. It is shaping up to be a big year in Townsville--one of our biggest years when it comes to infrastructure.
We have had the V8s, which the Bligh government helped fund and which gave our economy a real kick-start.
Mr Reeves: Hear, hear!

Mr WALLACE: I want to congratulate the Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport and federal Labor. The Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport was there. He saw just how successful that event was for Townsville.

We have already seen the start of our new world-class tennis centre, funded by this Labor government. Add to that the $13 million towards the Flinders Street Mall upgrade and more than $100 million by this government to build a world-class marine precinct at the Port of Townsville.

We are going from strength to strength in the north, proving that we are Queensland’s second capital. On Friday, I look forward to hosting the first of many top-level talks in our region. It is a golden opportunity for us to build on our strengths, to build better roads, to deliver more jobs and to kick-start local economies. We are paving the roads and paving the way for a better and brighter future for North Queenslanders.

Hon. TS MULHERIN (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland) (10.21 am): This spring Queensland is facing its worst locust plague in more than 30 years, which is why Biosecurity Queensland has been conducting intensive survey and spraying operations over the winter. Huge swarms of spur-throated locusts are expected to increase in Western Queensland in August. At the same time, Australian plague locusts, which are of great concern in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, are expected to hatch in South-West Queensland. These two different locust species have the potential to damage 1.3 million hectares of Queensland’s valuable cropping land. The hundreds of millions of locusts that are expected make this the biggest plague since 1973-74 are a result of increased rainfall in Western Queensland.

Biosecurity Queensland has been working hard over the winter to mitigate the potential impacts of this plague and so far our teams have controlled 55 swarms, covering almost 13,000 hectares in Western and Central Queensland. Biosecurity Queensland officers have been implementing ground and aerial surveillance and spraying operations, working primarily between Barcaldine, Blackall, Charleville and Cunnamulla. Biosecurity Queensland has been concentrating on spraying plagues in Western Queensland before they move east and threaten our multimillion dollar Central Highlands and Darling Downs cropping regions.

The winter months are the ideal time for spraying, as locusts band together in swarms and present a good target for aerial spraying. Although the control of locusts is a landholder responsibility, locusts are recognised as being a community problem. We have already spent about $200,000 this year, with reports of large swarms already starting to disperse, Biosecurity Queensland will be doing everything it can to find them and hit them with spray. We have also been working with local councils, landholders and industry to communicate the risks posed by locusts and to gain cooperation for spraying. Biosecurity Queensland will continue to undertake an increased control program to do everything it can to reduce the extent of damage caused by this plague.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Communities
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. D BOYLE (Cairns--ALP) (Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships) (10.23 am): Today I announce $73.4 million in funding over two years to support services and jobs in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. This funding is being delivered under two programs: the State Government Financial Aid initiative and the Revenue Replacement Program. This funding, which is going to some of our most remote councils, translates to over $36 million this year for municipal services and the jobs that go with them. Agreements will be negotiated council by the council as to how these moneys are best applied.

Projects will include making sure water and waste water systems are in good working order, improving drainage, maintaining roads and building footpaths, especially in the town area. The funding also supports services like rubbish collection, libraries and streetlighting and ensures that communities have access to public facilities, sporting fields and swimming pools.

Of the funding, $32.7 million comes from the State Government Financial Aid program and goes to 16 Indigenous councils. It is needed because these councils do not have sufficient rateable land to generate income, as do mainstream councils. There is also a grant of $564,060 for the Torres Strait Island Regional Council under the Heavy Equipment Management and Training Program. Not only does this money go towards the cost of providing plant and equipment to Torres Strait Island communities but also to training council employees on how to safely use them. The remaining $3.5 million is provided under the Revenue Replacement Program, replacing income previously generated for councils through liquor sales. We have guaranteed the nine councils involved $14.1 million in total over four years to 2012. What this support does is help them provide community services historically funded by profits from canteen alcohol sales. This year’s $36 million allocation takes the state’s total contribution under these programs to Indigenous councils for 2010-11 to $39.9 million. That is state government funding to help Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander councils move forward.
Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (10.26 am): I give notice that the Premier will move the following motion--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • recognises that the national broadband network is an essential investment in the future, including for the benefit of Queensland children and young people, future jobs, e-business, e-learning, e-health and decentralisation;
• supports the federal government’s NBN as the best, most comprehensive program to provide the required high-speed broadband services to Queensland; and
• calls on the federal opposition leader to guarantee the same high level of service, especially to rural and regional Queensland as provided by the NBN plan.

total debate time before question put, one hour.

XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Office of the Leader of the Opposition
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (10.27 am): I table for the information of the House the public report of office expenses of the Leader of the Opposition for the period 1 July 2009 to 30 June 2010. This public report has been certified by the Auditor-General of Queensland in accordance with the requirements of the Auditor-General Act 2009 and the Queensland opposition handbook.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Public report of office expenses for the Office of the Leader of the Opposition for the period 1 July 2009 to 30 June 2010 [ 2761 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: The report indicates a total expenditure for the year of $2,900,712, which represents a saving for the year of $35,388 from an allocated budget of $2,936,100.
Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (10.28 am): I give notice that I will move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House notes--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • that Child Safety officers in Bundaberg have removed an eight-year-old boy from his mother after she admitted to bathing with her son three years ago when he was five;
• the mother has an unblemished record and has not been charged with any offence;
• Child Safety Queensland has permanently labelled this mother as a sex offender and has removed her son for more than 10 months;
• two independent reports commissioned by Child Safety recommended that the child be returned to the mother;
• Child Safety has disregarded those reports and refused to reunite child and mother;

• Child Safety officers have told the mother that when she is near her son she must not brush the hair off her child’s forehead, whisper in her child’s ear, kiss or hug her child for more than three seconds or blow raspberries on her child’s belly.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: And calls on the Premier to establish an investigation by a retired judicial officer into these matters which seeks to establish whether misconduct has occurred and whether the civil and human rights of the child and mother have been disregarded.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: I remind the honourable member that he must be in a position to authenticate the facts in his motion. I would ask him to drop in later on before I accept that motion.
Mr MESSENGER: Just to answer that question, the mother is watching you and the parliament at the moment. We are happy to be in your office with a Bible and documents after question time.

Mr SPEAKER: Before I accept that motion I would ask you to come and see the Clerk and me. I would say to the House that motions are to be about 250 words. I also want to check to ensure that this motion does not interfere with the standing orders in relation to child safety matters.

Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition)
(10.30 am): I give notice that I shall move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House recognises the importance of recreational and commercial fishing and associated industries to Queensland and opposes the secrecy of the deal between the Greens and the federal Labor Party that will close off a minimum of 30 per cent of Australian waters to fishing.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: The House has before it two notices of motion. I would ask the Leader of the House to indicate which one the government will accept.
Ms SPENCE: The government will accept the motion from the Leader of the Opposition.
Mr SPEAKER: The rule of anticipation will apply to the motion of the Leader of the Opposition.

Mr SPEAKER: During this morning’s session, students and teachers from Churchill State School in the electorate of Ipswich, Mansfield State School in the electorate of Mansfield and Tallebudgera State School in the electorate of Currumbin will visit the House.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Premier and Leader of the Opposition, Debate
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr LANGBROEK
(10.31 am): My first question without notice is to the Premier. Tonight the Prime Minister and the federal opposition leader will participate in a town hall style debate in front of real Queenslanders who are able to ask real questions. Less than an hour ago the Premier spruiked the merits of people’s question time. I will today be inviting media outlets to host a town hall style debate between us on the most important economic issues facing Queenslanders--that is, privatisation of our assets and the AAA credit rating--and I ask: will the Premier front up or will she hide?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. I am assuming that the press gallery will be in a lather of excitement at the prospect that the Leader of the Opposition might actually step outside his office and appear in front of a camera at any time. They cannot get him out from under the bed most days of the week.

Mr Springborg:
Where have you been during the federal election?
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!

Ms BLIGH: I think it has actually been a very interesting process in the federal election campaign to see both leaders having the opportunity to take questions directly in a number of forums, whether it is the town hall meeting that was held last week and the one that will be conducted tonight or whether it is things like the ABC program Q&A . I think all electors have seen more opportunity for more direct answers to unfiltered, direct questions from the public in this election than certainly I can remember in my lifetime. It might have happened a long time ago when the original parish pump meetings were held, but we have not seen it for a long time and I certainly applaud it.

I will be very happy to do the same in the state campaign that is due in 2012. What is the Leader of the Opposition talking about? He is talking about opportunities to debate in an election campaign. I will be happy to do that. What opportunity does the Leader of the Opposition have to debate me on these issues? Every second week that he comes into this parliament he has the opportunity to debate the issues and he has the opportunity to question me. I am very happy to do that every second week.

I am very happy also to take the question from the member for Southern Downs. Not content to let his leader ask the question of the Premier, he wanted to ask another question. He asked what I have been doing during the federal election campaign. The first thing I did in the federal election campaign was stand up as the first Premier in Australia with the Prime Minister and announce the biggest piece of infrastructure to be funded by a federal government. And what kind of government is it? It is a Labor government that is delivering the rail to Redcliffe.

I was then very happy to stand with federal minister Joe Ludwig and start the process on the Gold Coast Rapid Transit project. I was very happy again to stand with Joe Ludwig and open the new food and fibre research centre as part of the election campaign. And I was very happy to be on the stage as the president of the Australian Labor Party introducing and welcoming people to our launch. That is unlike those opposite, who have not been seen. I do not think the Leader of the Opposition was even at the launch of the LNP. He was hiding under the bed again.

Mr LANGBROEK: My second question without notice is also to the Premier. Yesterday the Treasurer whinged and whined that no-one was issuing press releases about positive economic data. Today I table the latest figures confirming that corporate collapses in Queensland have skyrocketed by 47 per cent in June this year compared to June last year, a jump never before seen in ASIC records. I cannot find a press release that the Treasurer issued commenting on this data, and I ask: could the Premier advise what positive news there is in a record number of corporate collapses under Labor’s watch in Queensland?
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Graph titled ‘Corporate Collapses by State (June 2010) (% YoY Change)’ [ 2762 ].
Tabled paper: Graph titled ‘Corporate Collapses by State for the month of June 2010’ [ 2763 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for his question. I draw attention to the fact that I certainly did not hear the Treasurer whingeing or whining yesterday. What I heard him doing was condemning those opposite in no uncertain terms for their continual efforts to drag Queensland down. There is no doubt that Queensland has had a rough time in the global financial crisis. The data that the member opposite is presenting is hard evidence that Queensland companies did it tough and some did not survive. What were the plans of those opposite to help the Queensland economy when it needed it most?
Mr Wallace: Cuts!

Ms BLIGH: Their plan was to cut jobs. What would that have done for more businesses? They were going to cut jobs out of the public sector. Twelve thousand jobs would have been cut. That is 12,000 people not shopping, not buying food and not buying houses, thereby endangering even more small businesses, even more companies. In fact, people will recall the member for Southern Downs standing around scratching his head saying, ‘What financial crisis?’ Queensland did it tough. There is no doubt about it. That is why we went to the election and said that jobs would be our No. 1 priority. We have kept that promise and we are delivering. It has been delivered for 12 straight months.

What is the proposal that the federal leader of the LNP is taking to the people of Australia on Saturday? Cuts to jobs, cuts to services, sacking people in the federal Public Service and an increase in company tax. That is a tax on Woolworths and Coles--a tax on groceries.
Mr Springborg: Have you heard of the mining super tax?

Ms BLIGH: Absolutely, and you could not get a more stark contrast. Labor will tax the big companies that are making a profit out of our country to put it back into regional areas and those opposite will tax the grocery stores where every Australian needs to buy their groceries every week. Australians do have a choice on Saturday. They should not choose Tony Abbott, who will cut jobs, slash services, wind back the economy, do more damage in Queensland than in any state of Australia with his efforts to pull back on the NBN, and tax every business, every company and every store so that every Australian will feel it.
Ms DARLING: My question is for the Premier. Can the Premier update the House on the progress of the government’s plan to create 100,000 jobs and build tomorrow’s Queensland?

Ms BLIGH: As I have just recalled for everybody, last year the Labor team and I went to the Queensland electorate with a very clear promise. We said we would make jobs our No. 1 priority. We said we would make it our organising and guiding principle to create and deliver 100,000 jobs into the Queensland economy. How did we say we would do that? It was not just pie in the sky. We had a very clear strategy. Firstly, we would keep our record building program going and, secondly, we would have the backbone to make the tough decisions necessary to do that. That is what we have done.

What is that infrastructure program delivering? It is making Queensland the jobs capital of Australia. For 12 months in a row--every single month for the past year--Queensland has created jobs. In the past four months, Queensland has created more jobs than any other state in Australia. In the past four weeks 5,600 new jobs were created in Queensland. That is what happens with a government that is committed to the dignity of work and to ensuring that Queensland families have an income. We are halfway through the term of this government and we are nearly two-thirds of the way to that job target. We are halfway through the term of the government and we are beyond the halfway point in our target.

Our building program is not just creating jobs for Queensland. We are leaving a legacy for Queensland. We are creating the infrastructure needed by growing populations in communities across this state. For example, we have completed the new $350 million Sir Leo Hielscher Bridge, which is part of a $2 billion investment in the Gateway Upgrade Project, and motorists are already enjoying the benefit of that. In Mackay, the $148 million Forgan Bridge duplication is underway. Motorists are already using the new bridge while the original bridge is being upgraded. In Townsville, the $110 million Douglas Arterial section of the Townsville Ring Road is being delivered. A partnership with the federal Labor government will help deliver the rest of it. In my own area we are building the next stages of the Eastern Busway. We are also building the next part of the big busway network for South-East Queensland, which is the Northern Busway. We are using massive tunnel-boring machines to build Airport Link.

Importantly, we are building social infrastructure that really underpins the health and wellbeing of communities. We are upgrading hospitals and building world-class facilities in Cairns, the Gold Coast, Mackay, Townsville, Mount Isa, Rockhampton and here in Brisbane. That is the difference between a Labor government that believes in building and a Liberal National Party that believes in slashing.

Mr SPRINGBORG: My question without notice is to the Premier. In the past 12 months, in Australia business bankruptcy has increased by four per cent, yet in Queensland it has increased by 47 per cent. Will the Premier--
Mr SPEAKER: Order, the props will be put down immediately.
Mr SPRINGBORG: --now take responsibility for this appalling economic situation or will she blame it on her Treasurer, Julia Gillard or Wayne Swan?

Ms BLIGH: Unlike the member for Southern Downs, I am very happy to take responsibility for the office that I hold. That is why economic strategy has been so critical to the work that our government has been doing. This morning, this question comes to us from a man who told the Queensland people that there was no problem. He said, ‘There’s no problem; absolutely none. Everything is rosy. Everything is coming up roses.’ He said, ‘There’s no problem.’
Mr Springborg: You said we were in the middle of a recession when we weren’t, Anna. Then you told the parliament late last year we weren’t.
Ms BLIGH: You’ve never got over it, have you? Do honourable members remember when he was a nice boy?
Mr Robertson: A long time ago.
Ms BLIGH: It was a long time ago.
Ms Simpson: Laugh off the assets sales, laugh off the petrol tax. People aren’t laughing; they’re hurting.
A government member: Are you being served?
Ms Simpson: It’s all a joke to you.
Mr SPEAKER: Both sides will come to order.

Ms BLIGH: There is nothing to laugh about in unemployment. Last year when we went to the election, thousands of Queenslanders were facing a dole queue. We understood that and we understood that if, as a government, we were going to do the responsible thing, we had to put our foot on the pedal and invest in the building program that is building communities, building demand for products and services, and building jobs.

The jobs that result from our investment are only one part of what happens when we commit to duplicate a bridge, or build a new road or a new hospital. It is only one part of it. What are the other parts? Wherever possible, all the services and materials are sourced from Queensland companies. Queensland companies are getting the contracts and without those contracts the companies would be collapsing. We know that when those opposite have work or jobs to do, such as setting up their commercial website, they send it all to New South Wales. Yesterday we talked about the website, but I did not have a chance to tell the House that the project was given to a New South Wales company. What are they doing? They are undercutting small businesses--
Mr Schwarten: A whole new export industry.

Ms BLIGH: It is a whole new export industry. The LNP website is undercutting small businesses. They are out there, competing in the market and undercutting small businesses by sending their business to New South Wales. The member should not come in here whingeing about jobs, because he has never thought about a job except his own. Our economic strategy is well known, it is working and it is delivering. We know that those on the other side of this chamber have no strategy. They do not have one single strategy.

Ms GRACE: The Bligh government has been focused on strengthening the Queensland economy in the aftermath of the global financial crisis. Can the Premier outline to the House how the government is helping Queensland families deal with cost of living pressures?

Ms BLIGH: In the Labor Party we believe that the greatest thing any government can do to make sure families can pay their bills is to keep them in work. We believe in the dignity of work, we believe in job creation programs and we believe in investing in public infrastructure, all of which drives the economy. We understand that Queensland mums, dads and pensioners want to provide for themselves and are prepared to do that by working hard if work is available. We have been focused on supporting jobs to ensure that Queensland families do not suffer the consequences of the global economic downturn. There is no doubt that there is more work to be done in Queensland and we are getting on with the job of doing it.

However, we should applaud those Queensland businesses that have kept their heads above water in the financial crisis, such as those that have worked with the government to make sure they get contracts out of our big projects. If we look around the world, parts of the United States are experiencing unemployment at rates not seen since the Great Depression and parts of the Japanese economy are falling way behind the performance of Queensland and Queensland companies. We want Queensland families to feel secure in work and that is why jobs will continue to be our No. 1 priority.

However, we also want to make sure that we are helping Queenslanders to make every dollar count. That is why in the last budget we did everything we could to help, in the financial circumstances we faced. We introduced a new first home owners grant for regional Queenslanders buying their first homes. In the previous budget we abolished stamp duty and mortgage duty for first home owners. We made changes to CTP insurance to help save motorists money. We introduced half-price travel for pensioners and a ClimateSmart Home Service through which Queensland families can save up to $325 annually on power bills. Almost 200,000 Queensland households have taken up that opportunity. We are out there, helping people to use and conserve energy wisely and thereby cut their bills as, indeed, our solar program is doing. The greatest threat to the cost of living of Queenslanders is a Tony Abbott federal government. What has he said? He wants to put a 1.5 per cent increase on company tax.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr Dickson interjected.

Ms BLIGH: He wants to increase it by 1.5 per cent. He wants to tax every single company, and members opposite are here, backing it up. The member for Maroochydore wants a tax on Coles and Woolies. She wants a tax on the IGA. She wants to see her constituents robbed of the NBN and have their groceries taxed. That is what the member for Maroochydore is going to back, just like every one of them.
A government member: It’s bad news for the website.
Ms BLIGH: It is very bad.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Just before I call the member for Caloundra, the interjection from the member for Buderim, ‘You’re killing people’--
Mr Dickson: I apologise.
Mr SPEAKER: Thank you very much. I call the honourable member for Caloundra.

Mr McARDLE: My question is to the Minister for Health. I refer the minister to Caralyn Dobbs, an employee of Queensland Health for 13 years. On 12 July Ms Dobbs was advised that her position had been reclassified from an AO2 to an AO3 and that she would receive backpay from 1 July 2009. When Ms Dobbs sought clarification as to when payment would be made, she was advised--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We are unable to provide dates as we are currently in negotiations with FSSP payroll to establish timelines for the implementation of the upgrades. As you can appreciate payroll have been dealing with urgent issues of late, which has delayed this process.
XML.Hansard-Body: Will the minister now reveal how many other Queensland Health staff are not receiving backpay due to Labor’s mismanagement of the payroll system? I table the correspondence.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Letter, dated 12 July 2010, from Naomi Dwyer, Chief Operations Officer, to Caralyn Dobbs relating to upgraded position [ 2764 ].
Tabled paper: Email, dated 6 August 2010, from Centralised Job Evaluation Unit to Caralyn Dobbs relating to pay following upgrade of position [ 2765 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. I note that he sees the appropriate place to raise it is in here rather than indicating to the House that he would advocate on behalf of the individual staff member of Queensland Health. I am more than happy--
Mr Seeney: You wouldn’t reply to the letter.

Mr LUCAS: Yes, that is right. The member for Callide tabled a letter last time parliament sat in relation to a meeting that I had with the member for Cleveland. He raised the matter and I said, ‘I’ll go and have a talk to you about it,’ and then he complains about me physically speaking with people. That is the way those opposite work. They are funny. They complain when they raise something and I say, ‘I would like to talk to you personally about it,’ and I do that, but then apparently that is not responding when I offer to personally meet a member of parliament to talk about their concern.

I am more than happy to have a look at that. One of the things we have pride in under this government is the very substantial increase in the number of staff that we have employed in Queensland Health. One of the things that we have done under this government is significantly increase the pay for our workforce--whether that be our medical staff or indeed our nursing staff or indeed our allied health professional staff who are at the end of quite a significant process of negotiation for further pay for them.

There is one thing more than anything else that affects the future employment of people in the health system and the continuity of that, and that relates to the future financing of Health. This government this year will outlay $9.99 billion in Health--a record budget, a 10 per cent increase. I note also that we released figures last week to show that we had record surgery for the year, record surgery for the quarter and record low long wait lists--
Mr McArdle: Longer waiting times than ever before.
Mr LUCAS: --massively shorter than the long waits when your crowd were in power and he was the health minister.
Mr McArdle: Two hundred thousand on the waiting list for the waiting list.

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for raising the issue of specialist outpatient waiting times, because one of things that was announced the other day by Julia Gillard as a way to help deal with specialist outpatient waiting times was a change in the manner in which you would be able to use the NBN for the purposes of consultation with specialists. We have heard deafening silence from the other side of the House. What is even more concerning is that so many people on the other side of the House represent people in areas that are remote that would specifically benefit from this. Indeed, the member for Warrego in the past has said that that is what he wants. On no occasion has he even bothered to come in here and claim that.
Do not in any respect claim interest in the staff of Queensland Health. In estimates you did not ask one question about the current payroll situation, notwithstanding having two hours to do it.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Direct your comments through the chair.
Mr LUCAS: You absolute hypocrite.
Mr McArdle: Tell the truth about it. You dodged and weaved your way around.
Mr LUCAS: Not one question.
Mr McArdle: You wouldn’t have the guts to answer the question.
Mr LUCAS: Get on to Madonna King again.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I think you have both had a go.

Ms FARMER: My question without notice is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. Can the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health outline for the House how comprehensive health reform will deliver benefits for Queenslanders?

Mr LUCAS: I am delighted to deal with this matter. I do note the conclusion to my previous answer: the member for Caloundra did not ask one question in estimates about the current payroll status in Health, not one. I invite people to look at Hansard .

The Bligh and Gillard governments believe in universal public health care. They believe that, regardless of colour, creed or social status, every Australian should be able to access free public health care. It is the foundation of our beliefs. That was Ned Hanlon’s core belief in Queensland as well. We believe in investing in social services like education and health care and believe that we have built a nation where this is a basic right. That is unlike many First World countries. In fact, the intergenerational report comments on the equity in this country compared to most other countries in the world. We know that we in Australia have the second longest life expectancy on earth, and that says something about it. What is more, there is many a First World country where basic health care, much less world-class health care, is not a basic right--the United States, for example.
