If you are going to hang your hat on a belief, you have to have a policy to back it up, which is more than I can say for the other side of the House and certainly more than I can say for Tony Abbott. Yesterday the Australian Healthcare and Hospitals Association--which is the only national industry body for the public healthcare sector and the only independent advocate for public hospitals and health services at the national level--released a report card into election health promises. The report card has carved in stone what has been clear for many years with both the Liberals and the Nationals when it comes to health: they have no policies. In fact, it is impossible to govern without a clear vision for what you want to do. Health at a state level is the single biggest item of budgetary expenditure, and the Bligh and Gillard governments have a clear vision for the future.

Contrast that with the last state election when the member for Caloundra announced a mental health policy without staff. That is how much he cared about staff then. He cared so much about them that he did not want to have them so he did not have to pay them at all. Many a time we have stood in this House and challenged the other side to deliver a policy, an idea, even a light bulb moment, but time and again they have failed.

It is not just the Queensland Liberals and Nationals who have a policy vacuum. Let us go back to the Healthcare and Hospitals Association report card. In the area of national reform: Labor--establishment of a national health and hospitals network, national oversight with local governance; the coalition--no policy. In the area of national bodies: Labor--establishment of independent, accountable bodies, tick; Abbott--no policy. In the area of local government: Labor--local health networks and Medicare locals implementation plan, tick; the coalition--individual hospital boards, no networks for PHC, some hospital networks, cross.

On the issue of access to elective surgery: Labor--funding to expand elective surgery places, tick; Abbott--no policy. On the issue of access to emergency departments: Labor, tick--we know the four-hour rule there; Abbott--no policy. In relation to infrastructure: Labor--hospital health fund, tick; Abbott--no policy. In relation to e-health: Abbott--as we have said, and I will say again today, absolutely no policy. I table that document.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Document titled ‘Summary--AHHA election statement’ [ 2766 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms DAVIS: My question without notice is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. I refer to the Department of Oral Health at the Royal Children’s Hospital, where sterilising equipment is supposed to be tested and validated every 12 months. Will the minister explain why, as part of Labor’s mismanagement of health, a breach of infection control occurred where a steriliser used had not been validated for more than two years?

Mr LUCAS: I am more than happy to investigate that matter. I am delighted that the honourable member has a question, because I know that she has been complaining long and loud to everyone who will listen in her own party that the powers that be will not ever give her an opportunity--
Mr Springborg interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: Order!
The honourable the Deputy Premier.
Mr LUCAS: I know that she has been complaining long and loud to everyone in her party who will listen that she never gets a go. Having said that--
Ms Davis interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! It would help if--

Mr LUCAS: I am more than happy for her to take a point of order if I am not being accurate here, Mr Speaker. As I said before, I am more than happy to have that issue specifically investigated. But there is one way in which you will make a real difference when it comes to hospitals--and that is investing not only in the bricks and mortar but in the people as well. That is investing not only in the bricks and mortar and the people but also in the services and the throughput that happens there. One thing that we have is a health capital works program of almost $7 billion. The state that is nearest to that is New South Wales at $2.3 billion. Every time we build those new facilities we upgrade them to allow further services to be provided for Queenslanders.

We know that Tony Abbott--he has announced this--would not pay states for hospital beds until they were delivered and he would not commit to 60-40 funding of our hospitals. We know that in the future the inexorable growth that is happening in our health system that will require things such as more operations and more procedures so therefore more sterilising procedures would be unfunded under Abbott. Abbott will not end the blame game. People are sick to death of Commonwealth governments not playing their role. They are sick to death of people like the member for Toowoomba South ripping money out of Rockhampton Hospital, as he did when he was health minister. He wore as a badge of honour that he ripped money out of the Rockhampton Hospital. He did that and he did it with relish. He left Queensland with a long wait list, and the member for Toowoomba South--
Mr Horan interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Toowoomba South.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Both sides of the House will come to order. The Deputy Premier has the call.

Mr LUCAS: What is more, he left Queensland--yes, ‘he’; not someone who used to be here, but ‘he’--with a long wait list for elective surgery, notwithstanding that the population of Queensland had grown substantially in that time, which was massive compared to that list now. We have a greater population and we have got stuck into it, yet he is still here reckoning he can make a contribution. That is an absolute disgrace.
Ms JOHNSTONE: My question is to the Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development. Can the Treasurer update the House on economic forecasts for Queensland’s major trading partners?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Townsville for her question. Being from Townsville, she knows the importance of trade and the importance of export industries in supporting jobs and supporting the regional economies of Queensland. Queensland is the second most trade exposed state in Australia, and therefore the fortunes of our trading partners are absolutely vital to calibrating the economic policies that we as a state government pursue. Therefore, I am pleased that Consensus Economics has released an update for our major trading partners of last week which shows that across 2010 they are now predicted to grow by 4.8 per cent. That is above the trend growth they have experienced in recent times. Why? Because that reflects the nature of the downturn that has been experienced.

Where we see the strength is amongst Japan and amongst the rest of non-Japan Asia, amongst the trading nations with whom we do the most business in our region. Those figures also reveal that within the data there are areas of softness. Europe continues to be a big challenge, ticking along at just over one per cent growth. The United States has come back to under three per cent growth.

The lesson from this data is that the risks remain out there, that the big questions remain out there, that the challenges remain out there and that the path to global recovery is one that requires government vigilance. That is why, absolutely, governments around the world require a strong economic plan, a clear understanding, a clear policy framework and clear actions to put in place. That is what we have got. We have a $17 billion building program for the second year in a row. We are building the infrastructure of the future and delivering jobs. We are supporting more than 100,000 jobs, especially in regional economies like Townsville. That is why we have generated jobs for the last 12 months. That is why we have led the nation for the last four months.

Put that in contrast to the policy proposition from those opposite--where they do not have a clue, where they do not have a policy, where they do not have a jobs target, where they do not have an economics strategy. We all remember that their policy is to cut jobs, to cut services, to cut a billion dollars out of vital public services. Who are they cheering for on Saturday? They are cheering for the bloke who wants to cut the NBN, who wants to slash GP clinics, who wants to slash trade training centres, as they continue in the great tory tradition of slashing and burning and cutting services and cutting jobs.

The lesson is clear on Saturday. If you want to vote for jobs, if you want to vote for growth, if you want to vote for building, then you are going to vote for Labor and you are going to vote for Julia Gillard to keep building Australia’s future. However, if you want to cut jobs and if you want to cut services, then you are going to vote for Tony Abbott and his team from the upper class twitocracy on the other side here--those indolents who are not prepared to lift a finger, who do not stand for anything, who will not chart a course for the future. So if you want to vote for a better future for this state and for Australia then you are going to vote for those people who build this nation and who build this state. You are going to vote on Saturday for a Labor government that will continue to chart a course for the future of the Australian economy.

Mr BLEIJIE: My question is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. On 29 May, a constituent of mine, Mrs Mary Levets, broke her ankle and was admitted to Caboolture Hospital and on the following day was transferred to Redcliffe Hospital. The operation she required did not proceed. On 4 June, Mrs Levets’s husband collected his wife and waited three days for an appointment at the Nambour fracture clinic. Mrs Levets arrived for her operation on 8 June and was told that because the foot was swollen she could not be operated on so was kept in overnight. On 9 June she was sent home and told to wait until she received a letter giving a new operation date. Come 18 June, her husband attempted for four hours to phone the fracture clinic. Mary was then finally operated on some 25 days after breaking her ankle. Can the minister explain why, after bragging in this place on so many occasions about how wonderful the Bligh government is, people like 73-year-old Mrs Levets are forced to wait 25 days and be transferred between three hospitals for a broken ankle?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. I will actually provide some further information in relation to some of the issues that have been raised before. I indicated before the number of long waits over a year in relation to Queensland Health. At the current time, there are about 137; in 1997-98, before this government came to power and when the member for Toowoomba South was the health minister, they were 8,500.

The honourable member has raised a question today in good faith about a lady’s surgery issues and I am more than happy to have a look at that. I do know this: when you take our 137 away from your 8,500 you end up with in excess of 8,300. So it is not just the 36 days which I think was the period of time that the honourable member raised; there is a difference between these two governments in that more than 8,300 people would have been waiting over a year for their elective surgery. That is the essential difference. It is unacceptable when people wait too long, and that is why we are absolutely focused on that. What I say today is that there are 137 people waiting over a year for surgery under this government, but there were 8,500--
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! There is too much crossfire.

Mr LUCAS: We had a year of record elective surgery, we had a quarter of record elective surgery, and the aggregate over long waits across all three categories was the lowest it has ever been. It is true to say that for categories 1 and 2 the long waits are higher; however, 90 per cent of category 1 patients receive their surgery within 36 days. We will continue to target that. It requires the cooperation of our surgeons and we are getting excellent cooperation from the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons, including people like Professor Russell Stitz.
Mr McArdle interjected.

Mr LUCAS: The honourable member for Caloundra quite rightly raises the issue of specialist outpatient waiting times. That is why the election of Tony Abbott is such a threat to people, because he will not support training additional doctors and additional specialists. This is a function of one thing and a function of one thing only: the number of specialists who actually operate in our system. The rate that we pay our doctors is superior to any other state so we know that is not a factor. The issue is the training numbers and the places of specialist medical staff that we have. One thing we know is that Tony Abbott constitutes the greatest threat to that because we know that he did it in the past. We also know that when he was in charge of health policy he did things like take over the Mersey Hospital in Tasmania but he did not do anything else. That is the sort of flakiness you get.

Ms MALE: My question without notice is to the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade. Would the minister update the House on any initiatives to help Queensland businesses tap into the potential of clean, green energy technology?

Mr ROBERTSON: Once again, I thank the member for the question and for her ongoing interest in matters to do with renewable energy. Once again, I am pleased to stand in this place to talk about a new initiative as part of our overall Queensland renewable energy strategy.

Queenslanders are embracing renewable energy sources, and today I announce a new initiative to help businesses reduce greenhouse gas emissions and save on their energy bills. The Office of Clean Energy will today launch web content that provides examples of how large buildings can switch to clean energy sources, cut power bills and slash carbon emissions. The content will encourage developers and building owners to install on-site, low-emission energy systems including solar, wind, natural gas, and biomass and biodiesel to name just a few renewable energy technologies which can be applied in today’s modern construction environment. It will provide information on the significant benefits of on-site generated power and includes guides on how a developer can go green with energy generation.

The potential savings in cuts to emissions that can be made are remarkable. That is why renewable energy is one of the keys to tackling climate change, but it is new technology so government must take the lead and encourage others to follow. That, after all, is the role of government. We will not shy away from the tough challenges of introducing new renewable energy technologies into Queensland because that is the task of a responsible government, but it is a task that clearly the LNP and particularly its colleagues in Canberra do not understand. Just last week the Leader of the Opposition put out a press release in which the opposition finally shed some light on its otherwise non-existent plan for renewable energy and climate change in Australia. If one read it carefully, as with all LNP policy, one would have probably missed it. With the usual manufactured gusto, it said, ‘Labor likes to make big promises on the environment but they never back up the words and spin with real action.’ This is the same ‘real action’ that climate change denier Tony Abbott has promised on renewable energy--the same real action which will slash $650 million from renewable energy research in this country. Right at the time that we should be investing in renewable energy technologies, Tony Abbott has announced he will slash $650 million from the existing renewable energy research program.

That just follows on from the state LNP. We know from the estimates that, if given a chance, the LNP would slash the Office of Climate Change and it would slash the Office of Clean Energy. The LNP has no vision for renewable energy for Queensland. It is once again a policy-free zone when it comes to one of the most important challenges that this state and this country face in terms of a cleaner energy future for this state and this country.

Ms BATES: My question without notice is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. I table a copy of a letter from Q-Comp confirming that an injury to a nurse had occurred due to unreasonable management practices. In short, she was bullied. Given that a culture of bullying and intimidation remains rife throughout Queensland Health under Labor, does the minister finally accept that the culture of Queensland Health cannot be changed without changing this government?
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Copy of reasons for decision, dated 16 August 2010, by Q-Comp relating to a claim by Susan Dale [ 2767 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. We have about 78,000 staff in Queensland Health, and one complaint of bullying is one too many. However, one of the things we know with an organisation that large is we need to make sure that at all levels people understand the appropriate way in which to deal with their fellow staff members. Members of the House would know, for example, that a few years ago in Townsville we had a situation where the cardiac unit was shut down as a result of doctors not being able to get on with doctors. It had nothing in that instance to do with management.

One of the things that is very important and that Queensland Health has invested significantly in is management training for people at a middle level, for want of a better word. I am not talking about hospital administrators; I am talking about nurses or doctors who manage units. I can say as a legal professional--and I know it is the same in relation to nursing and medicine--that management training is not integral to those professions where it might be in many others. Dealing with people in increasingly complex systems that are working 24 hours, seven days a week is an important aspect of training our own staff.

That is why, for example, Tony O’Connell from the Centre for Healthcare Improvement has invested a very significant effort in supporting management training at that middle level, because that is frequently the interface between lower level workers and management. It is not at a senior level. The director-general does not go down and direct people individually. We have a network of 240 workplace equity and harassment officers in Queensland Health, and bullying is not acceptable at any point in time.

I will say this, though: while it is the responsibility of everybody in the organisation, while it is the responsibility of every manager in the organisation, frankly, the ability to interact between a director-general or a minister and an individual staff member is inappropriate. We know that there have been examples, particularly on the other side of politics, where ministers have sought to individually intervene to direct staff to do things. We do not do that. It is not appropriate to do that. That is why it is very important for us to ensure that our staff and our managers, particularly at that management level, are appropriately trained.

Ms STONE: My question without notice is to the Minister for Transport. Can the minister please outline the government’s funding for public transport and the prospects for future federal funding for public transport in Queensland?

Ms NOLAN: I thank the member for Springwood for her very good question. Queenslanders know that this government is passionately committed to better public transport. We are committed to it because public transport is what makes our urban areas sustainable, and we are committed to it because good quality, affordable public transport massively improves Queenslanders’ quality of life.

When this government was elected, there were no busways in South-East Queensland. In recent years we have built 24 kilometres of busways for the south-east. In the lean years of the Howard government--a government which committed no money to public transport in this state at all--we forged ahead building public transport. We extended rail to the Gold Coast, building rail to Varsity Lakes. They did nothing; we built.
Mr Nicholls interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Clayfield!

Ms NOLAN: I note the member for Clayfield’s claim that the Howard government was in fact committed to public transport. Then he stands in very stark contrast to his federal leader, who recently, as I informed the House in the last sitting week, said this--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Transport infrastructure is a state responsibility. The Commonwealth Government should no more have to fund it than the State Government should have to buy new tanks for the army.
XML.Hansard-Body: The member for Clayfield might want to pretend that at a federal level the LNP is committed to public transport, but if that is his position then in these words written down, the gospel truth, he is directly contradicted by his federal leader. What did Mr Abbott say in his recent manifesto Battlelines ? Not only did he say that the Commonwealth should not fund public transport; he questioned the need for it at all when he wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... there just aren’t enough people wanting to go from a particular place to a particular destination at a particular time to justify any vehicle larger than a car.
XML.Hansard-Body: In Battlelines Mr Abbott wrote essentially not only that public transport should not be funded by the Commonwealth but also that it is not necessary at all. One of the key divides between the two sides in this federal election is the question of public transport. Labor is committed to building public transport, with substantial money going into the Gold Coast Rapid Transit project and $700 million for Redcliffe rail, while the LNP federally believes not only that it should not fund it but also that public transport, it would seem, does not need to exist at all.

Mr FOLEY: My question without notice is to the Minister for Health. It appears that the issue of transporting people to treatment from rural areas where there is no public transport is not covered under Queensland Health policy. There is a denial of access to treatment where there is no family member able to drive these patients. The demographics of Queensland would suggest that this is, and will remain, an issue to be addressed. Will the minister change the policy to allow these patients to have access to timely health services?

Mr LUCAS:
I thank the honourable member for the question. I am more than happy to seek some further information from him if he has some specific instances, but I will say a number of things about transport when it comes to people in rural areas. There is a Commonwealth inquiry into the Patient Travel Subsidy Scheme. I know that a number of members have made representations in the past in relation to the overnight accommodation level, for example. The mileage level is about at the rate that it would cost in petrol for a four-cylinder car but it does not take into account wear and tear. We cover the full cost of airfares. We have a program of building facilities where we will provide overnight accommodation through various NGOs. We opened one in Rockhampton a little while ago. That is very significant.

In relation to people who have no ability to transport themselves, I will have to seek some information as to whether there might be situations when it comes to non-emergent matters. In an emergent situation the Ambulance Service or the RFDS would assist. I will have to seek some information about that. I advise the honourable member that that is why the announcement by the Gillard government that it will provide significant funding to allow internet consultations will make a very significant difference for many people. The honourable member for Caloundra spoke about surgical waiting lists before. I have spoken about them. Many of the specialist outpatient waiting times for people are for medical matters. They are not in fact surgical matters and may never require an operation. For example, if a person has diabetes and they see an endocrinologist it may be that they are not going to get operated on.

The opportunity to provide services to people without them having to travel out of their communities is something that we will see more and more of. What we need to do is two things. Firstly, we need to have a broadband network that has sufficient bandwidth that it allows people to talk to each other in a seamless fashion. Secondly, we cannot penalise practitioners, whether they be general practitioners or specialists, who might seek to provide those services. We have had a situation up until the present time that if a person goes to their local GP in Cloncurry and then talks to a specialist in Townsville their GP is out of pocket because there is not an MBS billing schedule for it. That is really quite wrong. This will address that. As I said to members, why Tony Abbott has not sought to match this I do not know because it will make a real difference.

The other thing that Julia Gillard announced--and Tony Abbott said no, the telephone system is good enough--is the ability to ultimately have an online overnight consultation with doctors and nurses on the equivalent of 13 HEALTH. I know as a parent, particularly when people have their first child, people get very concerned about things that they do not properly understand. It is one thing to talk to someone and describe something over the phone. I am partly colour blind and am not very good at describing colours or flushes or those sorts of things in people. If medical people could see someone over the internet with a reasonable degree of specificity they could then make a difference. I am happy to look at the issue raised by the honourable member. But I also do think that if this significant investment in technology could affect anywhere, it could affect health.

Mr CHOI: My question is to the Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability. Can the minister update the House on what the Bligh government is doing to protect the environment in Moreton Bay and the bayside suburbs?

Ms JONES: I thank the honourable member for the question. I know that the member for Capalaba is genuinely concerned about protecting the environmental values of Moreton Bay and the bayside suburbs. He is one of those backbenchers who is constantly coming through my door, whether it is to talk to me about the future prospects of North Stradbroke Island or something else. He is a strong believer in transitioning North Stradbroke Island to green jobs and a sustainable future. He supports our vision there. I will be working very closely with him on our plan going forward to make sure that North Stradbroke Island is a place where people can come, enjoy and experience this wonderful part of our region.

The member for Capalaba has also been a great supporter of the plan that we have to protect greater tracts of koala habitat in his region. Already we have protected over eight hectares on Mount Gravatt-Capalaba Road under a $45.5 million program to purchase koala habitat. He has also supported our government’s position with regard to the long-term sustainability of Moreton Bay. All of these programs are being undertaken by this Labor government because of our commitment to protecting this unique part of Queensland.

Once again, these are all things that have been opposed not only by the LNP in this chamber and its members on the ground but also by the federal member for Bowman, Andrew Laming. Members could imagine my surprise when I saw the advertisement in the Bayside Bulletin this week where the honourable member for Bowman claims that the LNP is green.

Members would think that that would be enough shock to throw us off our chairs, but it gets worse. True to form, Mr Laming not only tried to pretend that the LNP was green but he asked the taxpayers of Australia to pay for it. True to form, he came out at the beginning of the day saying, ‘I assure you that it is in the guidelines. I did not do anything wrong. I’m sure if you examine it you will find it is in the guidelines.’ But, oops, his campaign manager had to come out later in the day and say, ‘I’m sorry.’
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. There is too much crossfire across the chamber. The member for Redlands, you have had more than a fair go. I call the honourable minister.

Ms JONES: Mr Speaker, quite frankly if I were a member of the LNP I would be embarrassed too. The member for Bowman is using taxpayers’ dollars to fund advertising which breaks the rules contained in the guidelines. He said it was in the guidelines but his campaign manager had to come out and correct him and say that taxpayers will not be paying for it.

This is the second time this week that there has been an investigation into the actions of the member for Bowman. Not only has the member for Bowman used taxpayers’ funds to pay for ads but he has also used taxpayers’ funds to fund restaurant guides. They want to promote businesses in New South Wales and print restaurant guides to hand out as an inducement when people go to vote. If this is true, it is clearly a breach--
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Both sides of the House! I call the minister.
Ms JONES: What we have seen once again --
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Both sides of the House will come to order!

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: My question without notice is to the Minister for Health. The Queensland Cancer Council has just released data showing that for the 2003 to 2007 period Gladstone had a 10 per cent higher rate of cancers diagnosed compared to all of Queensland. The recent clean and healthy air study dealt with air quality. Will the minister ensure that the causes of this higher diagnosis rate are thoroughly investigated?

Mr LUCAS:
I thank the honourable member for the question. I am a bit of a fan of Gladstone. I think it is a wonderful city. We take the health of people in Gladstone and people in our regional cities and indeed all of Queensland very seriously. Gladstone is very much an economic powerhouse. Its industry is its strength. There is no reason people of that city should have to worry that polluted air endangers their health. That is why we do the sort of testing we have done.

We initiated the Clean and Healthy Air for Gladstone Project aimed at better understanding Gladstone’s air quality and identifying potential risks to health. Members will recall that the study released relatively recently indicated that it would appear that there are no issues arising as result of that. Additionally, we reviewed data around asthma, miscarriages, total cancers and leukaemia in the Gladstone area in early 2007. The review showed Gladstone had broadly the same incidences of these diseases as the rest of Queensland, with the only exception being a higher rate of chronic lymphoid leukaemia, of CLL. The review did not identify environmental factors such as pollutants that would have contributed to or caused high rates of CLL. It found that air quality and environmental factors could not be blamed. That was independently reviewed by Professor Roder of the Cancer Council of South Australia.

In relation to the current matters raised by the honourable member, I am more than happy to seek advice from my department. But I do note the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare’s 2010 report, which I would behove members to read, stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The National Cancer Clearinghouse 2003 shows that in 2003-2005 the incidence of cancer decreased slightly with remoteness, with combined rates in Outer Regional, Remote and Very remote areas 7% lower than Major cities. Accordingly, the incidence of most types of cancer was lower outside Major cities , the exceptions being head and neck cancer (5% higher ...) melanoma (8% higher) and lip cancer (60% higher). The cancers showing higher incidence outside Major cities are generally preventable and occur either through smoking and alcohol consumption ... or sun exposure (melanoma).
XML.Hansard-Body: I think we were talking about melanoma and lung cancer in relation to Gladstone. That may in part provide some information. I am more than happy to have that examined.

In relation to the matter raised by the member for Aspley, I am advised by Queensland Health that Dr Steve Atkin from the Children’s Oral Health Service advised that there was no sterilisation failure at the Royal Children’s Oral Health Service. I am advised that there are four levels of sterilisation checks that are conducted and that a routine check showed the fourth level of validation, a fail-safe audit to ensure other validations were conducted properly, was not conducted on time.

However, when the delay was identified and the audit was conducted, it was shown that the sterilisation had been undertaken properly and there were no sterilisation issues with the instruments. The Chief Dental Officer has also confirmed that he believes appropriate action has been taken to clarify the responsibilities to the appropriate officer at the Children’s Oral Health Service to ensure that the validation issue is addressed. The Chief Dental Officer has further confirmed the annual validation check is the lowest of the four different tests done on sterilised instruments.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! The minister’s time has expired. I call the member for--
Mr LUCAS: The testing is done to test functionality--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: The minister’s time has expired. I call the member for Barron River.

Mr WETTENHALL: My question is to the Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport. Minister, I note that the federal Labor government recently announced a $3.5 million upgrade to the Jones Park rugby league ground in Cairns. Can the minister please update the House on how the Bligh government is working with the federal Labor government to ensure Queenslanders have the best major sporting infrastructure available?
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Minister, you have one minute.

Mr REEVES: I thank the honourable member for the question. That upgrade was a great announcement and it just shows what the Gillard government is putting its resources into, just like the state Labor government. Our record speaks for itself. In terms of the Suncorp Stadium redevelopment, the Queensland Labor government committed $280 million. What did Tony Abbott and the Howard government commit? Zero! In terms of the Gabba redevelopment, the Queensland Labor government committed $184 million when Tony Abbott and the Howard government committed zero. In terms of the Dairy Farmers upgrade, the Queensland Labor government committed $27 million when Tony Abbott and the Howard government committed zero. In terms of Skilled Park, the Queensland Labor government committed $160 million when Tony Abbott and the Howard government committed zero. In terms of the Gold Coast stadium, the Queensland Labor government committed $72 million and the federal Labor government committed $36 million. Its record speaks for itself. We got nothing under the former Liberal government. Those opposite want to back-pedal. They do not care about Queensland. They want all of the money to go to the southern states. Federal Labor and this state Labor government back the stadiums and back Queensland.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! The time for question time has expired.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Further Answer to Question; Queensland Health, Payroll System
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health) (11.31 am), by leave: The member for Caloundra asked a question about the workload of payroll staff and a staff member who is waiting for backpay from the award reclassification process. The letter relates to a reclassification process that has taken place under the last EB7. The staff member sought reclassification of her position and succeeded. This is a process that was agreed to by the government under the generous EB arrangements that have resulted in very significant pay rises and additional staff numbers in Queensland Health. In contrast, the opposition went to the last election promising to cut staff and cut costs.

The letter is self-evident. Most AO2s and AO3s are administration staff--not all, most. There are over 80,000 Queensland Health employees and the reclassification exercise affects the positions of over 10,000 staff in more than 50 positions. The process has taken a number of years and significant backpay is owing. It is not surprising that the process of getting those staff backpaid takes time. That is what the letter says. So we reclassified them and said that we would do the right thing by them and pay them for that reclassification. The process has been undertaken in consultation with unions and staff as part of the interest based bargaining process. I congratulate all parties on this successful outcome.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! The time for private members’ statements will expire at 12.03 pm.

Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (11.33 am): Today this parliament heard the latest chapter in the tale of Labor’s mismanagement of the economy, yet yesterday the Premier had the gall to come in here and say that Queensland is recovering because of her government’s policies. From 2009 to 2010, the number of companies that collapsed in the month of June skyrocketed by 47 per cent--up from 133 companies in 2009 to 196 companies in 2010. Nine companies per working day are going broke under the incompetent economic management of the Bligh Labor government. That is 196 businesses that will not be employing Queenslanders. Many of these businesses are owned by ordinary Queensland families. Many of these families have lost their homes, along with their business.

But day after day members of the ALP come into this place and make speeches about how well things are going. They are deluded! This long-term Labor government is crippling businesses with increased taxes, fees and charges. Rego, fuel costs, water charges, road tolls, business licences, public transport charges and environmental levies have all seen double-digit increases over the last year, and it is no wonder that businesses and families are struggling to cope! It offends me that those opposite continue to pretend that people are not suffering. How dare they pretend that businesses are not going under? It is time they owned up and acknowledged the damage that they have done to Queensland’s great economic reputation.

As people head to the ballot box this weekend, they need to remember that Kevin Rudd, the former Prime Minister, said that everything was costed and everything was paid for. We had money in the bank and we had no deficit, yet now we have new taxes and we have debt and deficit--exactly what Labor has done in this state. It has given us a fuel tax in the last year and after the last budget we now have a waste tax. During the term of the Borbidge-Sheldon government, from 1996 to 1998, we had no debt, we had no deficit and we had money in the bank. But that is not what Labor will do. That is what Queenslanders need to remember when they go to the ballot box. Labor members will say anything before the election and do something else afterwards!

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! Before calling the member for Cook, I would remind members that the person who has the floor is usually the only person to speak. I would ask you to respect that.

Mr O’BRIEN (Cook--ALP) (11.35 am): Last Wednesday I joined with the federal member for Leichhardt, Jim Turnour, to officially open the new $13 million development of stage 3 of the Western Cape College at Weipa. This includes more than $6 million of federal grants. Over the last six years Weipa has been transformed by this government with a new $45 million hospital, vastly better roads, a new swimming pool, boating facilities and a complete transformation of the school delivered over three stages. Schools are the hubs of our communities and our students deserve to learn and prosper in 21st century facilities, which is what is being delivered at Weipa. The Bligh government together with the federal government is spending $10 million a day on infrastructure right across Queensland.

Stage 3 of this campus is just one example of how we are transforming the face of our schools. This development gives the children at this college a new performing arts building, a new administration building for staff and parents, a remodelled and expanded special education unit, staff and general car park, covered drop-off area for the special education unit, a new kiln for the arts students, and an electrical upgrade to the manual arts and home economics building. The Commonwealth’s $6 million contribution built a huge sports stadium which will be used by the entire community and three state-of-the-art science classrooms. Let me assure the House that staff and the community were not complaining about wasting money or any other rubbish Tony Abbott is raving on about at the moment. The community was very happy and proud of the fantastic new facilities which will serve the Weipa community for decades to come.

The Bligh government’s $850 million State Schools of Tomorrow project is also rolling out around Queensland, and Weipa received 10 classroom upgrades as part of that funding. The project has been worth more than $480,000 to that school. These are fantastic new improvements at that school which will drive that community forward in years to come. I am proud to be associated with the great work that we are doing in Weipa, particularly at this school.

Ms SIMPSON (Maroochydore--LNP) (11.37 am): When Premier Anna Bligh and Labor say that they are from the government and they are here to help, watch out for their sticky fingers reaching deep into your pockets! Queenslanders face taxing times, and Labor’s answer is to tax Queenslanders more. There is the half billion dollar petrol tax, rego is up 27 per cent and power is up 34 per cent--and water has been an absolute debacle. Once again I rise in this parliament to stand up for Queenslanders and the Sunshine Coast and highlight how the wasteful spending on the SEQ water grid--more than $7 billion--which has no business plan, is now hurting people. That is particularly so on the Sunshine Coast, where our water security was robbed by a one-way pipeline while higher bulk water charges are now landing in ratepayers’ mailboxes.

This debacle is compounded by the mess which is Unitywater--a council owned entity which council claims it does not control and the state government claims that it does. But the buck-passing has to stop. I table a number of water bills which show how this has got absolutely out of control and people are being charged ridiculous amounts wrongly.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Bundle of accounts, correspondence and articles relating to water [ 2768 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: One person’s bill showed usage of 610 litres a day for last year rising to 10,228 litres a day for the same period this year. I don’t think so! And their projected state water bulk charge? Some $1,869.15--a combination of a failed policy and even worse execution. The Mooloolaba Bowls Club has just been hit with a $10,000 rise for the half year, which it also says is outrageous and over the top. But one constituent--a pensioner--said about the arrival of her new water charge--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I was shocked and distressed. This amounts to stealing from innocent victims.
XML.Hansard-Body: She went on to say that she had been saving for an electric bed so that she could raise her disabled sick husband, but this water bill was putting this out of reach. This is failed Labor policy that is hurting people!

Mr FINN (Yeerongpilly--ALP)
(11.39 am): Residents in the Yeerongpilly electorate, whom I am honoured to represent in this parliament, are keenly awaiting a design proposal for the Cross River Rail project. Of key importance for local people is the location of the southern tunnel entrance and the associated community impacts. My advocacy for a tunnel portal located in the Clapham area and minimal impacts on the great character and amenity of local suburbs being incorporated into design and throughout construction is well known.

Recently, the Cross River Rail team undertook the second consultation round of the project and southside residents turned out in force. Throughout the July to August consultation period, nine consultation events were held, 630,000 newsletters were distributed, 3,600 property owners were direct mailed, 153 calls were received on the Cross River Rail hotline, 285 email inquiries were sent to the project email address, 218 online and 195 hard-copy feedback forms were completed and 825 people attended a consultation event. Of those feedback figures, for the southern section consultation events 200 people attended the event at Dutton Park State School, 100 people attended at Moorooka State School and 250 people attended the event at the Fairfield Gardens Shopping Centre. That is some 550 attendances at local southside events and I thank the community for turning out in force and having their say.

I know the sentiment in the local community well and I, too, await the proposed reference design, including the portal location, going out for public comment later this year. The residents in my local area want certainty about the project design and they want their feedback to be considered in detail. I welcome the assurances that project design recommendations will take into account community and key stakeholder feedback, community benefits and impacts and environmental issues, including heritage values. These are my primary concerns. I also thank the team, especially Luke, Arthur, Julie and Catherine, for their assistance with residents’ inquiries throughout the consultation period.

Dr FLEGG (Moggill--LNP) (11.41 am): The shambles of kindergarten funding in Queensland is now looking more and more like ceiling insulation. The minister announced a new funding scheme, where we would be given vouchers for $1,200 for children attending kindergartens. On 30 June, he started to back away from that and said that he would guarantee the present DECKAS funding level for all services in 2011. Yesterday, he repeated that claim and under his letterhead had circulated, signed off by the office of early childhood, a letter to parents saying that the kindergarten services will have DECKAS level funding guaranteed until 2014 and that it would be indexed. In other words, he has completely backed away from the new system and gone back to DECKAS.

But imagine the horror of finding that this minister’s commitment to this parliament and these kindies was a pack of dishonest deception. When the kindy at Condy Park on the Fraser Coast contacted the office of early childhood, despite receiving that letter, they said, ‘No, no, no, the funding cut is still in place’--over $90,000 a year. When the Campus Kindy at the University of Queensland contacted C&K, they were told, ‘No, no, no, the funding cut stands’ and for that particular kindy, it is $60,000 to $90,000 a year.

We cannot believe a word this education minister says. He has given ironclad commitments that this funding will not be cut, yet kindergartens across Queensland are getting slaughtered. And who is going to pay? The parents are going to pay when the fees get put up, or when their local kindergarten closes down. This minister needs to get off his backside and explain why he misled this parliament.

Ms DARLING (Sandgate--ALP) (11.43 am): What do Olympians, Paralympians and Special Olympians have in common? They all love their sport, they love their country and they love the team spirit, friendship, fun and fitness that comes from the long hours of training and competing. However, the difference is that Queenslanders who are selected to compete at the Olympics, the Paralympics or the Commonwealth Games currently receive a bonus grant from the Bligh government, but those selected for the Special Olympics do not.

Over 40 years, the Special Olympics has grown from an American summer camp for people with intellectual disabilities to an international Olympic competition held every four years with local events held all year round. Next year, Athens will host the Special Olympics World Summer Games and over 30 Queenslanders have been selected for the Australian team. Shaun McKee, who hails from Bracken Ridge in my electorate of Sandgate, has been chosen as a member of the Australian soccer team and must raise $7,000 to get to Athens. Today, I am launching an appeal to Sandgate businesses to get behind Shaun with some sponsorship to help make his dream come true. Life Without Barriers is organising to collect funds on Shaun’s behalf and has already received donations. Last week, the sports minister, Phil Reeves, visited my electorate and took the time to meet Shaun and his mum and talk about his plans for Athens and to congratulate him on his team’s win at the national games in Adelaide earlier this year.

Today, I am calling on the minister to look at ways that our government can support Queensland athletes trying to raise funds to travel to the Special Olympics next year. I know that Queenslanders can achieve the target of becoming Australia’s healthiest people. If you need a bit of inspiration, you should go and watch some of our Special Olympians prepare for the most amazing games the world has ever seen. Go get ’em, Shaun; I am right behind you.

Mr STEVENS (Mermaid Beach--LNP) (11.45 am): I am pleased to report to the House that the Gold Coast City Council task force on short-term rental accommodation has resolved to ban so-called party houses in suburban residential areas. The council will achieve this protection of residents’ rights and amenity through a temporary local planning instrument, which is an action that was supported ably by the Labor member for Burleigh, Mrs Christine Smith, as well as by me, as part of the concerned task force members.

Mayor Ron Clarke boldly led the task force in the face of much pressure from the vested interest group of party house owners who have been using a loophole in the Gold Coast City Council planning act to run a business in a residential area without any planning application being made. The CEO of Gold Coast Tourism, Mr Martin Winter, debunked the unfounded calls that banning these party houses would be the end of tourism for the Gold Coast by advising the task force that these unapproved, inappropriately located short-term accommodation houses were actually costing genuine tourism accommodation providers money through their backdoor moonlighting activity.

In fact, there are 15,000 short-term accommodation providers licensed through the Gold Coast City Council. The vast majority of those accommodation houses are appropriately located, conform with all tourism accommodation building and safety requirements and have been approved through correct town planning applications. The fast-buck investors in these party houses can still rent out their properties for normal residential tenancy as approved under the planning scheme. So their howls of financial ruin ring hollow in the realm of reality.

I call on the honourable Minister for Infrastructure and Planning, Mr Stirling Hinchliffe, to expedite the issuing of the temporary local planning instrument for the Gold Coast City Council to bring to a close the unsociable behaviour, the unbearable ruination of suburban amenity, the incessant demand on police resources and the unfair trading advantage these party houses take over approved short-term accommodation venues. The problem is not only exclusive to the Gold Coast, with the Sunshine Coast Regional Council successful on--

Ms STONE (Springwood--ALP) (11.47 am): People driving on the M1 through Logan would have noticed the extensive roadworks that are being constructed at Daisy Hill. Improvements to the Springwood south to Daisy Hill section will progressively be delivered. Weather permitting, we will see major improvements to the Winnetts and Loganlea roads interchange in late 2010. This $490 million upgrade is being jointly funded by the state Labor government and the federal Labor government. The upgrade will provide a huge boost to employment, sustaining an average of 1,409 direct and indirect jobs over the life of the project.

There is no doubt that for many years Queenslanders were ignored and short-changed on road funding by the Howard Liberal government. In fact, I was often asked why the federal coalition government gave money to the Pacific Highway over the border and nothing to upgrade the road in Logan City. Unlike the Liberal and National Party members in this House, I did not stand and whinge and whine; I lobbied both sides of politics for my electorate’s fair share of road funding and federal road funding and I was delighted when the commitment came through from the federal Labor Party and was announced and delivered when it won government.

Today, I again stand in this House asking both sides of politics to give a commitment for more federal funding to keep the much needed upgrade of the Pacific Motorway through Logan City continuing--although I fear I know the answer from Tony Abbott, who has already said that transport infrastructure is a state responsibility. However, I will continue to lobby for the dollars that are needed for this upgrade no matter what level of government and no matter which party is in office. Today, I call on the Logan City Council to give its commitment to the upgrading of the local roads and the streets that will be affected by the upgrade. Improving the roads around the Loganlea interchange would be a good start as to where the council needs to show its commitment to the M1 upgrade. It is now time for the Logan City Council to give its commitment to road funding for improvements of local roads servicing M1 motorists. There is no point in us fixing up the M1 when all motorists do is hit a bottleneck on a council controlled road.

For 12 years the Howard Liberal government ignored Logan motorists, it ignored the residents in my electorate and it ignored the motorists using our major transport link to the southern states. I call on all levels of government to commit to making sure that this upgrade proceeds.

Mr KNUTH (Dalrymple--LNP) (11.50 am): Yesterday I tabled a petition containing the signatures of 769 Tablelands residents calling on the government to provide funding for signage on all arterial roads and thoroughfares throughout the Tablelands to highlight awareness by all road users and the community of the many bike riders who share the roads. This petition was initiated by Mrs Sharyn Cook, whose husband, Lindsay Cook, was tragically killed in March this year while riding his bike along the Kennedy Highway between Atherton and Mareeba. He was one of three fatalities in the past 18 months as a result of accidents involving bikes and vehicles on the Tablelands.

These tragic losses of life emphasise the need for improved infrastructure and adequate signage to enhance the awareness of the increasing number of people who are choosing to ride bikes to improve their lifestyle. I acknowledge that this government is interested in promoting bike riding in Queensland and I welcome such projects as the Principal Cycle Network Plan for Far North Queensland. However, the majority of development has occurred in the south-east and urban centres. I would also like to acknowledge the state member for Cook’s efforts in pushing for improved road infrastructure for bike riders on the Atherton Tablelands and in the Far North.

This petition is asking that the government urgently fund the erection of signs to raise awareness of bike riders to prevent further deaths and near misses on Tablelands roads. There are an increasing number of bike riders on Queensland roads. Research indicates that there are three times more riders per head of population in Far North Queensland than in Brisbane. It is becoming more evident on the Tablelands, where there is a rapidly expanding community of recreational bike riders who ride six days a week at six in the morning. Many Tablelanders are choosing to commute on their bikes.

The fact is that government initiatives aimed at promoting healthier living and greener lifestyles are still premature in regional and rural Queensland. Bike riders on the Tablelands are at high risk of being injured if nothing is done and are pleading for appropriate funding to erect signage to increase bike rider awareness throughout the Tablelands road network in an effort to save our families from tragic and preventable loss of loved ones.

Mrs KIERNAN (Mount Isa--ALP)
(11.51 am): I am pleased to advise the House that the government has finalised contract negotiations with the Cloncurry Shire Council in respect of the 38-kilometre pipeline which was completed in March 2010 on time and under budget. The pipeline ensures a secure back-up water supply from Lake Julius in times of drought after Cloncurry’s water supply fell to a critical low of three per cent capacity in 2008.

Construction of the pipeline commenced in July 2009 and was completed in December last year. The pipeline was declared operational in March 2010. This valuable piece of infrastructure contributed greatly to sustaining jobs during the GFC. It created employment for about 20 people locally, sustained employment for approximately 40 project contractors and injected around $3 million into the local economy.

Since the completion of the pipeline the government has consulted extensively with the council to assess various proposals for the allocation of costs to achieve the best outcome for all parties. The government assisted the council as it was vital to ensure the costs to the community were kept at a reasonable level. I acknowledge Mayor Andrew Daniels and his council, CEO Graham King, SunWater, DERM and DIP officers, particularly Greg Oliver, for their hard work to finalise the project.

As part of the agreement, the state government will pay the bulk of the costs through SunWater, the government’s water entity. Up to 2014 the council will only pay fixed water allocation costs to secure the entitlement to draw water from Lake Julius and the variable costs for the actual volume of water taken from the pipeline. In this project the state government will absorb all other project costs involved in the pipeline’s construction. The state government has also made concessions to the council in regard to trigger levels in Chinaman Creek Dam for taking water from the pipeline, it being raised from 25 per cent to 40 per cent.

Mr DICKSON (Buderim--LNP)
(11.53 am): I rise to speak on behalf of the hundreds of thousands of Queenslanders and their families who are only now starting to see the ramifications of the Bligh Labor government’s latest form of punishment: water torture. Those ramifications are in the form of water bills. Yes, something is rotten in the water across South-East Queensland.

Three weeks ago in my electorate of Buderim mailboxes began receiving Unitywater bills. My electorate office has been flooded with complaints, some very emotional, from people with families who have received bills for hundreds of dollars. The Premier is obviously very concerned about the pain and suffering her water-billing reform would cause to Queenslanders. I have no doubt this is why the Premier did away with the portfolio of water minister. That was a cynical move in an effort to try to distance herself and her government from the form of water torture they are going to inflict on Queenslanders. The cynical moves do not stop there. Unitywater’s website states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Unitywater is jointly and wholly owned by the Moreton Bay and Sunshine Coast regional councils.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: But Unitywater’s brochures and bills state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Council’s getting out of water, we’re getting into it.
XML.Hansard-Body: We are talking about water, but does the government seriously think we all came down in the last shower? Do not be mistaken: the Bligh government is getting its cut from water customers as well. Unitywater does not own water. The bulk water charges in everybody’s bills are the cost of water that Unitywater buys from the grid manager. Who owns the grid manager? The Bligh Labor government owns the grid manager.

Queensland will not forgive the Premier and her government for the water torture they have foisted upon them through these water bills. If they think they have copped flak over the recent electricity bills, they have not seen anything yet. When people go to vote this weekend, I urge them to take their water bill with them and remember who gave them this bill. Vote Labor out. We can no longer afford them. With increases in registration fees and water bills, this government will break the people of Queensland. Remember this weekend when you vote. Vote them out.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Prince Charles Hospital, Children’s Emergency Department
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr WATT (Everton--ALP)
(11.55 am): The new children’s emergency department at the Prince Charles Hospital continues to move ahead. This $45.6 million project will open in 2012 and will deliver great emergency care for northside children closer to home. It will build on the world-class services already provided by the Prince Charles Hospital to this area. This project will deliver designated children’s emergency treatment spaces, 20 beds for short stays and additional children’s outpatient services. Funding for the project was locked in in this year’s state budget. Early works have now commenced and a managing contractor will be appointed shortly. Construction will now begin before Christmas.

As parliamentary secretary for healthy living, I established a designated Family Advisory Council to engage with the community on the development of new services and facilities to be provided. The advisory council consists of 20 members of the general public: a mix of parents, carers and grandparents from within the hospital’s catchment area. This group now meets on a monthly basis, with three meetings having been held to date. I understand that these meetings have all been very constructive, with a range of suggestions made on the development of this important project.

This council will play an integral role in the planning and design of this project, in particular in ensuring that the needs of local families presenting to children’s emergency services are met and ascertaining how services can be managed to best meet these needs. It also allows local parents and carers the opportunity to have direct input into the way in which services will be delivered in this new facility. The feedback obtained from families through the Family Advisory Council is essential to create health services that are truly family centred. I look forward to providing further updates in the future to the House on the work of this council and this project more broadly.

Mr BLEIJIE (Kawana--LNP)
(11.57 am): In 2001 I ran in a council by-election in the old Caloundra City Council area. Out of the nine candidates in the field I ran third. The then member for Kawana, Chris Cummins, made a speech in the House regarding candidates in that by-election and I was lucky enough to rate a mention, although it was hardly a glowing endorsement. Almost 10 years later I have pleasure in giving the residents of Fisher a summary of Mr Cummins’s colourful past before his candidacy for Fisher at this Saturday’s federal election.

Mr Cummins’s most recent bungle was as a senior IT adviser to the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. He was one of the most senior bureaucrats involved in the debacle of changing over the Queensland Health payroll system. I submit to the House that the bungle is ongoing, with no end in sight. When questioned about his role in the debacle, Mr Cummins stated that he had no role in the pay issue and also that as a federal candidate he could not comment on any state issues. The ‘minister for nothing’ has become the ‘IT adviser who has nothing to do with anything’. It is what one expects when two ministers deny responsibility. He was trained by the incompetent best in the Bligh government.

One state issue that he is happy to discuss is the Sunshine Coast University Hospital. With tremendous audacity he says that the LNP has delayed the hospital. I remind Mr Cummins that it is the Labor Party that has delayed the hospital. I table a copy of the misleading brochure he has sent out.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Copy of an election flyer for candidate Chris Cummins [ 2769 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Let us talk about Mr Cummins’s policy on health. He is going around now saying that health is a major issue. I table for members opposite a copy of a letter that Mr Cummins wrote in 2003 in which he states, believe it or not, Parliamentary Secretary for Health--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I do not agree with your opinion that our area is suffering from a gross lack of hospital facilities.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Bundle of correspondence from the then MP Chris Cummins to Maureen Mileham regarding hospital facilities for Kawana [ 2770 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: That is what Chris Cummins said in 2003. He is misleading the public by now stating that there is any issue in relation to health at all--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! The member’s time has expired.
Mr BLEIJIE: --because he did not believe there was any issue with health services on the Sunshine Coast in 2003.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Before calling the member for Mulgrave, I would say this: member for Kawana, when your time is called and you try to talk over the chair, it is gross disrespect to the chair. When you are called, that is the end of your time.

Mr BLEIJIE:
Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. My apologies.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: National Science Week; Townsend, Ms D
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr PITT (Mulgrave--ALP) (11.59 am): This week is National Science Week and more than 45 state schools across Queensland have organised science activities, including science fairs and Science on Saturday events. The community’s renewed interest in science aligns with state government moves to increase the profile of science in state schools, with programs such as the $37.7 million Science Spark initiative that focuses on improving teacher knowledge and skills to teach science in years 4 to 7, being ably led in Far North Queensland by regional manager Adam Hooper.

Last week I presented a Community Service Award to Debbie Townsend, the primary science facilitator based at Gordonvale State School. Deb has recently organised National Science Week activities at Gordonvale and Aloomba State Schools. She was instrumental in Isabella State School obtaining a grant to run its science fair and the science expo to be held next week at Gordonvale State School. She has contributed to the excellent performance of the science program at Gordonvale and is accompanying students from Aloomba State School to the International Kids Teaching Kids Coastal Conference to be held at Caloundra in October.

Debbie has a long history of bringing science to the fore in the primary setting, previously at Hambledon State School and now at Gordonvale, where she has conducted extensive support activities to make science come alive. For example, she had the Gordonvale SES attend a lesson and had the students learn about the efficiency of different pulley systems by using emergency services equipment to rescue Jack, the training dummy. When not involved with science, Debbie is actively involved with Girl Guides and Brownies, a labour of love for nearly 50 years, and is the first aid officer at Ellis Beach Surf Lifesaving Club.

The Science Spark initiative is offering great benefits to teachers and students alike and is helping to build Queensland’s already renowned science community. Deb Townsend is a great example of why the initiative is so successful. She is a passionate educator, both in and out of the classroom setting. She has the spark to ignite passion in her students because she is always willing to go the extra mile to accomplish her goals.

Mr FOLEY (Maryborough--Ind) (12.00 pm): I rise to bring to the attention of the House the fact that I, along with many other local members, are hearing an increasing number of people complain about the costs that are levied on them by local government. That puts us in a difficult position. In Queensland there are 73 councils and this growing frustration over the increasing charges is something that we cannot do anything about at a normal level. I table a copy of a document from the Department of Infrastructure and Planning, which offers people the advice that if they have a complaint about their council they should contact that council directly. Of course, people then perceive the situation to be one where Caesar is judging Caesar.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Copy of a document, downloaded on 18 August 2010, regarding council rates and charges [ 2771 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: In a letter to me, a constituent of mine writes--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Given that our region has some of the lowest per capita income in Australia and that our rates are amongst the highest in Australia, the bottom line is that the bulk of ratepayers can no longer afford this council.

I believe Queensland is long overdue for a law which directs all councils to annually submit proposed rates and charges to a totally independent, non-partisan, apolitical authority which has the power to approve, reject or alter all submissions--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: For rises in prices--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Above all, its decisions are final.
XML.Hansard-Body: I believe that that cost could be shared amongst the 73 councils and, with top-up funding from state and federal governments, it would mean that people could be confident that they were not being rorted, as it were, through charges. A local publican received a $15,000 bill because someone made a mistake in calculating the bill and the council had undercharged him. He told them to go jump in the lake and, basically, the charge was waived. That sort of uncertainty needs to be addressed by an independent arbiter.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2)
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Infrastructure and Planning) (12.03 pm): I present a bill for an act to amend the Ambulance Service Act 1991, the Animal Management (Cats and Dogs) Act 2008, the Building Act 1975, the City of Brisbane Act 2010, the Local Government Act 2009, the Royal National Agricultural and Industrial Association of Queensland Act 1971 and the Sustainable Planning Act 2009 for particular purposes. I present the explanatory notes, and I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a first time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) [ 2772 ].
Tabled paper: Building and Other Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), explanatory notes [ 2773 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Infrastructure and Planning) (12.03 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This bill implements stage 2 of the government’s swimming pool safety improvement strategy. This bill culminates a two-year comprehensive review of and consultation on Queensland’s pool safety. Queensland will have the toughest pool laws in Australia. I thank all stakeholders who have provided their expertise in the development of the pool safety laws, such as Hannah’s Foundation, the Royal Life Saving Society, the Queensland Law Society, the Real Estate Institute of Queensland and numerous organisations from the pool, building, community title and health sector, as well as all the members of the community who provided their input.
XML.Hansard-Body: Between 1 January 2004 and 18 May 2010, 35 children under five years of age drowned in residential swimming pools. Further, in 2008-09 eight children drowned in swimming pools. There are approximately 50 non-fatal immersion incidents each year, with cases that are often characterised by permanent brain damage. In 1991, pool fencing legislation resulted in a dramatic reduction in drowning deaths and, as a result, we know that better laws will save lives. This government will not accept tragedies as inevitable. Of course, nothing replaces adult supervision of children when they are near water, but the new laws aim to drastically reduce the risk of young children entering pools on their own.

Stage 1 of our improvement strategy commenced on 1 December 2009 for new pools. Stage 2 will mostly cover Queensland’s 325,000 existing pools. Primarily, this bill will replace the current assortment of pool safety standards with a single uniform standard. The bill extends state pool laws to indoor pools and pools associated with hotels, motels and other residential buildings, caretaker dwellings and caravan parks. One single standard will make pool safety laws easier to understand, easier to enforce and easier to comply with. Also, to ensure pool owners have time to adjust and are not unduly disadvantaged, this bill allows a five-year phase-in period for owners to upgrade their pool fencing and safety arrangements, unless they sell or lease the property first.

Pool safety organisations agree that the risk of drowning is highest during the first six months of occupation, particularly on rented premises. Seventy-one per cent of the drowning deaths involving young Queenslanders between 2007 and 2009 occurred on rented properties. This bill establishes mandatory inspections of regulated pools with a pool safety certificate issued by licensed pool safety inspectors, if triggered by the sale or lease of a regulated property. No property with a non-shared residential pool can be leased without a current pool safety certificate. For all other pools, where a pool is sold without a pool safety certificate a prescribed notice must be given by the seller to the purchaser advising that the pool may be non-compliant. The Pool Safety Council must also be advised that the property was settled without a pool safety certificate.

The bill provides for a six-month phase-in period for pools associated with short-term accommodation to obtain a certificate. This phased implementation is in direct response to our tourism stakeholders, such as the Hotel Motel and Accommodation Association and the Queensland Tourism Industry Council, telling us that December and January is one of their busiest periods. All other shared pool owners will have two years to get ready and plan for upgrading their pool fences to the one standard, and be required to obtain a pool safety certificate. The Commissioner for Body Corporate and Community Management, along with key stakeholders, has advised that this phase-in period is critical to allow bodies corporate sufficient time to comply with the scheme.

The bill also addresses strong community concern of the risks portable pools pose to young children. It does so by reducing the maximum depth of portable pools not requiring a compliant pool fence from 450 mm to 300 mm, and in doing so brings Queensland in line with the rest of Australia.

The bill implements Queensland’s mandatory immersion incident reporting system. This will facilitate accurate pool immersion data collection and a comprehensive assessment of the practical operation of our pool safety reforms. The amendments mandate reporting by a private or public hospital and the Queensland Ambulance Service of an immersion incident of a child under the age of five. They must report it to Queensland Health within five business days and include information about the date and location of the incident. Queensland Health will then distribute the information to relevant bodies, including local governments, the Pool Safety Council and the Queensland Injuries Surveillance Unit.

Most importantly, this information will trigger local government action, as the bill requires local governments to inspect the relevant pool so that appropriate improvements are identified and undertaken. To make sure pool owners and the various affected sectors of new pool safety obligations--such as the pool community title, real estate and legal sectors--know of the new obligations for pool safety, my department is developing a targeted education and awareness campaign.

The bill also amends the Animal Management (Cats and Dogs) Act 2008 to clarify that American Staffordshire terriers, also known as Amstaffs, are not ‘restricted dogs’. The Queensland Supreme Court recently concluded that Amstaffs are the same breed as American pit bull terriers. As pit bulls are classified as ‘restricted dogs’, this caused significant uncertainty for Queensland Amstaff owners.

This bill will also prevent creditors or liquidators from dealing with particular public land and will, instead, revert ownership back to the state. The Royal National Agricultural and Industrial Association, the RNA as we better know it, is entering into a development agreement with Lend Lease (Bowen Hills) Pty Ltd in order to redevelop the Ekka site. The purpose of the proposed amendments are to facilitate this commercial arrangement while at the same time guaranteeing that the historic Ekka site is not lost to future generations. Under this arrangement, only that part of the site that is necessary for the Lend Lease development will be available as security for the financial transaction. The balance of the site will be quarantined from the financial arrangements and will remain in public hands.

Finally, the bill amends the Sustainable Planning Act 2009 to enable local governments to continue publishing material relating to development applications on their websites. Currently, publication of this material may be in breach of the Information Privacy Act (2009). However, these websites are important, widely used tools that facilitate transparency in the IDAS process, which is a matter of critical importance to all stakeholders. The amendment authorises online publication of certain documents or information relating to development applications. A determination of which documents are appropriate for online publication is being formulated with a balance struck between personal privacy and public accountability. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate, on motion of Ms Simpson, adjourned.
Resumed from 17 August (see p. 2650), on motion of Mr Robertson--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr RYAN (Morayfield--ALP) (12.12 pm): I rise to contribute to the debate on the Geothermal Energy Bill.
