This bill is about balance--balancing our energy needs today with our needs for a sustainable future tomorrow; balancing the interests of agricultural landholders today with the economic demands of the diverse employment possibilities of tomorrow; balancing the current methods for the energy generation of today with the transitional pathways for the energy generation of tomorrow.

On this side of the House, we believe the mainstream science on climate change. We believe that climate change is happening now and we are committed to playing our part by expanding and investing in a Queensland based renewable energy sector. As someone committed to a sustainable future and as a member of the Queensland parliament’s Environment and Resources Committee, I am pleased that this government is investing in new renewable energy technologies and strategies. By diversifying our state’s energy generation sector and by lightening our reliance on fossil fuels, this state government is securing Queensland’s energy future.

This bill supports the development of a geothermal industry in Queensland within a strict framework of promoting competition, protecting the interests of landholders and creating jobs for the future. As some members may know, geothermal energy or hot rocks energy is a virtually carbon dioxide emission free energy source which has the potential to produce more baseload energy than any other source of renewable energy generated in Queensland. This capacity is important not only for network stability purposes but because it fundamentally lightens our reliance on fossil fuels for baseload energy generation. This technology is a game changer.

This bill is also about supporting landholders and providing a regulatory framework for land access by geothermal explorers and producers. Our renewable energy future must be developed in partnership with our friends in the agricultural sector. As such, it is important that collaborative and constructive frameworks exist and all stakeholders are afforded the due respect and support that they deserve. I am pleased that a Land Access Code of Conduct will be introduced to promote transparency, equity and cooperation amongst stakeholders.

I would like to now spend some time discussing the amendments to the Electricity Act in relation to the retailer of last resort scheme. As members may know, the retailer of last resort scheme was enlivened last year when an electricity retailer, Jackgreen (International), was suspended from trading on the national market. A number of my constituents contacted me to discuss their experience with Jackgreen and their transition to a new retailer under the scheme. As members may know, the retailer of last resort scheme protects customers of an electricity retailer who may be suspended from the national electricity market or otherwise become unable to provide retail services.

The scheme ensures that customers of a failed retailer continue to receive electricity supply by automatically transferring them to another retailer, known as a retailer of last resort. However, there are not insignificant costs associated with providing a retailer of last resort service. Currently, the scheme provides for a retailer of last resort to recover costs by charging transferred customers a fee. This fee can only be charged if it is approved by the independent Queensland Competition Authority.

Following the successful operation of the scheme in respect of Jackgreen, I understand that some concerns were identified in respect of the scheme’s cost recovery process. Accordingly, I am pleased to see that amendments contained in this bill will establish a more equitable cost recovery process. The proposed new process would spread costs of a retailer of last resort event across all Queensland customers through distributors’ network charges. These events are rare, with only two occurring since the commencement of the national electricity market in 1998.

The amendments to the act will enable development of an improved cost recovery process to minimise costs to individual customers, whilst encouraging retailers to continue to offer the retailer of last resort service. It will also align Queensland’s retailer of last resort scheme more closely with the proposed national scheme expected to be introduced in the middle of 2012 under Ministerial Council on Energy reforms. Details of the proposed new cost recovery process are being developed in consultation with stakeholders and will be implemented through an amendment to the Electricity Regulation.

I would like to conclude by noting the hard work of the minister, his staff and the departmental staff in respect of this bill. This is a good bill which looks to the future in a responsible, measured and balanced way. This is a bill which supports stakeholders and customers through a variety of sensible amendments. This is a bill which highlights this government’s hard work of developing a diverse and secure renewable energy sector. That has to be good for the Queensland of today and for the Queensland of tomorrow. I commend the bill to the House and ask other members to support it.

Mrs KIERNAN (Mount Isa--ALP) (12.18 pm): I rise to speak to the Geothermal Energy Bill 2010. It has been with keen interest during my time in this House to see the progress of so many aspects of the expansion of renewable energy which has been a strong and steadfast commitment of the Bligh government. Representing one of the most promising geothermal regions in the state, this bill sets out to establish frameworks to encourage and facilitate the safe production of geothermal energy to accelerate the expansion of the renewable energy sector in Queensland. The bill also sets out to provide a balanced approach to private land access and recognise and clarify the rights and authority of tenure holders and landholders in relation to access to private land for resource related activities and compensation. This bill amends a number of other acts. However, I will keep my comments particularly to the production and land access.

Geothermal energy, or hot rocks energy, is a virtually CO 2 emission free energy source and has the potential to produce more baseload energy for Queensland than any other single source of renewable energy. It is heat energy contained within the earth’s crust derived from the natural geological processes which may occur in various forms, including geothermal water and steam--that is, wet geothermal energy--or hot dry rocks. Geothermal energy can be used in a variety of small scale applications--for example, heat pumps--and industrial applications, as well as large scale electricity generation.

I am very proud to say that the only wet geothermal electricity generation is in Birdsville, which is in my electorate. It has the capacity to provide for about one-third of Birdsville’s average power consumption. I also would like to acknowledge that the member for Gregory is a very, very strong supporter of this project and of these renewable initiatives in our part of the world.

Exploration for geothermal energy is currently regulated under the Geothermal Exploration Act 2004 and the Geothermal Exploration Regulation 2005. This legislation was intended to be an interim measure in Queensland so that exploration could commence while legislation to enable production was developed. Nine exploration permits have been granted and 31 are proposed to be granted in 2010.

While Queensland has significant resources of hot dry rocks, many of those resources are not close to large townships or major industrial load centres, which poses particular transmission and distribution challenges to the development of the industry in the state, in addition to the existing legislative barriers to the production of geothermal energy. While recognising that the Queensland government has committed $5 million to the Coastal Geothermal Energy Initiative and understanding that this initiative was launched to identify high geothermal heat-flow areas close to existing electricity transmission lines along the Queensland coast, I believe that the north-west remains at the forefront in respect of geothermal and other renewable energies.

In July 2008, the Premier announced the newly discovered Millungera Basin, which has the energy potential to rival that of the Cooper Basin. It is possible that the Millungera Basin could hold clean energy sources that could provide low-emissions power for the entire north-west region. This discovery, which is east of Cloncurry, is actually in the north-west and right in the heart of the McKinlay shire. I make mention of this find because, apart from the great excitement at the time, since that time we have marched on substantially in the north-west, particularly in respect of transmission potential.

On 18 June 2010, the Coordinator-General declared the CopperString project to be a significant project requiring an environmental impact statement. The project will provide an electricity transmission network as identified in a clean energy corridor. The significant renewable energy resources would benefit from the ability to connect to the NEM to export electricity.

Just last week, the Deputy Prime Minister and Treasurer, Wayne Swan, announced that a re-elected Gillard government would make the CopperString project the first cab off the rank for the Connecting Renewables initiative. This follows the strong support this project has received from the Queensland government, with both the Treasurer, Andrew Fraser, and Minister Stephen Robertson working over the last few years to find long-term solutions to energy for the north-west minerals province and the prospect of many renewable energy opportunities along the Mount Isa to Townsville corridor. I would also like to acknowledge the visionary leadership of Paul Woodhouse--
Mr Reeves: Hear, hear! He is great bloke.

Mrs KIERNAN: I take that interjection. He is a great bloke, absolutely. He is the mayor of the McKinlay shire, and I acknowledge his strong advocacy for all things renewable. I particularly acknowledge his excitement for geothermal advancement within his shire and his strong support of the CopperString project.

Land access matters are highly relevant to the Mount Isa electorate, both for our explorers and miners and for our vast pastoral industry in the north-west. We have seen a substantial and ongoing increase in exploration activity, which has placed a greater emphasis on the importance of developing a policy and legislative framework that clearly articulates the rights and responsibilities of resource tenure holders and rural landholders relating to access to private land for the potential development of this state’s mineral, petroleum and geothermal resources. Significant growth and expansion for resource activity across the state has resulted in increased interaction and conflict between rural landholders and resource tenure authority holders regarding the manner in which these companies access private land and the potential business impacts that resource activities may have on agricultural enterprises. It effectively grants a right of access to private land, so it is therefore incumbent on the government to ensure that it facilitates equitable outcomes for all affected parties.

I would like to congratulate and thank Minister Robertson, his staff and his department for this bill, particularly the many aspects of the bill that I know will be truly beneficial and will harmonise the relationship between our explorers, our miners and our pastoralists. On that note, I commend the bill to the House.

Mr SHINE (Toowoomba North--ALP) (12.27 pm): I rise to make a contribution to the Geothermal Energy Bill. It certainly is timely that this bill is being introduced and debated today bearing in mind its applicability to an important area of Queensland, namely the west and particularly the south-west and Darling Downs area. This legislation is of great interest to people who live in my electorate in Toowoomba, although no part of my electorate itself is the subject of exploration or mining that I am aware of.

Nevertheless, Toowoomba is the regional capital of the Darling Downs and South-West Queensland and, as such, the issues that have arisen as a result of the activities in the Surat Basin are very much to the fore for them. The people of Toowoomba are very aware of the issues arising as a result of the growth of the coal seam gas industry and they are particularly concerned about any danger to the Great Artesian Basin. They are concerned about the proposed open-cut mine at Felton and similar mining operations that are proposed west of Toowoomba at Warra. They are also more recently concerned about the gasification process at Kingaroy that was mentioned last night by the member for Nanango.

These are some of the more prominent concerns that have been raised in my community as well as in the wider Darling Downs and south-west Queensland. Indeed, Mr Deputy Speaker, I have been lobbied by advocates on both sides of that argument, as you would assume I would be. I am aware, therefore, of the concerns of farmers and, to a large extent, I empathise with them and share their concerns.

Members opposite yesterday were explaining to the House the feelings that landowners had who have been associated with a property for generations, their affection for and love of the land, and their worry about what might be happening. I understand that. Having come from a farm, I am only too pleased that that area is not, and never will be as far as I am aware, the subject of mining interest. But I do genuinely share their concerns.

Their concerns, as I alluded to before, have a wide and deep level of support in the Toowoomba community. Toowoomba is a community that is a retirement centre for people who have come from country areas, from farms and so on, and therefore one would expect Toowoomba people to have sympathy and a connection with what is happening on the land. However, I am also aware that it is not just farmers or people with that type of connection to the land but it is also scientists, particularly scientists in the plant area, who have raised concerns about the various activities of mining of one sort or another that is happening in that region.

I had occasion to send to the minister, and, indeed to the Premier, an article in the Toowoomba Chronicle of recent times written by the Catholic Social Justice Commission, which was concerned about moral issues arising out of the use of land for mining purposes and the obligation that we have to protect farming lands for the production of food and so on. I mention these things because many ordinary Toowoomba residents, other than those with a vested interest, have legitimate concerns about what is happening in the south-west region of Queensland.

It was for that reason that I elected to travel to Roma recently to sit in on the community cabinet to gauge for myself the views of the people more directly affected by what is happening in that industry in that part of Queensland, which was a worthwhile experience from my point of view. The people who have concerns call for such actions as a moratorium, pending the carrying out of research to obtain some certainty before the industry is further developed.

The value of the primary production in that part of Queensland is almost immeasurable in terms of their production of food and fibre. That certainly applies to the Felton area and to the Warra area. The honourable member for Warrego, who is in the chamber and who represents a lot of that part of Queensland, is well aware of its value as a food production area of Queensland, and likewise, as I said, with Felton. In terms of Felton, the effects on Toowoomba could be quite significant both from an aesthetic point of view and the amenity itself of Toowoomba with respect to the influence of dust from prevailing winds and so on.

Farmers have come to me from Cecil Plains, in particular, concerned about the effects of coal seam gas on the Great Artesian Basin. They are worried that saline water et cetera could escape into the Great Artesian Basin from the aquifers where gas is being extracted. They are concerned about the potential for great disaster being caused to that great natural wonder which supports the economy of country Queensland and, indeed, Australia so significantly. These are really genuine concerns that these people have. They are not people who should not be taken seriously.

Likewise, we had the incident recently at Kingaroy, and I was pleased to hear the member for Nanango acknowledge the efforts of the minister in going up there, listening to the people and taking immediate action to stop proceedings. You can understand, Mr Deputy Speaker, the need in the minds of people for a moratorium so that more research can be undertaken. I do not have it in front of me, but my recollection is that in the past the member for Condamine has called for a moratorium on these sorts of activities. Listening to the honourable member for Callide yesterday, I do not think that was his position. In fact, I think his position was balanced and was supportive of development of this industry providing precautions were taken. I think that is a fair summation of his speech.

There has to be a balanced view taken here not only being cognisant of the views of what we might call the farming sector. We have to also look at the effects on the resources industry and the welfare, the economic welfare particularly, of that part of Queensland--indeed, all of Queensland and Australia--if we were, for example, to adopt a moratorium instantly without other measures being taken.

Bearing in mind the nature of this bill, some members have advocated that we should concentrate almost entirely on geothermal production of energy or electricity from this source. As I understand it, that would really be a very expensive way to provide electricity to our consumers who at the moment are already, understandably, not happy with the cost of electricity as it is. If we were to do away with coal produced energy, in Queensland, as I understand it, the cost of production of electricity would go through the roof literally. So I do not think that is a realistic alternative either.

On that recent trip to Roma I noticed--it was obvious--the economic effects of the resources industry, the coal seam gas industry particularly at Roma, in terms of the economic activity in the town, the nature of the vehicles on the road and the number of vehicles on the road, many of which were involved with the mining industry. Ten years ago it might have been the cattle industry. Now it is cattle but to a large extent mining--people staying in motels, getting off airplanes and so on. The effect of the mining industry there is enormous, but so too is the effect in a place like Toowoomba. Many of the aspects of the mining industry are supported by locations in Toowoomba. Be they administration, manufacturing, construction or transport, these headquarters are often in Toowoomba. People live in Toowoomba and travel from there. Many of the small businesses in Toowoomba are associated with supplying the needs of the mining and resources industry. Many new people have come to Toowoomba. Their children go to Toowoomba schools and they attend health facilities in Toowoomba. All those aspects of living that flow from new people coming to an area are happening in Toowoomba, to a large extent because of the opening up of the Surat Basin.

Toowoomba is greatly affected and influenced by the oil, gas and coal industries in that region of Queensland to which I have referred. I had an opportunity yesterday to obtain a bit of a briefing in relation to the worth, if you like, of the resources sector in Queensland. The figures I received were these: in 2008-09, the resources sector directly and indirectly contributed 20 per cent of the Queensland economy, 12 per cent of the total full-time equivalent employment, $3.4 billion in royalties to the state government, $4.2 billion in company tax to the federal government and had the highest average weekly earnings of all industries of $2,034. It can be seen that this is already a significant industry not just throughout south-west Queensland but throughout the whole of Queensland.

Xstrata is proposing to proceed with major works at Wandoan. The Wandoan coal project has indicative capital expenditure of $6 billion. The start-up date is 2014. It would involve 3,000 construction workers and 1,500 permanent workers. Likewise, that company is involved in the Surat Basin rail project with QR and ATEC. That is a billion dollar project and has an indicative start-up date of 2013-14. Some 750 people will be involved in construction. These are potentially huge investments for the south-west of Queensland. Therefore, those interests have to be balanced and taken into account carefully.

I am pleased that, in my view, the government recognises the contribution of the rural sector, recognises the need to manage the interaction between the resources and agricultural industries and has the aim to ensure the viability of both sectors and ensure a balance between the needs of both sectors. The range of initiatives being progressed by the government and industry to achieve the right balance between resource development, agricultural production and environmental management have been arrived at. The focus on how to proceed really involves minimising the impacts of resource development on strategic cropping land for a start--and a discussion paper has been issued with respect to that--controlling access to private land and ensuring appropriate compensation, which is primarily the subject of this bill, addressing the impacts on the interests of relevant parties with respect to groundwater and addressing the effective and safe disposal of extracted salt.

These are matters that are not covered by this bill, as I understand it, but they are matters that the government has taken action on or is about to take action on. I refer to things like the evaporation ponds. The transitional arrangements for evaporation ponds will be developed in consultation with industry. With respect to groundwater the government is putting in place a new policy regime under the water legislation which will include the establishment of trigger thresholds for changes to water levels in springs and bores, the application of make good provisions to include the impacts on springs and bores built after the granting of environmental authorities and, finally, the development of a groundwater monitoring regime to be funded by way of an industry levy on CSG producers to be oversighted by an independent body. Some of those matters are not relevant to this legislation but they do touch on the overall general problem.

In my view, there is a degree of scepticism and mistrust between one sector and the other. It may well be that an independent body could be looked at to do the research properly. The University of Southern Queensland exists. As I understand, it is ready, willing and able to carry out the necessary research. It has a good standing in the community, particularly in the rural industries of south-west Queensland. I would encourage the minister to make some overtures to the University of Southern Queensland in the hope that it could perhaps provide a valuable service in investigating and ultimately giving the assurances that will be necessary. Obviously, government has a vested interest and the resource industry has a vested interest whereas a body like USQ could be regarded as an independent broker in determining the issues that are alive in that part of Queensland.

I commend the minister for the legislation before the House. It is another great step towards addressing these issues which are of real concern to my constituents and people living on the Darling Downs and in south-west Queensland.

Mr HOBBS (Warrego--LNP) (12.45 pm): I am pleased today to be able to speak in the debate on the Geothermal Bill 2010. This legislation is certainly very much overdue. The bill sets out how the state will regulate geothermal resources and the security of tenure and how resource development, and environmental, health and safety issues are managed in this state. The government has continually failed to recognise the importance of this industry and the needs of landholders. We have a wonderful industry out there. We also have a lot of wonderful landholders out there. There is going to be conflict unless we have appropriate rules and guidelines for people to operate under.

This legislation does make improvements in the arrangements around access to land by resource companies. I refer particularly to the coal seam gas development that is occurring in my electorate especially. We have enormous development going on out there. There are some very good companies who understand the needs of landholders and understand the needs of the community and are doing their bit. There are other companies that do not seem to really understand those needs at this stage and are looking at it purely as a resource and extracting it as soon as they can. There needs to be a lot of work done by those companies who have not stepped up to the mark in relation to how they approach this.

In 2007, there was a matrix report done that covered some of these things, but not all of them. They all tie in to a certain degree. Nothing was done at all at that time. This legislation is two years late in being brought forward. Had there been some foresight and some understanding of the industry and the complications that may occur this legislation would have been introduced sooner. It is here now so it is good in one sense.

We are certainly dealing with a reactionary government when it comes to these matters. That is not satisfactory for either the landholders or the resource companies. The companies, in good faith, are putting in enormous resources and effort to try to build an industry. I am sure they are frustrated by the way this is being handled.

The LNP has a very strong position on this and has announced policies to govern the industry. If people understand and believe in these philosophies it makes it a lot easier to legislate. People know where they are going if they have those parameters and beliefs. For instance, we have announced a charter of property rights that recognises pre-existing rights. If people have that philosophy they know how they can legislate.

We have proposed a commission for future food and fibre for strategic targeting of new, growing and emerging market opportunities. If people understand that they can legislate. Another one is protecting genuine prime agricultural land from mining and other incompatible uses. If people understand and believe in that and do not just talk about it they can legislate. We have proposed resourcing our regions to ensure our regions share in a meaningful investment in their communities. This is a significant change to what this government has done.

We have also proposed the establishment of a rural water advisory panel to monitor and report on the impacts of coal seam gas and UCG. The government does have such a committee but it is not properly resourced. It does not have all the resources it needs to be able to manage quickly these emerging issues. At our LNP conference recently we endorsed even stronger measures to ensure the sustainability of our underground water supplies.

Again, this is a reactionary government. Some 65 pages of amendments to this legislation have been released in a short number of weeks. In fact, there was even another amendment added since the shadow minister was told what was in the legislation and what has come before this House. I welcome those amendments, but it just goes to show that there seems to be a bit of catch-up going on all of the time. With regard to the consequential impacts of compensation, it is fundamental to ensure that such issues are covered in the legislation because people look for them. When they are not in the legislation, people ask, ‘Why were they taken out?’ Why were consequential impacts in relation to compensation taken out in the first place? It is fundamental that we do not do those sorts of things. However, that issue is in the legislation now.

There are also concerns about issues such as consequential impacts in terms of accounting, legal issues and valuations. These matters are some of the basic and fundamental problems that people are facing. They are trying to get professional people to assist them in terms of valuations and the legal complications. A lot of those people in many instances are very good farmers, but they are not legal people. They need to be able to seek this advice in order to understand what all of the documents mean. They need to have access to good advice. In the past we have seen people negotiate on behalf of companies and those people doing the negotiating on behalf of those companies were retired barristers. It is an unfair fight sometimes when people have to come up against those sorts of situations. It is important that we do it right, and I am pleased that this aspect is covered in this legislation. However, why was it taken out in the first place?

Land access is not understood by many Labor members in this House, and that is a shame. I genuinely hope that debate on this legislation today in the House may help to explain some of those issues. In the past Labor has never had respect for landownership or the blood, the sweat and the tears that go into obtaining and holding on to a block of land. There is enormous effort put in by families over the years to hold on to the land. They have done that through various impacts such as deaths in the family, probates in days gone by, and drought. Enormous sacrifice and effort are put into that, so that land is very important to them. They own and love that land and want to keep it going for generations. They want to make it a better place. There seems to be a belief on the other side of the House that those people want to try to virtually rape the land and pull every tree out and everything else. That is not the case. They want to make it a better place for their kids, a better place for the future and achieve a better environmental outcome. There are so many people out there trying so hard to do that. There has been a lot of effort put into land care over the years and sustainable farming and management. Australia has some of the best farmers and graziers in the world today. In fact, we lead the world in many of our farming practices. So it is important that we understand that.

When other tenure holders are given the right to explore and maybe develop a mining or gas development on that tenure there needs to be some understanding of the needs of both parties, and that certainly has failed. From the landholders’ point of view, in many instances they do not want to see these people come onto their land. However, the reality is that that is the way the tenures are and we have to try to create a situation where they are compatible as best we can. Landholders do not want them in many instances, but if they are there they need to have the least impact possible. However, if they are incompatible the government should not approve the lease. You cannot mine in a national park. You cannot mine in a state forest area. You cannot take a piece of coral from a Barrier Reef island. You cannot take a piece of wood out of a national park. Mining and gas companies take on these projects in good faith, and they also need to have good guidelines. As I mentioned before, some companies do not understand that. It is the case in Australia now that good Aussie companies discovered all of the coal seam gas and got the industry going but now all of the multinationals have come in and taken over the industry and those Aussie companies are basically world conglomerates.

Security of property rights is a fundamental policy right of the LNP, and for too long Labor governments have taken other people’s property rights for granted and abused and eroded those rights. A simple philosophy is that if the community requires a private asset for community purposes the community should pay. That is a fairly simple way of looking at it, and the community simply has to pay it. Access to land has always been an issue. However, mining companies moving into closely settled areas has highlighted shortcomings in existing legislation. Access to land coupled with the unknown and uncertainty of the impacts of the proposed development have caused tension.

For example, let us take the instance of a coal seam gas company forcing its way onto the farm. That, coupled with uncertainty in terms of the impacts on underground water, is a recipe for conflict. There is not going to be a lot of logic at the end of the day after they have been through all of that because landholders do not want them there because they think they will damage their water supply. Landholders have to know for sure that there is going to be no impact, know that the government is looking out for them in good faith, know that there is not going to be a detrimental effect on their underground water supplies. Presently, quite frankly, landholders do not really know that. There has to be more work done in that respect. I know that the government is doing work on this now with staff in those areas and briefings are underway. There is a recognition by the government that it is a major issue and there is a bit of catch-up going on.

The differences between the mineral act and the petroleum act have caused concern in the past, and this legislation should rectify that to bring consistency with the landholders access code. That has always been an issue with not only the landholders but also the companies themselves in terms of the different cost tenures and so forth that were causing a lot of tension. Compensation has certainly always been an issue, particularly when one considers the diminution of the value of the land. There is always an argument in terms of what a property is worth before and after exploration--that is, if a landholder has no wells or 20 or 30 wells, ponds and a 300-man camp. There are places where even the councils do not know that a 300-man camp is being set up at the end of a road. That is just not satisfactory. The council has to fix the road, because eventually the road gets worn out and torn to pieces if it rains. There has to be something put in place, particularly now that we have the accounting, legal or valuation costs. Where a claimant necessarily and reasonably incurs a cost, they can negotiate and prepare a conduct and compensation agreement. That is important.

With regard to the point I was making before, consequential damage is now in the legislation, and that is good. It needs to be there just to clarify the whole thing if nothing else. Clarification of these things is very important because people are looking for certainty, but the problem is that they do not trust government. We need to understand that. We have to go over the top to ensure that we cover everything well and ensure that we are doing the best we can so they understand that we have a genuine interest in supporting them in terms of making it easier for both sides--not necessarily just the farming and grazing industry in terms of landholders but the mining companies themselves. They are making a substantial investment in these projects. These companies have to have some sort of certainty and understanding where they are going otherwise they will not develop, and that impacts on landholders as well. Whilst late, this legislation is welcome. I hope we can move quickly in terms of bringing in further legislation if other problems come to the fore in order to quickly resolve them.
Sitting suspended from 12.58 pm to 2.30 pm.

Mr FOLEY (Maryborough--Ind) (2.30 pm): I rise to participate in the debate on geothermal power. This is a very topical and timely issue, because we realise full well that we need to move towards renewable energy rather than rely on fossil fuels. Recently I had the pleasure to travel to New Zealand with the environment committee, capably and well led by the erstwhile member for Pumicestone.
Mrs Sullivan: Thank you.
Mr FOLEY: Yes, the member did a great job. We had a wonderful trip where we were able to review in one trip wind, hydro, geothermal and wave technology.
Mr Moorhead: That sounds like an awful lot of hot air.

Mr FOLEY: No, we worked very hard. Let me assure the member of that. The one thing that came from that trip was that we realised that, when it comes to renewable energy, you cannot have all of your eggs in one basket. A meaningful mix of renewable energy is required to capture the gamut of energy that is required without relying on fossil fuels. Prima facie, geothermal would seem like the silver bullet that is going to fix all of our energy woes. But, as can be seen with underground coal gasification, one needs to weigh up very carefully the safety factors involved in this type of technology. Is it really worth it? We have to ask ourselves that question particularly in terms of safety, such as risking the pollution of the underground watertable. Once that is done, it is impossible to undo. There are lots of things that probably seemed like a good idea at the time, such as BP drilling for oil off the gulf coast and some of the ecological disasters that have been wreaked in places like Papua New Guinea through mining.

Whilst there are bad things about this bill, there are also some very good things. With regard to the property rights of landholders, this bill seeks to enshrine a fair and reasonable deal for landholders who may be displaced by geothermal energy projects. Through this bill, the minister is at least trying to make up for the shortfalls of previous legislation by increasing the compensation regime.

I guess there is no finer example of the law of unintended consequences than underground coal gasification. This is very much a new and innovative style of energy creation. Those who are on our environment committee know full well that I am the one who is always saying, ‘Let’s look at some of the new stuff.’ In a sense, solar and wind have become old hat, even though they are very efficient generators of power. We need to look at the cutting edge of energy generation, but before we release that technology to the population as a going concern we need to be very careful that there is safety in place for the watercourse. In recent times we have had great rains, and hopefully that has filled up a lot of the underground watertable. The last thing in the world we should then do is do anything that adversely affects the quality of that underground water.

One of the advantages of geothermal energy is that it requires a very small footprint in terms of surface area. But we have to be very careful about some of the other issues involved. I am not against underground coal gasification per se; I simply say that we need to be very careful about things like UCG until we can be absolutely sure that all of the safety boxes have been ticked. We just cannot afford to have contamination of our underground water.

When the environment committee went to New Zealand it visited the offices of Mighty River Power. We then drove to the Ohakuri Dam and power station and had a look at a hydro system that has been in operation for many years. You would look at that and say, ‘Boy, that is some pretty clean, green power there,’ because there is such a high snowfall there. The snow caps melt, the water comes down the river and if you simply put a turbine in the middle of that mixture you can generate power. But again, the law of unintended consequences comes through. When we spoke to representatives of Mighty River Power they said that if they had their time over again they would do it differently in terms of not impacting on fish life and flows in the river system.

The environment committee also travelled to the Aratiatia Dam and power station and looked at the generation of power in rapids, which is basically capturing water and then letting it flow out quickly. That was just a stunning place. Those of us who were on that trip really appreciated the incredible brainpower that must have gone into someone designing such an innovative system.

The committee also went to the Wairakei geothermal power station. I was particularly interested in that power station, because that is a very high-tech plant. Put simply, there is so much geothermal activity in that area that steam is able to be taken from the ground and put into a liquid--the name of which escapes me at the moment--that is highly toxic but has an 80 degree Centigrade boiling point. Clearly, unlike water, which needs to be heated to roughly 100 degrees Centigrade to turn into steam, this liquid can be heated from steam in the ground. That then becomes a vapour and drives a steam turbine. Fluid then simply goes off into condensation tanks, cools down and then the whole process starts again.

Some of the most impressive technology that the committee looked at was wind technology. We met with representatives of the Energy Efficiency and Conservation Authority and we met the chairman of the International Energy Agency’s Ocean Energy Systems. You just cannot go innovation for innovation’s sake. I and a few of the other members of the committee felt that some of the sea technology that was being propagated was not that feasible. I know that the member for Pumicestone had some grave reservations about the paint that was put on these things to stop the build-up of products on them as they sat in the sea.

The West Wind wind farm was just absolutely amazing. A number of members got some great photos. The size of these wind turbines was just amazing. When you see them on the side of the hill they do not look that big, but when you are up close to them you are absolutely dwarfed by even one of the blades and then you realise that this is a fantastic renewable energy. In some respects I wish we had some of the climate of New Zealand so that we could capitalise more on wind power. All in all, it was a fantastic trip. The committee had an opportunity to see renewable energy at its finest.

One of the comments that was made--and I think this is really relevant to this debate--is that in any consideration of renewable energy you must look at what is the natural strength of the particular area in which you are looking at creating the power. For instance, we wonder why New Zealand has around 20 per cent renewable energy. Clearly, one of the reasons is that it has such an unstable underground environment. There is so much steam and volcanic activity there that it is a heat resource that can be captured and used relatively easily compared to other places. The minister is well aware of the difficulties of creating geothermal power and, in fact, any renewable energy. The hard bit is to create it in a place where it has efficient access to the main power grid but it is not so closely sited to residences and farms that it might impact on people in a negative sense.

Clause 3 of the bill states that the purpose of the bill is to encourage and facilitate the safe production of geothermal energy for the benefit of all Queenslanders. I would urge the minister to focus on safe production, in particular of UCG. The bill provides for the granting of an authority to explore for or produce geothermal energy; the creation of a regulatory system for the carrying out of activities relating to geothermal tenures to ensure that the carrying out of activities relating to those geothermal tenures that conflict with other land uses is minimised; that people affected by the activities are constructively consulted; that owners or occupiers of the land adversely affected by the activity are appropriately compensated; that land and resources are managed responsibly; and, of course, that the use of renewable energy in the state is encouraged. That will in time become a motherhood statement. We are fast realising that some of the things that are done in the name of producing power are very, very dangerous to the environment.

In terms of geothermal power, it is a relatively simple process. Underground heat is produced by the friction of the earth’s plates rubbing together and the molten core at the centre of the earth. Hot rocks underground heat water to produce steam. That can be accessed in a number of ways. By drilling holes down to the hot region, steam comes up and is purified and used to drive turbines which drive electric generators. There may also be natural groundwater in the hot rocks. Whether it is a hot fractured rock system or whether it is a wet system, they are both valid technologies.

The first geothermal power station was built at Landrello in Italy and the second was at Wairakei in New Zealand. Others are in Iceland, Japan, the Philippines and the United States. In Iceland--and members will recall the volcanic issue of recent times which hurt the aviation industry--geothermal heat is used to heat houses as well as for generating electricity. Even if the rocks are not hot enough to produce steam in their own right, they can still be used efficiently. There is a civic centre in Southampton in England that is partly heated via warm liquid rather than the boiling point temperatures. It has a district heating scheme with thousands of customers.

How useful it is, of course, depends on how hot the water gets, where the hot rocks are to start with and how much water may be needed in a wet system to pump down to them. In that context, water is pumped down an injection well. It filters through cracks in the rocks in the hot regions and comes back up the recovery well under pressure. It flashes into steam when it reaches the surface. The steam may be used to drive a turbo generator or pass through a heat exchanger to heat water to warm houses. As I said before, there is a town in Iceland that is actually heated in that way. If we think about it in simple terms, it is the opposite of an air conditioner. A note of caution is that the steam must be purified before it is used to drive a turbine or the turbine blades will get furred up much like in an electric kettle. When we looked at some of the turbine blades in the hydro schemes in New Zealand we saw there was a lot of damage caused by what would be the most pristine waters one could imagine.

In terms of the context of this bill, one of the challenges is to find places where a geothermal power station can be built. There need to be hot rocks of a suitable type at a depth where they can be reached by drilling. The type of rock is important because it must be a type that can be easily drilled through. Sometimes in the fullness of time the geothermal site may actually run out of steam. Hazardous gases and minerals may come up from underground and it may be difficult to safely dispose of them. That is my concern with UCG.

We have a federal election this Saturday. If Labor wins this election it will be very keen to promote geothermal energy as an alternative to a domestic nuclear industry. If Labor wins the election I think we will see a bull market in relation to geothermal stocks--by the way, that is not an investment tip. There is more to the geothermal energy story than what green politicians have embraced. For alternative energies to be adopted at a commercial level they must provide truly reliable, safe and clean power to real customers and very soon. The companies must also provide investors with growing earnings and profits without huge start-up costs and cost blow-outs.

Queensland is a natural place for a solar energy industry but the amount of money that has to be put into the exercise to create even a 1.5 kilowatt PV system requires a tremendous government spend on that technology. We really have to push the other end of the envelope to make for cost-effective renewable energy.

The short version of how it works is simple. The earth has a molten core. About three to six kilometres below the surface of the earth in some places is a layer of super hot granite that can be as hot as 250 degrees Centigrade. Here is a really stunning fact: one cubic kilometre of hot granite at 250 degrees Centigrade has as much energy in it as 40 million barrels of oil. To put it in context, it is very, very significant and has the potential to reduce our continued dependence on fossil fuel or even replace fossil fuel.

By the nature of its geology, Australia has a lot of hot granite that is within three to five kilometres of the surface of the earth. We have the potential, if we do this right, to create a revolutionary industry in terms of power production. If we are not careful, the wider context of geothermal exploration could be picked apart by disasters that may happen in areas such as underground coal gasification. It would be a great tragedy to see one sacrificed because of the other. I think that this is a good bill and I would urge the minister to not take the brakes off in terms of safety standards for some of the more cutting-edge projects.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind)
(2.48 pm): I rise to speak fairly briefly to the Geothermal Energy Bill and to concentrate in particular on property access rights. I commend the minister for concentrating on that. Whilst the new energy that is being targeted in my electorate is LNG, the impact on landowners does not differ, irrespective of the location of the resource. It is my understanding from talking with landowners in my electorate affected by resource development that their clear impression is that often, as freehold title owners, they lack consideration in relation to entry by companies with an interest in the property and minerals or resources below the ground. They also lack the right to protect their property in respect of the use to which they have been putting it. There has been little opportunity for landowners to exercise their rights in relation to freehold title. My understanding of this bill is that it does address in great measure those issues, particularly in the area of geothermal energy.

I would like to thank the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee for its Legislation Alert No. 7, which comments on this bill. The explanatory notes acknowledge that generally the provisions of the legislation may affect the rights and liberties of individuals. More specifically, justification is provided in respect of individual provisions in clause 28. The notes state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Whilst the state is claiming, on behalf of all people in the state, ownership of those resources captured beneath the surface of the ground, as I have already said there has been a problem for landowners in the way that they were dealt with not only by the prospectors and those who are endeavouring to develop the resource but also, I might add, by the state government and the state government’s representatives. As a parliament, local government and, I assume, federal government, part of our responsibility is to defend the right of individuals and families to the quiet enjoyment of their land and their home.
XML.Hansard-Body: I know from my experience--and I am sure the member for Callide and others whose electorates have had prospecting and particularly extraction of underground resources, whether it is gas or coal, would know--of the tension that has developed within landowners’ family structures and emotional structures. We know that often the development of those resources comes at a great price. That tension can be caused by the amount of time between the identification of the resource, the acquiring of all the permits and the development of the resource. The family almost goes into hiatus in terms of what they can do on their property. It can cripple individuals emotionally and psychologically, it can destroy marriages and fracture families. That has been part of the experience in any electorate that has underground resources that are being developed. Therefore, if this legislation gives greater respect and rights to the owners of the properties in their dealings with the resource developers and also the state, certainly it is a step in the right direction.

Recently in the electorate of Nanango we saw the problems that can arise with new technology in the underground coal gasification industry. Those farmers faced difficulties in circumstances that were totally beyond their control. Indeed, they were relying on the state and the state government’s departments to properly monitor the operators of that enterprise. It has transpired that that monitoring and overseeing was ineffective or insufficient. Some farmers could not sell their cattle until after a short withholding period. There was uncertainty about the health impact not only on stock but also on families. Those are the sorts of frustrations that landowners face because of circumstances beyond their control.

I am most interested in the parts of this bill that give greater certainty, greater rights and greater clarity to landowners who are in the process of having resources developed on their land. The member for Callide spoke of landowners receiving a landowners’ information pack. Many landowners have had no dealings with industry in the past and are in a disproportionate position of power. Few of them are lawyers and they do not have access to lawyers so may not readily understand the legal implications of their situation and, indeed, whether the proponents are going through the right process in terms of access regimes. There are simple things that need to happen--and they should be simple--such as the spraying of vehicles for weed management. The landowners have to rely on the companies to do the right thing. Those companies may be obligated to do the right thing, but they have to do it practically. In many circumstances, the group or the individuals who carry the greatest risk are the landowners, many of whom have been in situ for many years.
The other aspect of the bill that I seek the minister’s clarification on relates to the retailers of last resort. In his second reading speech, the minister states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Currently, retailers of last resort can recover their costs of providing this service by imposing a fee on the transferred customers. The amendment in the Bill will enable a more equitable approach, by allowing the costs to be spread across all electricity customers through distributors’ network charges. The amendment will enable the improved cost recovery process to be developed and included in the regulation which sets out the details of Queensland’s retailer of last resort scheme.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I seek a clarification from the minister on this. With the deregulation of electricity and the ability for consumers to choose from whom they will buy power, is there a risk that the broad distribution network, that is, the group of people who may not have been speculative in their power purchases, will be caught in this new structure and will be required to pay, in part, the costs of perhaps a failed distributor? I seek clarification that there is equity in this changed structure.
XML.Hansard-Body: The bill clarifies that the coal seam gas proponents may undertake agreed low impact surface activities that do not invoke a resource right in underground coal gasification pilot areas. The second reading speech states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This will allow CSG production activities in surrounding areas to continue whilst allowing for the trial of UCG technology.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The member for Nicklin asked me what was my understanding of that. It appears to me that, whilst a CSG proponent may not have approval to commence resource extraction, they will have the ability to undertake low impact surface activities. If that is the case, I would ask the question: will allowing CSG proponents to undertake low impact surface activities infer or imply to the CSG proponent a fairly positive prospect for approvals to continue on the development? Does it place at a disadvantage the landowners or could they reasonably believe that the CSG proponent, without approvals for underground extraction at a point in time, could be disruptive to the landowner, thus undoing some of the good things that this bill sets out to do in terms of protecting landowners’ rights? I seek clarification on those two matters. I look forward to the minister’s summing-up.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr CHOI (Capalaba--ALP) (2.59 pm): It gives me great pleasure to rise to speak to the Geothermal Energy Bill 2010. At the outset I thank the minister and his team, both within the minister’s office and within the department, for putting together in my opinion a very important piece of legislation, particularly the amendments which address some of the land access provisions of this bill. I do believe that this bill largely addresses most of the issues that I have heard so far regarding land access conflicts between landowners and project developers in terms of facilitating improved relationships between resource companies and landholders, as well as providing consistent and transparent and, more importantly, equitable access arrangements for private land for these activities.

The Geothermal Energy Bill clearly aims to encourage the growth of the clean energy industry by providing a framework to facilitate the safe exploration for and production of geothermal energy. Exploration for geothermal energy was first introduced in 2004 with the implementation of the Geothermal Exploration Act 2004. That act enabled the commencement of geothermal exploration in the state while the legislation to enable production was developed. The bill only regulates large scale production as determined by a threshold. Geothermal energy production that does not meet this threshold will be regulated if those activities trigger requirements under existing legislation.

Geothermal exploration and production may be conducted across many parts of Queensland, except in those areas declared restricted by the minister. Restricted areas may be released for geothermal exploration by the minister at a later date. A proponent can be granted a maximum area of slightly over 3,700 square kilometres for an exploration permit. The maximum term for a geothermal exploration permit is five years, with subsequent renewals allowed to a total of no more than 15 years. A geothermal exploration permit holder is required to relinquish part of the area of its permit after each five-year period from the date the permit originally took effect to ensure that land is available for other geothermal proponents. Where a resource has been identified, an exploration permit holder may apply for a ‘potential commercial area’ for a maximum term again of five years. This provides the holder with an option to retain an area of the permit for reasons such as attracting further investment or further research and development.

To support the development of the geothermal energy industry in Queensland, the bill allows a maximum term of 30 years for a production lease with no limit on the number of renewals. Proponents are able to apply for a maximum area of slightly over 1,800 square kilometres for a geothermal production tenure. This bill also recognises existing resource tenures by providing a mechanism to ensure efficient use of the state’s resources by allowing overlapping authorities for exploration and also for production. This bill further demonstrates clearly the government’s commitment to cutting Queensland’s carbon footprint and supplying Queenslanders with cleaner energy and an alternative to fossil fuels by implementing this renewable energy legislation.

As I participate in a lot of community engagement forums, there is no doubt in my mind that one of the biggest problems with the emerging energy sector--whether it is CSG, LNG or geothermal--is the conflict between landholders and project proponents. I am pleased to note that this bill contains landmark amendments to the way resource tenure and authority holders access private land and how compensation arrangements are arrived at. These amendments are essential in my view due to the increase in interaction and conflict between landholders and tenure or authority holders for land use, particularly in the light of continued strong growth in coal seam gas and coal exploration and development across the state.

The new land access provisions will make it easier for private landholders and mining and petroleum companies to deal with the complexities and challenges caused by overlapping activities by providing a uniform framework for land access and compensation across all resources legislation. The key elements of the land access policy framework reflected in this bill include a single land access code of conduct, with all tenure and authority holders required to comply with the code; a notice-of-entry process for designed preliminary activities that will have little or no impact on landholders; a requirement to make a conduct and compensation agreement prior to entry on land for advanced activities that are likely to impact the landholder; graduated negotiation and dispute resolution processes; and improved compliance and enforcement processes for administering the code of conduct.

This bill introduces activity thresholds that increase the level of regulation as the intensity or impact of the proposed activity increases. This is a sensible measure that balances the level of regulation with the level of impact. Early exploration activities can have nil or negligible impact on private landholders. The bill defines these as preliminary activities, which might include taking rock, water or soil samples or simply walking the land. For preliminary activities, resource authority or tenure holders must give each owner and occupier of the land within the tenure or authority area an entry notice and copy of the land access code at least 10 days prior to entry. Access for these activities does not require a conduct and compensation agreement.

Correspondingly, when the impacts are far more significant on private landholders or occupiers, a higher level of accord is required. These activities are referred to as advanced activities. For advanced activities, tenure holders must be party to a conduct and compensation agreement with each eligible claimant for the land. Where agreement is not reached, the framework provides mediation mechanisms in the shortest possible time frame. To assist in the negotiation process, a standard conduct and compensation agreement template has been developed in consultation with resource and agricultural industry peak bodies, along with a negotiation tip sheet for landholders.

The land access amendments introduce an innovative new requirement for mediation to occur between parties if agreement could not be reached. This has been included on the basis that all stakeholders have expressed a desire to keep these matters out of the Land Court and to use all means to negotiate a mutually acceptable outcome for both parties. If both parties decide, they can always go to the Land Court for a final determination. A detailed compliance and enforcement strategy will be developed to ensure that these new measures achieve their full effect on the ground, particularly with respect to the land access code.

In the balance of my time I would like to briefly touch on the amendment to the Electricity Act 1994 regarding the retailer of last resort scheme. The scheme protects consumers of an electricity retailer that is suspended from the national electricity market or otherwise becomes unable to provide retail services. The scheme ensures that customers of a failed retailer continue to receive electricity supply by transferring them to another retailer, commonly known as a retailer of last resort. But there are costs associated with providing a retailer of last resort. Currently, the scheme provides for a retailer of last resort to recover costs by charging transferred customers a fee, and at times these fees can be significant, especially for small customers.

A retailer of last resort event occurred in December last year when Jackgreen (International) Pty Ltd was suspended from trading in the national electricity market. The scheme operated successfully to transfer customers of Jackgreen to other retailers. However, concerns were raised about the current cost recovery process. The amendments to the act will provide a head of power to enable development of a more equitable cost recovery process to be included in the Electricity Regulation 2006. The proposal would spread costs of a retailer of last resort evenly across all Queensland customers through network charges. This means that, if a retailer of last resort event were to occur in the future, all customers would pay a very small amount instead of costs being met only by customers of the failed retailer.

Retailer of last resort events are very rare, with only two occurring since the commencement of the national electricity market in 1998. The act amendment will enable development of an improved cost recovery process to minimise cost to customers while encouraging retailers to continue to offer the retailer of last resort service. It will also align Queensland’s retailer of last resort scheme more closely with a proposed national scheme expected to be introduced in mid-2012 under Ministerial Council on Energy reforms.

I am pleased to support this legislation. In conclusion, I want to comment on the state of affairs of Queensland energy. Most people recognise that in the past Queensland has been known as the Sunshine State, and rightly so with more than 310 days of sunshine each year. In recent times, the Sunshine State has been called the Smart State. It is my view that in the near future Queensland will be known as the Energy State because of our clearly abundant supply of coal--if we can develop a cleaner capture and storage technique--coal seam gas, natural gas, solar power, geothermal energy, wind power and tidal power. In my view, these are all very important for the economic development of this state. They will also provide alternative energy for Queensland. I fully support this bill.

Mr KNUTH (Dalrymple--LNP) (3.10 pm): The regulations proposed in the Geothermal Energy Bill 2010 and accompanying amendments to the Mineral Resources Act 1989, the Greenhouse Gas Storage Act 2009, the Petroleum Act 1923 and the Petroleum and Gas (Production and Safety) Act 2004 are a long overdue recognition of the need for a more collaborative approach to mining exploration in this state. This is a rare step by this government towards correcting the understandable concerns amongst landowners that the tenure of land that they have toiled over the generations could be at any moment superseded by a tenure to an exploration company for the resources beneath their crops and pastures.

The member for Callide was right when he said that landowners should never be the victims in the necessary but often times complicated issue of land rights. The bill goes further, ensuring stronger negotiation positions for landowners when dealing with resource exploration companies. However, as stated by the member for Callide, there needs to be a greater effort by this government to make landowners aware of the implications of this legislation, their rights as well as their responsibilities.

Only a month ago, carcinogenic chemicals found by a company monitoring bore samples caused the shutdown of local bores within a two-kilometre radius of an exploration site in the Kingaroy basin. While the restrictions imposed by DERM have been lifted, this highlights the permanent impact that exploration can have on the surrounding area, not only the area for which the resource company has tenure.

The coal seam gas industry is a relatively new and untested industry in Australia. I welcome more stringent regulations which entitle landowners to have their say in the methods that resource companies use on their land for exploration. The perception of the mining sectors as the schoolyard bully with legislative protection has contributed to much unnecessary tension between primary industry and the resource industry. This government’s failure to recognise the importance of protecting the agricultural assets that built this state before the shift in our economy to the energy industry has not alleviated this perception.

The case in the Kingaroy basin brings to bear an even more critical aspect of this legislation--that is, the need for cooperation where landowners feel and believe that mining companies are not a burden but at times an asset. The greatest asset that we have is security of tenure and that is what has made this country great. To undermine that security through vegetation management, spy in the sky satellites, dob in a farmer hotlines and excuses to ride roughshod over land tenure all in the name of mineral wealth or protecting our environment severely contradicts our democracy and the Australian way of life. The need for legislation which recognises the supremacy of principal tenure is fundamental in upholding the authority of land tenure legislation.

The proposed legislation does not affirm but goes further towards assuring property owners are to have a say regarding operations and mineral development on the properties for which they hold tenure. Landowners deserve legislation that recognises and respects their contribution to the Queensland economy. Cooperative relationships between parties involved in tenure negotiation should see less delay in exploration and development by the mining sector.

It is important for landowners to receive appropriate compensation if they have developed their land for generations and, all of a sudden, the situation changes--whether it is a road going through their property or some development in their region. It is important that just compensation is received for all of the costs that they have put into their land. That is why the LNP has a policy of a charter of property rights. We want to ensure that anyone who is affected in any way when it comes to their land being resumed is appropriately compensated. I commend the minister for this legislation because I believe it goes a long way towards fixing issues which have been around since I was elected in 2004, like vegetation management, reef protection, dob in a farmer hotlines--the whole lot. I commend the minister for showing an element of goodwill towards that.

This is important legislation. Two or three years ago, there was a mine spill at Mount Leyshon mines and there is still leakage and there always has been leakage. That spill went into Clarke Creek, the Puddler, the Two Mile, the Broughton and then into the Burdekin River. It contaminated that water. There were a number of dead birds and the people in the town were ropeable, but the sad fact is that it took 20 days before the EPA came out and looked at that contamination.

I commend the EPA for what it is doing now at the Mount Leyshon site in working with the company, but at that time it was unbelievable that it took the EPA 20 days to even look at it, when only two weeks before a household that had 5,000 bats above its home was visited by an EPA boss from Brisbane who knocked on their door and threatened them on the grounds that they were disturbing the flying foxes. I hope we never see anything like that, but I commend the EPA for its work with Newmont over the Mount Leyshon mine spill. There is still an issue in relation to the landowners in that area. Some of them have not been able to sell cattle for over two years, and that is why it is very important that we ensure we have protection for our landowners.

Queensland’s primary industries provide more than $13 billion to the Australian economy and they were recognised as being a main driver through the global economic crisis. It should also be acknowledged that the mining and petroleum industry contributes $26.76 billion to the Australian economy. That is why it is unbelievable that the present Prime Minister and the previous Prime Minister proposed the super tax. These industries were the main drivers through the global economic crisis, but they are being punished by the government in this act of stupidity. I know of a helicopter pilot who sold his helicopter because he lost three mining projects due to the fact that there is no confidence in the mining industry as a result of this proposed super tax. In regard to this legislation, we hope that this is a step in the right direction to ensuring successful exploration tenure negotiations that will see our mining and energy industry continue to grow through cooperation and due respect to our agricultural sector.

Mr HORAN (Toowoomba South--LNP) (3.19 pm): The Geothermal Energy Bill is an important bill which we are debating today because it does, amongst other things, set in place a land access code of conduct which is so important to people who are suddenly finding with the burgeoning mining industry that their rights at times are being virtually trampled over.

The growth of the mining industry in some parts of Queensland I think has taken everybody by surprise, and no more so than in the Surat Basin to the west of Toowoomba, where exploration was on a relatively minor scale for a while, particularly with regard to coal seam methane. All of a sudden there has been virtually an explosion. The sheer size and scope of it have taken people by surprise. There is potential for tens of thousands of bores to be drilled on a grid pattern that is something like 800 square metres apart. Then there is the joining up of all those various bores or wells that have been put down, linking up to various gas lines, taking that gas to a central point or taking it further to Gladstone to export all over the world through 26 or more supertankers. In just a few years, the industry has almost exploded before people’s eyes.

Initially everybody saw it as being really good for the economy. It has the potential to provide diversification, particularly in the Surat Basin areas--in the Western Downs from Dalby through to Chinchilla, Miles, Wandoan, Roma, Taroom and Injune. There are massive areas which are as yet untapped so it could go on for many, many years.

It is important because it is another source of energy with a lot of potential uses in the future over and above the oil supplies of the world. The world’s reliance, and particularly Australia’s reliance, on oil as an energy may well be diminished by the discovery of coal seam gas throughout the area. There have been various estimates of what the extent of it is, but it is in the hundreds of years perhaps of supply of this particular form of energy for export or for our own use.

Along with that has come a lot of community excitement. There has been work for contractors and for people on the land or those living in rural towns. Those towns have been provided with opportunities, particularly for young men and women to work as contractors, to go away to university to get degrees or technical knowledge, and to come back and work in an exciting field. It certainly has been seen as having great potential to provide additional sources of income, population, growth and liveability to some of the towns by virtue of the extra people, extra facilities and work opportunities. Business is doing reasonably well or certainly far better than before.

However, in the midst of all that excitement I think everybody lost sight of some of the things that were gradually happening and taking over almost like a tidal wave. First of all there has been the issue of access, which has gone from accessing only a few properties to suddenly blossoming into wanting to access on a massive scale a vast area. As I said, some companies are drilling tens of thousands of wells and bores on a grid pattern right throughout this area. That involves on a massive scale drilling, logistics, accessing of properties and the subsequent follow-up with pipelines and possible disruption to the operations of properties.

When some of these resources were discovered in low-grade country, it was not all that much of an issue. In some parts of the Western Downs--to the west and south-west--it is pretty ordinary country and it has not been a problem. However, as these developments occur on more developed areas there may be irrigation bores, fenced off areas, cattle laneways leading to yards and cell grazing, a lot of fencing, laser levelled areas for irrigation, flood irrigation and precision farming, and the use of GPS and high-tech tractors that can do up to five or six processes in one pass. All of these sophisticated farming areas are now also being impinged upon by this development. Alarm bells first started to sound when landowners found people coming onto their property without the normal common courtesies, protocols or systems being observed.

Very often a company might have said, ‘We’ll do the right thing,’ but as it filters down to different contractors, subcontractors or sub-subcontractors--for example, two or three blokes in a Toyota Land Cruiser--they just drive past the gate, go over to where it has to be done, peg it out, and the next thing the farmer comes out and says, ‘What are you doing here?’ They say, ‘We’re here to peg out where we are going to drill.’ It was almost like that.

This bill today is the result of a committee that has been put together that included organisations like AgForce to endeavour to have in place a proper code of access regime that respects the property rights of people and that has some common courtesies, systems and protocols in place that go right down to people in particular companies. So there can be no excuse for people just driving onto properties and putting pegs out where a centre pivot is going to go around and all the rest of it. That at least is a move in the right direction.

One of the problems that we face in Australia is that the resources in Australia belong to the Crown; they belong to the people of Queensland. Sometimes people think from watching movies in America, which has a different type of land title, that if oil is found on your property then overnight you are a billionaire. It is a different system over there. The resources are not vested in the Crown; the resources are vested in the property owner. We have a different system. People often say, ‘They can’t just come onto our place, can they, and do things?’ I know there are certain protocols that have to be gone through, but basically companies can take out mining leases over people’s properties. In fact, I understand that something like 70 per cent of the amalgamated Toowoomba Regional Council, which has combined eight councils into one, is under various mining exploration leases or other types of mining permits. That gives the House an idea of the breadth of these mining leases and the number of people that are being imposed upon.

Go back a couple of decades with the development of the coal industry in Queensland, and much of it was in Brigalow Belt areas and more extensive grazing areas. It still impinged upon people’s property rights but it had a lesser impact than it is having now. Intense drilling, mining exploration, leases and so forth are occurring close to cities and towns, almost surrounding them; in lifestyle areas where there are numbers of small blocks; and in highly productive areas such as the Felton Valley, to the south-west of Toowoomba, and Haystack Plain, just west of Dalby.
