To the north of Toowoomba in the Acland area, where extensive mining now takes place, only about 1 decades ago that was a tightly knit, mixed farming community. There were little Lutheran churches and other churches dotted throughout the area. That entire area is now a social desert. It is a whopping big open-cut mine. Farms have been bought up all over the place. The whole area has been denuded of people and of houses. The company is running a major rural enterprise with only a handful of people because it has bought up all these different farms that eventually will be part of the coalmining exercise there. That coalmining exercise, I understand, will double in the very near future.

That is the dramatic change that takes place. That is what the people of Felton fear and see happening in their area which is one of the most fertile valleys we could find in the world. The Pittsworth to Millmerran area is responsible for the vast bulk of egg production in Australia. The grain production in the Felton valley is very important. It is grown in the beautiful blacksoil on the creek flats through the Felton valley.

The phrase that the people fighting for the Felton valley and the Haystack area use is that you cannot eat coal for breakfast. That is very true. These are some of the finest agricultural lands that produce domestic production for Queensland and produce exports for Queensland and Australia. The needs of these people and the balance in the whole system have to be considered as we rush headlong into these massive increases in mining.

Access is covered quite specifically in this bill through a code of access. This should have been there some time before. The pace of the development has been almost exponential. It is good to see that this bill introduces a code of access so that there is some certainty, some courtesy and some regulation when it comes to how access occurs.

Along with the access problem there is the problem with getting rid of the saline water produced from the coal seam methane process. I will deal first of all with the problem water from the coal seam methane process. Thousands of bores are put down to tap into the coal, depressurise the area and suck out the coal seam methane gas. The gas comes out about 50-50 with water. The estimate is that in the very near future there will be about 350,000 megalitres of water a year that will be extracted with the coal seam methane gas.

Currently, that water is being stored in above-ground ponds that cover 20 acres or so. They are somewhat like the ring tanks that are built on the black soil of the Downs in the hope that the water can be evaporated off. They are also using snow machines to fire the water into the air and evaporate it. That water is salty. In many cases it is well above the 3 parts per million that is safe for cattle to drink. It is too salty to be put into the nearby Condamine River where it could then flow into the Balonne and then into the Darling and down into the Murray.

It is a serious environmental problem. The salts in this water are not the normal NaCl. The salts in this water contain a lot of fluoride and bromide and various other nasties or chemicals which make up salts that are not good salts. There is a real problem with this. The amount of salt that could potentially be left after the water is evaporated off is not wheelbarrow loads or truck loads, it is train loads--and many, many train loads of salt at that.

The problem is what to do with this water and what to do with this salt if the water is evaporated off. If the water were to go through a desalination process it would be a massive desalination process when we consider that we are talking about up to 350,000 megalitres of water a year. If Toowoomba did not have restrictions it would use 15,000 megalitres of water a year. This is potentially 350,000 megalitres of water per year. It is a massive amount of water to be environmentally dealt with so that the land is safe, the rivers are safe and the environment is safe from this huge amount of salt that is brought up in the water from way down in the earth.

The other issue that has suddenly arisen is the concern that people have about the Great Artesian Basin. It is one of the great wonders of the world. The only reason that Australia is populated in many of the areas west of the Great Dividing Range is there is artesian water. It would be almost impossible to run any grazing operation in Western Queensland without artesian water because the rainfall is not reliable enough.

This is one of the most precious resources we have. It has been likened to the Great Barrier Reef in terms of its value. Not only is this a great national icon but it also delivers water in those areas. It is old water. We are not sure where it comes from and how it is recharged. Some say that it comes from the highlands of New Guinea and over hundreds of years it seeps through rock. It is very old water. If this water is not carefully looked after and managed by capping the bores and no longer having open drains for water for sheep and the pressure and level of the water is not maintained the levels will seriously drop down and it will take a long time to recover, if at all.

People are worried about the depressurising of these areas with the use of tens of thousands of bores. What is that going to do not necessarily to the artesian bores but to the other bores that do not go into that level but go down into the basalt or other areas? Is the depressurising going to drop the level of water? Will the mining activities impinge upon the viability of farming or grazing operations or impinge upon towns in these areas where there is this rapid development having a water supply?

What is going to happening to the artesian water from the Great Artesian Basin with this deep drilling in that area? Is it going to allow water to seep from one area to another? Is it going to depressurise areas? What is going to happen in years to come? Will these bores ever be filled in with concrete so they remain an impervious connection between different levels of underground water on different rock shelves and at different levels? Much of this is unknown. Given the pace of the development and the pace of exploration, this is worrying people.

Whilst this bill deals specifically with the code of access there are other issues that we are faced with at the moment. We have to deal with the thousands of megalitres of saline water that is brought up with the coal seam gas. We have to make sure that there is absolute security of water supply from the Great Artesian Basin and from the other underground water structures that are so vital to farming and people being able to live in those areas.

I know that this bill deals with the overlapping of leases. Recently we saw an issue in Kingaroy. There was the scare of contaminated water from the coal gasification process going on there. I saw this in its early stages at Chinchilla a number of years ago. People have said it is new technology. It is old technology. It is based on what the Russians used to do in Siberia.

Coal gasification is quite a crude system. The coal underground is set on fire and burnt so that the gas is discharged and comes up through the pipes and collected. Following the drilling down at different grid points and the burning the ground subsides. We end up with properties that are roly-poly and up and down. People would not want to ride a horse through some of these places after a few years. They would have a tumble if they were going at any speed. The ground subsides due to the burning of the coal. It depends on the level at which the coal is. I saw that in the area between Chinchilla and Kogan some years. They were doing initial trials and tests there. I saw the subsidence and spoke about it with the people there. That is the legacy.

The code of access at least addresses one particular problem. But we have ongoing problems and issues. One of the big ones is respect for people’s property rights. I know the LNP has come forward with a marvellous five-point plan that respects property rights. It looks at the issues around food and fibre production and protecting the water rights of people. That is important. What we need in the future is a five-point plan like the LNP has put forward. Areas like Felton and Haystack, prime pieces of agricultural land, could then continue to feed the people of Australia and indeed the world.

Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind) (3.39 pm): I rise to participate in the debate on the very important Geothermal Energy Bill. At the outset I indicate to the House that the member for Nanango has unfortunately had to leave the parliamentary precinct to visit a very close friend who is dying. If a vote is taken on this bill before the member for Nanango returns and members wonder why she is not voting on this bill after her contribution to this debate yesterday, that is the reason.

Very clearly, this is a proposed new law to regulate mining and geothermal energy exploration in Queensland, and the bill amends a number of Queensland acts--the Mineral Resources Act 1989, the Greenhouse Gas Storage Act 2009, the Petroleum Act 1923 and the Petroleum and Gas (Production and Safety) Act 2009. The bill simply sets out a whole range of new laws to better regulate a range of issues, including the code of access to private land by mining and exploration companies and mediation and compensation issues--an issue which members have certainly touched on in great detail. The bill also distinguishes between preliminary activity and advanced activities. The bill is also an attempt to better reconcile competing interests between freehold land, leasehold land, and mining and exploration permits throughout Queensland.

This is nothing new. The state government has always been challenged to find the best fit to reconcile these competing interests in Queensland. Queensland has a number of categories of land tenure ranging from freehold land through to leasehold land through to a whole range of state government permits. All of those permitted activities enable landowners and lessees to undertake a range of permitted activities. The government also very clearly sets out a range of prohibited activities, and the prohibited activities depend upon the will of the government of the day. History will show very clearly how previous state governments and this state government have reflected the will of the government as to how they want to either better protect certain parts of Queensland, be it our natural land or our waterways, and how other permitted activities are able to take place. Marine parks are protected under the Marine Parks Act 2004. Recreational areas throughout Queensland are protected under the Recreation Areas Management Act 2006. A whole range of different state forest reserves are protected and regulated under the Forestry Act 1959. National parks throughout all of Queensland are protected and regulated under the state Nature Conservation Act 1992. We protect land and waters for a whole range of different reasons.

With regard to this bill, I note that it has proposed a simple way to deal with overlapping mineral and pilot tenure. At the moment Queensland has three pilot trial underground coal gasification plants. One is at Chinchilla, commonly known as Linc Energy, and then there are two, Cougar Energy and Carbon Energy, in Kingaroy in my Independent colleague the member for Nanango’s electorate. These three underground coal gasification plants are dealt with under this bill pursuant to their respective mineral development licences, and they are, as stated in the bill, licence No. 309, licence No. 374 and licence No. 385. They are specifically identified in this bill with regard to pilot tenure licences. I understand that the bill will enable these activities to continue their underground coal gasification trials until 2012, unless the state government intervenes and stops it earlier. As I understand it, under this legislation these three underground coal gasification trial plants are able to have priority to continue their trial works until the government stops it or on the advice of an expert and scientific panel which is due to report back to the government by 2012, or earlier if necessary.

The bill also deals with overlapping mining and exploration approvals that apply to the same land. I understand that trial underground coal gasification projects will have priority over coal seam gas projects which may be in that same area, yet I understand that coal seam gas investigations are able to still continue on the basis that they are deemed to be low-impact work as set out in this bill. I note the minister’s second reading speech where he said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Bill also clarifies that coal seam gas ... proponents may undertake agreed low impact surface activities, that do not invoke a resource right, in underground coal gasification ... pilot areas. This will allow CSG--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: coal seam gas--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: production activities in surrounding areas to continue whilst allowing for the trial of UCG--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: underground coal gas--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: technology.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That is there for us all to see in black and white. There is no doubt about what we are voting for in this bill, notwithstanding the range of other very significant improvements in trying to better manage the conflict between landowner and miner interests.
XML.Hansard-Body: That leads me to a meeting that I attended at the last sitting of parliament where many farmers--husbands, wives and children--from the Darling Downs and Central Queensland travelled to Brisbane to parliament. During that meeting I was presented with a letter. This letter was from Friends of Felton, the Darling Downs community, the Queensland Conservation Council, Friends of the Earth and Community Climate Network Queensland. It was a letter to the Premier and the Leader of the Opposition headed ‘Our Land, Our Water and Our Future are Under Threat’. That letter simply asked for a moratorium on coal seam gas development until social and environmental issues are resolved. It also asked for a ban on underground coal gasification and a prohibition on new coalmining and coal seam gas extraction on cropping lands in proximity to towns and areas of high ecological value and adjacent to protected areas.

These are very valid and justified requests, because over the years we have seen the state government respond to many requests. We have seen the marine parks being protected. We have seen a whole range of changes to laws in Queensland to pass specific acts of parliament to prohibit certain activities and protect others. What disappoints me after listening to the debate that has happened to date is that I understand the position the government has put. I understand the reasons and the lengthy preparation that has gone into the drafting of this bill by the minister, the government and previous ministers. However, my real concern is that we have an opportunity as Independents and members of the opposition to stand up and very clearly say, ‘We want to protect our good quality agricultural land. We want to value our good quality agricultural land because it is prime land and there is not a lot of it around. This is a chance to protect it for the future.’ In this regard, I find the opposition wanting.

At that meeting I attended with farming families from the Darling Downs a mother came up to me and said, ‘Peter, we know you’re not our local member but please don’t forget us.’ All they want is the state government of the day to recognise the importance of their land--not because they own it but because of the uniqueness of their land because it is so limited in our country and because it is good-quality agricultural land and good-quality cropping land. The disappointment I have at the moment is that the alternative government for Queensland is not flagging that it will protect that land. It is saying a whole lot of words, but when we have an opportunity to stand up and say, ‘We do not want to allow these pilot programs to continue because we want to protect your land because of the uniqueness of it,’ I believe the opposition is found wanting. We have that opportunity.

The government has placed a challenge before the opposition and Independents because it has included in this bill this very challenging component. The question is: will the opposition join the member for Nanango, me and hopefully other Independents and members of the Queensland Party in saying, ‘No. We are drawing a line in the sand. We will support the calls from the people from the Darling Downs and Central Queensland in saying that their land is special and their land is unique’? We are sending a very clear message that if we have the chance to form an alternative government--whatever form that may be--legislation will be passed to protect their land because of the agricultural significance of it.

Under our national parks throughout Queensland there is a whole range of mineral deposits, but we do not see mining companies lining up to make applications to mine in our national parks. Why is it that this government and this opposition are not prepared to take a similar stand on the good-quality agricultural land in Queensland? There is a limited amount of it. I believe that this is a chance for us to say very clearly that we are prepared to pass similar, strong legislation that sends the message to the multinational companies and the mining companies that are certainly wealthy and able to influence the government, the opposition, or whoever wants to listen to them, ‘Don’t waste your time because this land needs to be recognised because of its agricultural pursuits.’ I will support the Darling Downs community and I will support those parents and those children who are trying to protect their agricultural land by making it very clear that, when I vote on this bill, I will be voting against it because I believe to vote otherwise is sending a very clear message to all of those mining industries that, by supporting this bill, we are supporting the continuation of the pilot trials for the underground coal gasification proposals and perhaps in the future for the coal seam gas projects.

One of the members of the opposition spoke about how dare other people enter into their territory and pursue some of these issues. Reference was made to the Greens and, in the member’s words, the so-called Friends of the Earth and how they are so quick to exploit the situation. Basically, the member was insinuating that these political activists were influencing and manipulating his or the Liberal Nationals’ constituents. Can I say quite clearly that as an Independent I am not being influenced by the mining companies. I have no bone to pick with them apart from, as an Independent and a representative of state parliament and Queensland, being prepared to go wherever people want me to go to try to support their cause and I believe they have a just and valid cause. My challenge to the opposition as the alternative government for Queensland is to be stronger for their constituents.

I also would like to congratulate the minister for sending out the information packs. I know other members have spoken about this and have also congratulated the minister for them. I would hope that this information pack is able to be circulated throughout Queensland, similar to the letter that the former government sent to all landowners when it chose to change the tree clearing laws in Queensland. I cannot remember another time prior to that where a government wrote an individual letter to all landowners. There is a lot of valuable information in this information pack. But unfortunately, as other members have indicated, many members of our communities do not come into regular contact with politicians and they do not come into regular contact with bureaucrats. Yet there is so much information in this information pack that I believe would benefit and better inform all members of our communities. So can I put on the record my congratulations to the minister for this great information pack and the staff who have been involved in putting it together. I would urge the minister to use whatever means to make many of them available. I am not sure what the current run of them is. I have certainly put in a request for quite a few of these to be delivered to my area on the Sunshine Coast. Whilst I have some mining areas in my electorate, certainly it is not anything to the extent that is on the Darling Downs and in Central Queensland.

The last issue that I want to touch on--and I do not want to be simply having a go at different people; I suppose we all have a chance to say what we want to say--is that I took the opportunity to look at the Liberal National Party’s alternative proposal to have a charter for property rights. I listened to the member for Condamine address some of his constituents and other people at the last sitting of parliament at the entrance to Parliament House. He spoke about the charter of rights but what I did not hear was--and I have not heard this during this debate to date and I have tried to listen to all speakers--any real willingness to say, ‘We can put a line around this area in Queensland and say that this area is to be protected for agricultural purposes.’ We have heard previous governments say that and previous governments do that. My challenge to the Liberal National Party is to go further than their charter of property rights. The people I speak to say, ‘We don’t want compensation. We believe our land is special and unique because of what it is. It should be protected. Why is it that our land cannot be recognised in a similar capacity to our national parks or recognised in the way the Great Barrier Reef is recognised? Why do we not have a government and an opposition that is prepared to give us similar recognition because of the uniqueness of the land that we happen to be farming on?’ A whole range of members have spoken about the greatness of the agricultural value of the land, but I have not yet heard a member from the opposition or the government say, ‘We will legislate to protect it and this is how we are going to do it’ or even to go so far as to say, ‘These are the proposed boundaries for your land.’

Another member of the opposition spoke about how some of their constituents were being influenced or manipulated by outsiders. Can I say that at least Peter Garrett, the federal minister for the environment, has asked some further questions. I wonder what will happen if the government does change. I am not picking favourites; I do not know what is going to happen at the election on Saturday. Quite frankly, I do not know who is going to win. I know in my area we have a federal member who has simply been taking the people for granted. I hope he gets the greatest wake-up call ever, because members in safe seats deserve to get wake-up calls. I believe that may be the only reason I was ever elected, because the former member took the seat for granted. At that time it was deemed by the National Party to be a safe seat and to not worry about it. Safe seats in Queensland can never be taken for granted. I hope that at the federal election this Saturday a message will be sent to all those members who occupy safe seats in Queensland that they should not be allowed to take their constituents for granted.

I do not know what will happen after the federal election. I wonder if Peter Garrett will stick to his guns and get more information or if his alternative will simply say, ‘Yes, big business, mining companies, we need you because of all the industry and all the money you are going to bring. Forget about the good agricultural land. That can happen somewhere else.’ Maybe it will happen in China. Who knows? I do not know how much good agricultural land China has but, by crikey, we certainly get a lot of imports into our shops in Queensland that have been produced in China. I will resume my seat and look forward to listening to the contributions of other members.

Mr FINN (Yeerongpilly--ALP) (3.56 pm): I rise to speak in support of the Geothermal Energy Bill--a bill that is central to the ongoing development of renewable energy options for Queensland. The bill is about climate change. At the outset, I say that I believe that climate change is happening, that it is caused by human activity and that action must be taken.

Australia is a country that, comparatively speaking, is not rich in developed renewal energy sources. The proportion of renewable energy generation in Australia, whilst increasing, remains low in a world sense. As we close on 10 per cent, we remain well below the world average, below the OECD average and below countries including Turkey, Mexico, China, Italy and Brazil and way behind India and New Zealand. Today, as we have a target across Australia of 20 per cent renewable energy generation by 2020, our close neighbours across the Tasman have a target of 90 per cent.

New Zealand, with its mountainous topography and fast-flowing downhill rivers, has harnessed this energy with hydro schemes for decades and these schemes are the basis of New Zealand’s place in the top five countries in the world for renewable energy generation. Wind farms are in rapid development. As the roaring forties belt across the New Zealand land mass, some large scale farms are already in operation. As well, local landholders are contributing to the grid in smaller scale with single turbine generation. There are also opportunities for wave and tidal energy generation, with several companies developing prototypes to harness the natural energy of the sea.

But geothermal energy is one of New Zealand’s most reliable sources of renewable energy. New Zealand’s first geothermal plant opened in 1958 and, whilst geothermal provides approximately only 11 per cent of generation, there are several plants mapped for future energy needs. It is estimated that in New Zealand some 3,600 megawatts in geothermal remain untapped. Geothermal operations in New Zealand are primarily based on harvesting the vast reserves of geothermal fuel that is located very close to the surface, with some plants reinjecting cooled fluids to continue a cycle of generation. This reinjection is critical to the renewable integrity of New Zealand’s geothermal energy production.

Here in Queensland we are not so blessed with this readily available renewable mix. With a few exceptions, the vast majority of wind resources are along the southern Australian coastline. Similarly, wave generation is at its best in other places--tidal generation too, although the Australian government mapping of current movements indicates some possibility of harvesting this energy. The topography of Queensland has also meant that large scale hydro is not developed in this state, although some smaller scale schemes exist. Much of Queensland’s current renewable energy generation comes from biomass and there are great opportunities to expand this energy source into the future. And we all know about our fantastic solar resources. After decades of work on how to affordably harvest solar, the deliberate focus of this government to advance solar harvesting is getting results. Solar panels on schools and kindergartens, a solar focus for Gambling Community Benefit Fund grants, the feed-in tariff and rebates for solar hot-water systems are all enabling small scale generation to reduce household grid demand and to generate back to the grid.

When the Solar Bonus Scheme was announced in March 2008 there were 1,200 homes generating power from rooftop panels. By April this year this had grown to more than 23,000 home systems. Along with the more than 180,000 hot-water systems, this has resulted in more than 250 megawatts of power coming from the sun instead of from a coal powered station. Today this government has a target of doubling this generation, with a target of 500 megawatts by 2015: a virtual power station generating power across Queensland roofs. Large scale solar generation projects have also been announced, with an investment in solar thermal at Kogan Creek developing the largest solar thermal project in the Southern Hemisphere.

Just as solar has taken time to develop into a viable affordable energy source--and there is still a long way to go--we must continue to invest in opportunities to harvest other sources of renewable energy. Geothermal energy is a relatively young science in Queensland, but there is no shortage of people who are excited about its potential. For Queensland geothermal energy is about harnessing the heat of the earth’s core, or the hot rocks as it is better known, to produce steam to drive turbines. What we know is that there are potentially large areas of Western Queensland where the hot rocks may be close enough to the surface to be able to drive geothermal power generation. What we hope is that this energy can be harnessed in an environmentally safe way. What we hope is that this can be done in an affordable way. And what we hope is that this energy source can reduce our reliance on coal fired power generation.

The answer to these questions is dependent on government assisting the development of the geothermal industry and, importantly, implementing the legislative protections to define ownership issues and to regulate exploratory activities. As government invests funds into the industry, most notably investing in the Queensland Geothermal Energy Centre of Excellence and the Coastal Geothermal Energy Initiative, we must also develop the frameworks to enable industry development. The coastal initiative is extremely important. One of the major challenges for much of our geothermal potential is its location in relation to the electricity grid. The far west of Queensland, where geothermal mapping shows a potential energy source, is a long way from the grid and at an estimated cost to develop transmission at $1 million per kilometre this is a significant issue for the development of this industry. But we cannot let cost kill off the opportunity. Development of the industry will require government investment, it will require innovation and it will require governments to grapple with the public and private funding mix of energy generation and transmission.

This bill continues the development of this framework through implementing government policy for geothermal energy production by underpinning the concept that the Queensland people own all geothermal energy resources; ensuring a consistent approach with other Queensland resource based legislation; and providing security and flexibility for the fledgling geothermal industry. This framework is designed to encourage the production and use of geothermal energy to develop a cleaner and greener energy generation profile for Queensland. We simply must reduce our reliance on coal fired energy generation. It is this government that has placed strong emission standards and retrofitting requirements on any future development of coal fired power stations. It is this government that has developed the gas industry and gas fired energy generation.

I welcome this move away from coal reliance. But in my view we must have a vision for a future that moves away from gas fired energy production also. Whilst gas results in reduced carbon emissions when compared to coal there are nonetheless higher emissions from gas than other renewable sources. We must have a vision and set targets that see gas fired energy generation as a transition phase to a similar renewable energy mix as developed by our New Zealand neighbours. This bill delivers a regulatory framework for large scale geothermal exploration and a regime for land and resource management. The bill encourages geothermal industry investment in Queensland and is the next legislative step towards delivering a cleaner and greener energy future for all Queenslanders. I commend the bill.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP)
(4.04 pm): In 150 years the world has grown in a spectacular fashion, largely on the back of transmitted energy during industrialisation. Fossil fuels, starting with coal, have largely driven that growth. Coal is still and will remain the key ingredient that drives global growth. Here in Queensland coal remains our key mining export, supplying the second and third biggest economies in the world with feedstock for their power stations and their steel-making plants. Here in Queensland we are diversifying our energy exports to include gas--both CSG and UCG--to a demanding market globally. Enhanced geothermal systems--geothermal energy--is a major new baseload energy producer. In fact, it is the only known method and source of renewable energy as defined with the capacity to carry a large baseload.

The bill, whilst having a primary focus on geothermal energy, also involves the adjustment of those laws regarding land access. The minister in his second reading speech stated that the new changes have been developed collaboratively with key resource and agricultural sector stakeholders. Fortunately the bill introduces new provisions for access to private land and compensation. This is to be supported. The minister’s description of the five key points are reassuring for all. They have been described today as: compliance with a single land access code of conduct; notice of entry requirements; conduct and compensation agreements; prescribed negotiations; and improved compliance and enforcement powers. With these changes coming in well in advance of the extensive rollout of EGS--that is, the enhanced geothermal systems--landholders can expect to be more fairly dealt with. The issues relating to those affected by UCG primarily would reasonably lead anyone to say that these changes are appropriate, measured and respond to the problems that have been consistently raised by landholders on some of our prime agricultural land. It has been well described in parliament today and earlier.

The critical changes to be implemented as a result of this bill are those changes I referred to earlier relating to the management of property, access and dispute resolution. There are some other changes in the bill relating to the Electricity Act and the Timber Utilisation and Marketing Act. These are reasonable. Queensland has a fairly long history of access and mining leases and what to do and what not to do. The hope of this bill is that we might just do things a little better. The shadow minister has gone into this extensively. It would be repetitive to go through the issues he raised. I will not go there.

I too remain very disappointed that the fringe green groups have attempted to attach themselves to local farming groups on the Downs challenging primarily UCG groups. Hypocritically, these groups have struck rigid preference deals with federal Labor to facilitate Labor’s re-election federally. How anyone could conceivably entertain open discussion with such pretenders is beyond me. Such are sometimes the actions of desperate people. I do hope that the changes in this bill can give new hope to farmers, their families and local communities that they will not be sold out cheaply to facilitate others’ rights pre-emptively.

I intend to focus primarily on the issue of EGS and its technical aspects. I endorse some of the comments made by the member for Yeerongpilly in relation to alternative systems globally. EGS has as its core application the use of heat exchange technology; using superheated water pumped from one shallow underground water reservoir to superheated granite fractured seams three to five kilometres underground by very deep wells. The steam produced powers very largely distantly located power plants. The demonstration power plant of geodynamics, which is a one megawatt station, seems to have been reasonably successful as a renewable energy producer. Unfortunately, the power is being generated a long way from where it is needed. As has been described, it currently costs $1 million per kilometre for transmission. It may provide a long-term solution for us and a medium-term solution for baseload supplies for regional communities currently supplied by diesel electric generators. There are plenty of regional centres in Western Queensland that fall into this category. In New South Wales alone over the last three years baseload electrical demand has increased by 2.6 per cent and peak demand by 2.9 per cent consistently.

The concern from an environmental management point of view is what is the impact of injecting groundwater into deep seams of fractured granite. These concerns range from groundwater contamination to Great Artesian Basin contamination to possible alteration in the earth’s seismic activity. Whilst Australia is at low risk of earthquake, we have had severe earthquakes in Newcastle where there has been extensive deep mining underground and blasting.

Concerns may be more perceived than based in reality. The earth is 4.6 billion years old with a relative depth of 6,371 kilometres radius and a core temperature estimated to be between 5,000 and 7,000 degrees Celsius. The crust’s temperature is 1,000 degrees Centigrade. Australia is indeed an ancient land. Similarly, its geology is comparatively very old. The areas that are intended to be drilled and tapped are very old volcanic segments of the earth’s crust. One needs to be very careful about potentially destabilising both subsurface ground-holding water and underlying deeper, largely impenetrable rock, creating new aquifers. There are legitimate concerns that the wells either may have a relatively short life or need to be intermittently left empty because the heat contained within the rocks needs to renew itself. Certainly the earth has a deep molten core with vast amounts of retained energy, but the earth is very deep at 6,500 kilometres and the heat can take some time to be conducted to those energy depleted areas in the top 0.088 per cent of its thickness. I intend to go into the details of those granite rocks a little later.

The energy in those areas is stored energy. It is only renewable energy by virtue of the fact that the energy may otherwise be lost, it does not have to be burnt to produce heat, it does not produce greenhouse gases and its energy coefficient is stored in a different form to those other commonly used materials, that is, it is in rocks. It is different to solar energy for that energy is supplied by the sun and releasing that energy is radiation. EGS is energy coming from the earth, so it is incorrect to group it with solar, wind, tidal, wave and hydroelectric. It may be considered to be nuclear energy. Maybe it is not a true renewable, but with vast energy reserves due to retained heat it is almost inconceivable that these types of stations will have any impact on the quantum of energy needed to retain the earth’s energy homeostasis. As I said, this energy is trapped in granites by overlying rocks acting as an insulating blanket.

The Queensland site most studied is the Cooper Basin, where 320 million years ago granites were extruded from the earth’s molten core and covered by four kilometres of sedimentary layers of the earth’s crust as an insulating blanket. Primarily, this contains oil, gas and coal, as we know. When it was extruded it was super heated by solar radiation and much of that energy was retained within it. The energy is measured at an average temperature of 250 degrees Centigrade, which is considerably higher than the average core temperature of 180 degree Celsius in Europe, where the geology is more recent. The heat in the rocks is largely naturally occurring through radioactive decay. Therefore, the heat results from both earth contribution and solar sun contribution. As such, it blurs the definition of truly renewable energy. For those who missed the critical words, those core extruded granites contain 50 parts per million thorium 232, 20 parts per million uranium 238235 and four per cent potassium, some as potassium 40. Those radioactive substances are in slow decay and generate 10 microwatts of heat per cubic metre continuously for hundreds of millions of years. This is nuclear power at work. When they cooled originally, the granites fractured, filled with water and eroded. These mini-nuclear reactors, as they are, then superheated the water in those fractures.

By virtue of the temperature gradient, currently in the Cooper Basin it is 60 degrees per kilometre of depth vertically as the wells descend into the earth’s crust, as opposed to 30 degrees Centigrade elsewhere. This reserve is 1,000 square kilometres alone, with one drill hole per square kilometre and each square kilometre containing roughly 40 million barrels of oil equivalent. That means that the Cooper Basin, excluding its existing shale, oil and gas reserves, is a reserve of 50 billion barrels of oil. It is one-fifth the size of Saudi Arabia, 12 times that of the North West Shelf and it has a 25-year, fully developed reserve life if the whole thing is drilled. It is one-fifth the size of the Galilee Basin supply.

Our fossil fuels are primarily accused of causing all our current problems and are, in fact, what we are surviving on at the moment. The reason that we need to look for alternatives is only in a small part driven by their burning and the issue of contributing to climate change. A greater problem for humans is the pollution caused by burning fossil fuels close to our communities. Their supplies are really in slow decline and it is far more difficult to find new supplies at a reasonable cost. The major issue is that the internal combustion engine that we are currently using cannot be made more efficient, because of the issue of diminishing returns. You get to the point where as the technology gets better the percentage improvement starts to decline. We have been at that point for the past 25 years.

What has been going on externally are the things that we really need to take issue with. The recent massive solar flares and the Finnish volcano eruption released far more harmful radiation and CO 2 than burning 50 years worth of fossil fuels in every country of the world. Strangely, fossil fuels derive their energy coefficient by virtue of photosynthesis. For those who may have forgotten, that is using solar energy and CO 2 . Plants use carbon to store energy and produce O 2 as a by-product when burnt energy is produced. It is only deemed nonrenewable because the production of CO 2 is deemed to be a greenhouse gas. Geothermal energy does not produce greenhouse gasses and is deemed to be renewable by virtue of the fact that no-one yet knows whether we will reduce the earth’s capacity to capture and store CO 2 by interfering with its own retained energy that is in the rocks. There are only six sites in Australia where this technology is applicable. Those reservoirs are defined as areas where the earth’s temperature is above 225 degrees Centigrade at five kilometres of well depth vertically. As I said, the two major zones are the Galilee Basin and the Cooper Basin, and it is the Cooper Basin that has been most defined.

One cubic kilometre at 250 degrees Centigrade will, tentatively, yield 40 million barrels of oil. Australia consumes 953,000 barrels of oil annually. The USA consumes 20.8 million barrels of oil. Currently we import 687,200 barrels, we export 300,000 barrels, we produce 586,400 barrels and we are in slow decline. As at July 2009, in Australia 48 companies are exploring for geothermal energy. With $1.5 billion forecast to be spent through 2013, this is potentially big business for Australia. In terms of costings, which I think are relevant at this point, currently the cost for clean coal is 6.5c per kilowatt hour and for black coal the price is 3.5c per kilowatt hour. The cost for solar and wind is 8c per kilowatt hour and is not deemed to be commercially viable. Basically, at the current cost of geothermal energy, the projected cost looks to be 4c per kilowatt hour with green credits, which seems to be within the ballpark of affordability for the nation. Currently, gas costs 4.2c per kilowatt hour.

Basically, to enable EGS geothermal exploration, we need to understand that we have a 20 per cent renewable target, which it is reasonable to work towards. This is potentially big business for Australia. As I say, currently the power plant will produce only one megawatt, but the intention is to get to a 25 megawatt plant within 10 years. Basically, a 50 megawatt plant with nine wells, five production and four injection, and multiples can be scaled up to a 500 megawatt system as opposed to volcanic plants, which were discussed earlier by the member for Yeerongpilly. They do not emit potentially dangerous gases and elements as do those plants. Technically, they are not renewables under the current guidelines. The gases that are emitted are primarily hydrogen sulphide and cyanide. EGS does not emit those at all, but it does fracture the granites to unlock the heat.

Currently, 9,000 megawatts of power generated by these systems are installed world-wide. In comparison, for those who may know, the latest nuclear systems are largely 2,400-megawatt systems. That is the general norm. As has been said, these systems are throughout the world. Unfortunately to date, the long-term success of the technology is to be driven in part by need, regional location of power supply, tax breaks and possibly future green energy credits. Without those green energy credits, when it comes to the future growth of the industry, in a world where the global price of a barrel of oil is only currently US$75, it may be that we get to that target a little slower.

Rather than listening to all the noise about those who claim to be green but have no idea about accessible technology for energy generation, one might consider that the EGS is a small but uniquely applicable alternative energy source that has a unique application to Queensland and Australia. It will never be a major input, but it might be comparable to solar. This is true solar, not the kind that has currently been implemented in places like Cloncurry, where they only had four panels installed instead of 1,200. We have talked a little bit about solar. Basically solar can be generated by smaller units. Solar installations can range from three-kilowatt units that the average home should be looking at to the massive five-megawatt units which power some communities.

The issue of biomass was raised earlier. In my electorate of Gaven, the tip at Molendinar, which is a considerable landfill site, will close over the next couple of years. By installing a methane gas extraction system, utilising harvest wells and watering from above using treated recycled water, this continuous system has the potential on the current site to yield five megawatts of power and massively reduce smell and future groundwater contamination. This is green energy at work and does not require much more than a methane concentrator, water and a heat exchanger. It puts all old landfill sites to work long past the dumping of household and commercial waste. This is also a form of geothermal energy. Every megawatt of power generated should earn a measurable green energy credit.

When the oil price was double the current price, the technology was strongly viable independent of green credits. But, even with green credits currently, it is said that the technology is almost at the point where, at the current cost of coal and with those carbon credits, a fully costed power station with geothermal will break even in comparison to any new coal fired power station. As I say, it comes with obvious economic benefits. We need to ensure that whatever plan comes forward, particularly by the incoming government, it addresses the issue of these green credits that attach to the EGS that can make it represent a key ingredient of the alternative baseload energy mix, particularly in a decentralised state like Queensland.

Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (4.22 pm): This bill is largely a good bill. It supports a worthwhile environmental and energy security initiative--geothermal energy. But this bill has been so badly contaminated with one small provision that will cause me to vote against this bill if it is not removed. The minister in his second reading speech stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Bill also clarifies that coal seam gas (CSG) proponents may undertake agreed low impact surface activities, that do not invoke a resource right, in underground coal gasification (UCG) pilot areas. This will allow CSG production activities in surrounding areas to continue whilst allowing for the trial of UCG technology.
XML.Hansard-Body: A vote for this bill will mean that the mining companies using the coal seam gas method of mining, which is still under trial, will be able to continue potentially polluting underground water supplies near Kingaroy, Chinchilla and Dalby, and I cannot be party to that action, as well as wanting to do the right thing by the farmers and rural Queenslanders. If that injustice is allowed to happen in those communities it can happen in my community as well. It can happen in the communities of the Burnett which have prime agricultural land.

The fact that the LNP has decided to support this specific provision in the legislation is of great disappointment to me and once again reaffirms my decision to resign from that party and become an Independent. I will not be told what to do by big business, and my loyalty is with the farmers and the people of those areas. Member after member of the LNP has spoken in this place but they have not highlighted the danger to farmers’ property rights of this provision, as stated in the minister’s speech and also in the legislation on page 271, part 4A. I pay tribute to the Independent members for Nicklin and Nanango for highlighting this issue and listening to the people.

There is real anger out there about coal seam gas exploration. Providing an example of that anger, I refer to a media article by Sam Burgess from the ABC titled ‘Coal seam gas blockade to continue’. On 10 August she wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Residents and environmentalists say they have no choice but to prevent further coal seam gas exploration on Queensland’s Western Downs region.
A group of residents and activists are preventing Queensland Gas Company (QGC) employees conducting tests near Tara, north-west of Toowoomba.
The blockade has been in place since Sunday.
Drew Hutton from Friends of the Earth says a meeting with QGC officials yesterday failed to quell their anger.
“We’re saying that this is just one activity,” he said.

“It’s not one that we are necessarily saying is among the worst that they’re doing, but it is something that we’re drawing a line in the sand on and we’re saying we’re holding the line on, until they start improving their behaviour.”
XML.Hansard-Body: I would like to put on the record that I am not a great fan of Drew Hutton and the Friends of the Earth.
Mr Hinchliffe: It’s probably mutual.

Mr MESSENGER: I take the interjection. Yes, I suppose that feeling may be mutual and it will probably become a bit more apparent why it may be mutual as my speech goes on. However, on this particular issue I think that not only is it time we drew a line in the sand physically in our rural areas--our rural areas which have prime agricultural land--but also it is time we drew a line in the sand in this place and supported the farmers who are manning the barricades, literally, over this issue. How could we not pay attention to the farmers rallying outside this place, the centre of democracy? I feel that by voting for this bill with this provision contaminating this bill I would be selling out those farmers. For that reason, I will not be voting for this bill. The minister in introducing this legislation on 19 May 2010 also said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Climate change has been recognised as one of the greatest challenges of our time. The Bligh government is taking steps to reduce the impact of climate change on Queenslanders through recent developments such as the Queensland Renewable Energy Plan, which outlines a road map for the expansion of the renewable energy sector in Queensland. The Geothermal Energy Bill is another strategic response from the government to tackle climate change as we move to broaden our energy mix away from a reliance on fossil fuels.
XML.Hansard-Body: I support geothermal but it will be for a different reason than the government. My support will not be to stop climate change. Humans have very little chance of stopping climate change. There is a science called geothermal engineering which may for a while change the weather patterns--which may for a while cool the planet down, if it needs cooling down. However, this cult containing people who believe that man-made carbon is poison and has caused climate change must be challenged and called for what it really is. It is a traitorous, treacherous, religious ideology which will bring about the destruction of the free Western world if the proponents are allowed to continue speaking their rubbish.

Even if you humoured those who worship carbon and went with their argument for a minute that man-made carbon was responsible for heating up the world, Australia produces about one per cent of the man-made carbon emitted into the atmosphere. If every Queenslander and every Australian could shed themselves of every vestige of 21st century living--if they clothed themselves in animal skins, lived in caves, burnt candles, worshipped effigies of Bob Brown and his crazy Greens mates--and we could reduce our greenhouse gas output to--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Kilburn): Order! I ask the member to adjourn the debate.
Debate, on motion of Mr Messenger, adjourned.
Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (4.30 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • recognises that the national broadband network is an essential investment in the future, including for the benefit of Queensland children and young people, future jobs, e-business, e-learning, e-health and decentralisation;
• supports the federal government’s NBN as the best, most comprehensive program to provide the required high-speed broadband services to Queensland; and
• calls on the federal opposition leader to guarantee the same high level of service, especially to rural and regional Queensland as provided by the NBN plan.
XML.Hansard-Body: This Saturday, Australians and Queenslanders will have a choice. We will have the opportunity to vote in a national election and to choose a government for our country. As you would expect, in the last five weeks we have heard many things from all sides of politics about the ideas that they want to put forward. There are many important issues in this election, but one that it is vital Queenslanders consider and that we in this House have a position on is the question of how we will adopt and embrace the technology of the 21st century--that is, how will we deal with the national broadband network.

What we have on the one side is a political party, the Labor Party, that is committed to embracing this technology--and not only embracing it but enthusiastically pursuing measures that will ensure it can be brought not only to the communities and the suburbs but into the homes and businesses of every part of Australia. Just as railway lines revolutionised industry and commerce at this time in the last century, we are now on the cusp of another great leap forward when it comes to new technologies and the way they can revolutionise the way that we live, the way that we do business, the way that we learn, the way that we interact with each other, the way that we interact with people across the country and across the world.

I believe that Queenslanders have the most to gain from the national broadband network and that means we have the most to lose. Why do we have the most to gain? We are the most decentralised state of Australia. We are the only state that has more people living outside our capital city than within our capital city, and they are living in major centres, major industrial parts of our state.

Great cities like Townsville, Mackay and Rockhampton are not small, isolated places; these are large populations and they are cities and communities that are driving not only the wealth of Queensland but the wealth of this nation. A city like Gladstone is poised on the cusp of the next great development as we contemplate the liquid natural gas industry. Big international companies are making Gladstone their Australian headquarters, they are wanting to do business with Asian partners and the world. Without the national broadband network, without the high speed access that it brings to the internet and to the information highways of the world, we would be denying the children of Queensland access to the best learning tool of the 21st century. Our teachers would be denied the opportunity to teach our children in even the most remote locations and give them the window to the world that constitutes the internet. Businesses would be denied the opportunity to trade across borders, across time zones and across cultures with the rest of the state, the nation and the world to build capacity and to build opportunities.

Information and communication technology is without a doubt one of the single most important enablers and producers of productivity in an economy. In Queensland, we see economic growth moving ahead of the rest of the nation, but there are large parts of our economy, and this has been the case for a number of years, where we could be doing better when it comes to productivity. What could we be doing in relation to improving technology? It is technology that helps us to do more with less. That is what productivity means. It means using the resources you have and getting more out of it. What is one of the main ways we do that in a modern economy? It is technology. Information and communication technology are the main tools in that area.

We are already seeing this technology change everything about our lives. It will continue to do that at an exponential rate that, frankly, we simply will not be able to imagine and the challenge is to keep up with it. We have no prospect of keeping up with it without a high-speed broadband network that goes right into the regions and the rural and remote parts of our state.

This Saturday, Queenslanders stand to lose the opportunity of a lifetime if we see the NBN fail to be delivered by both sides of politics. It is the Labor Party that stands for the future in this election. It is Labor that understands that the tools of the future, the key to that future, lies in technology. We are not afraid of it. We do not want to take ourselves backwards. We do not want to take Queensland or Australia backwards. NBN is the future of the Queensland economy. It will underpin everything that industry does, everything we do in our schools and everything we do with and between our communities.

Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (4.35 pm): I second the motion moved by the Premier. I have come here hot off the heels of a meeting with western councils of this state of ours that are supposed to be represented by those who sit opposite.
Ms Bligh: What do they say about NBN?

Mr SCHWARTEN: That is what they came to see me about. They are big supporters of NBN. Leave yourselves in no doubt that you are selling out the bush if you vote against this motion here today. Those people from the councils get it. They do not vote for us but they expect you people to stand up for them. The two members who were there--the member for Gregory and the member for Mount Isa--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Kilburn): Order! Minister, can you direct your comments through the chair.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I will do that, Mr Deputy Speaker. Be aware that those councils west of the Great Divide get this; they understand the importance of NBN. They know how important it is not just for their schools and their health services; they know that they need to have that fibre in the ground to get the level of connectivity they should have in a modern and emerging world. So every one of the honourable members who sit opposite and who vote against this tonight do so with the firm knowledge that they are voting against the bush.

I also want to talk about the Independents here today, because during our last sitting week we were subjected to the emotive story about privatisation. A vote against this tonight is a vote for Abbott privatising the NBN. What we have seen is the Labor government say that we are going to publicly own this and then we are going to sell it into the private market, just the same way that other Labor governments have done in the past. The state of Queensland--for those ignoramuses who sit opposite who do not understand it--was built on the basis of state Labor governments building businesses and then selling them into the private enterprise. That is exactly what we are seeing here. There would be no Snowy Mountains scheme if it was not for a Labor government after the Second World War doing just this. Where was the business case for that? There was not one; it did not ever happen. Where was the business case for the railway line from here to Rockhampton? It never, ever existed because Labor governments got in behind it and said, ‘We need to have this infrastructure.’ All of this pious nonsense about business cases and all the rest of it falls flat on its face in that regard.

I know that the federal opposition leader does not get the business of tech, and that is fine. I am not particularly expert in that field, but I do understand the pathway to the future for our kids in Australia to compete with every other country in the world. I have been to Germany, I have been to Singapore. All of those places are talking about fibre in the ground owned by the government.
Mr Horan: That was a successful trip!

Mr SCHWARTEN: I do not expect the person who sold out Rockhampton to understand that. I do not expect the ignoramus from Toowoomba who is going to vote against the people of Toowoomba tonight to understand this because they are the ones who are going to miss out. Let us go through the list. Let us see which people will be selling out. Mr McLindon will be selling out the people of Beaudesert. The member for Dickson will be selling out the people of Buderim. Ms Menkens will be selling out the people of Burdekin. Mr Dempsey will be selling out the people of Bundaberg. Mr Messenger will be selling out the people of Agnes Water, Apple Tree Creek and Bargara. So the list goes on--Mr Seeney selling out Gayndah, Goomeri, Monto and Moura; Mr McArdle selling out Beerwah, Landsborough and Mooloolah; Mr Hopper selling out Clifton, Dalby, Kingsthorpe, Oakey--
Mr Dempsey: Prancer!
Mr SCHWARTEN: And Mr Crandon selling out Cabbage Tree Point.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I know you think it is funny, but you go and talk to your councils out there.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Kilburn): Order! Minister, direct your comments through the chair.

Mr SCHWARTEN: You think it is very funny that you are going to be here tonight ratting on the people who have elected you. You go back to your electorate and you tell them, you grinning ignoramus from Hervey Bay, that you believe that they should go without broadband. You go back and stand in the town square and tell the people--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Minister, direct your comments through the chair and we will keep it calm.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I did get carried away there. The reality is that the member opposite is on the list here as well as Billy Bayou. Tomorrow every single one of the members opposite will have a media release from my office pointing out how they voted. That will include the Independents. I say to every single member who votes against this motion tonight that every one of their local papers will have that tomorrow. They can justify to their own constituents why they want to put us back into the Dark Ages because of their absolute passion for a rotten, filthy tory federal government coming in and selling out the people of this state. That is what they will be voting for here tonight--not for their constituents, not for the future. They will not be here to support what is going to happen in their hospitals or schools in the future. What they are here to do is play politics and support Tony Abbott and not stand up for their constituents.
Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (4.40 pm): I move the following amendment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Delete all words after ‘That this House’ and insert:
supports a fast, reliable and affordable broadband service for Queenslanders.
XML.Hansard-Body: That should placate the member for Rockhampton, who delivered that contribution that was so embarrassing, including making reflections on members which really is just so inappropriate.

The NBN is a political construct. It has nothing to do with delivering real benefits at a reasonable price. Even the Premier came in here knowing that she has delivered a debt of $85 billion and will deliver multibillion dollar deficits over the next few years and she spoke with no great conviction. No telecommunications company would come near the NBN because they know that it does not make sense. The NBN is about politics, not the internet because Labor’s NBN is an uncosted, unsupported white elephant that has already seen a cost blow-out from $4.7 billion to $43 billion. The people of Queensland know only too well exactly how this happens because Queenslanders have seen this state Labor government mismanage projects time and time again and waste billions upon billions of dollars. We have seen it with the water grid, the desalination plant, the Traveston Dam and the health payroll system.

Labor has zero respect for the hard work and sacrifice of taxpayers to earn the cash to pay their taxes. It arrogantly wastes money like it grows on trees because its members have no idea about business. It is great to talk about vision; however, the six leading members of the government have a collective work experience of 181 years and only two years of that has been spent in the private sector. We see also that there have been no years spent running their own business or starting their own business, no years spent as a director of a family business or a company, no years spent as a director of a public company, no years in a senior position in a public company, no years in a senior position in a private company, no years working in corporate finance, no years working in corporate or business restructuring, no years working in or with a bank, no years of experience in the capital markets, no years in a stockbroking firm, no years in negotiating debt facilities with banks, no years running a small business, no years at the World Bank or IMF or OECD and no years in Treasury or Finance. However, they are happy to have the Premier’s former chief of staff, who probably wrote her speech today, standing up for the NBN. The fact that Mike Kaiser is the chief troubleshooter for the NBN should explain to all Queenslanders that the NBN is just a political construction of the ALP.

The incredible cost of the NBN--at least $43 billion--will be at taxpayers’ expense. How will we pay off $43 billion? This is very easy for the government, which loves talking in billions--billions not millions. Repaying a million dollars at a dollar per second would take 11.5 days. However, paying back a billion dollars would take nearly 32 years and paying back $43 billion, which is of course the amount that this is now proposed to cost, would take over 1,367 years at the rate of a dollar per second.

Members opposite talk about vision and all that sort of thing and it all sounds very flash; however, either users will pay massively increased broadband costs or the shortfall in revenue will result in increased taxes for families and businesses. In fact, the heads of agreement with Telstra for the NBN actually requires that Telstra not offer cheaper 100 megabit broadband. That is right: the Labor Party is making sure, right from the outset, that families will pay more for broadband and it is restricting competition just to make sure. As if the cost-of-living pressures are not high enough, the NBN will make it worse for Queensland families.

We know that under this government there is zero chance that the NBN will be rolled out on time and on budget. We know that the federal ALP has a terrible track record when it comes to delivering programs: computers in schools, insulation in homes, school assembly halls built in schools that are being closed, school tuckshops that cost more per square metre than five-star restaurants. These projects are minuscule in comparison with the NBN.

They must be joking! How on earth are we supposed to believe that this lot is capable of delivering this promise on time and on budget? But we have a plan to responsibly bring affordable high-speed broadband to 97 per cent of Australians at a speed greater than that promised by Labor. Established telco businesses decided that the risks associated with this broadband folly were way too high. Do we need fast broadband? Of course we do, but we should not be spending billions of dollars on it when a comparable outcome can be achieved for far less.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP) (4.45 pm): I am pleased to second the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Surfers Paradise, that this House supports a fast, reliable and affordable broadband service for Queenslanders. The NBN’s Tasmanian pilot program is a real-world demonstration of the economic incompetence, sheer hypocrisy and rank political opportunism that puts Labor’s political interests ahead of good government and good policy.

Stephen Conroy and the Tasmanian government continue to refuse to tell the public how many people have actually signed up to this pilot. What have we learned from a pilot that has cost up to $700 million? We had an admission from the Labor Tasmanian Premier that he is considering making the NBN an opt-out program for Tasmanians, a sign that he wants to force residents to sign up. Why should it be compulsory to sign up for a program that is supposed to successfully deliver everything Gillard and Labor have promised? To date, only about a half of the 4,000 houses--with no mention of businesses--eligible for the nation’s first NBN rollout have accepted the offer of cable links into their homes. This is no surprise, considering Conroy admitted he had not made any calculation of the likely take-up rate, despite estimated costs of between $500 million and $700 million. More Labor economic incompetence indeed!

Yesterday in this House the honourable member for Rockhampton rambled on in his usual manner before tabling a document titled ‘Queensland cities and towns getting optical fibre’. By doing so, he let the cat out of the bag about what Labor’s much vaunted NBN might or might not provide. As usual, Minister Schwarten makes a lot of noise, as he did a few minutes ago, about Labor’s so-called ICT achievements, but the facts do not ever match the rhetoric. Documents that the minister tabled prove that Gillard’s uncosted $43 billion NBN cannot guarantee the high level of service to rural and regional Queensland that he demands. He supports a plan that self-admits it cannot deliver the services it promises. Minister Schwarten did not want us to see what Gillard’s plan actually delivers. Queenslanders should read the fine print before rushing into believing Bligh’s Labor. The document states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This is an indicative list of towns that will receive some fibre coverage. Many of these towns will also receive some wireless coverage. The list is based on initial detailed modelling work done by NBN Co which may be subject to change following more detailed planning and design work.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The statement continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The fibre modelling is based on NBN Co’s current optical fibre design rules rather than detailed premise and density and may not result in contiguous coverage of all locations within the indicated fibre footprint.
XML.Hansard-Body: Minister Schwarten could not even spell the word ‘optical’ in his media releases let alone understand what it means. Let us take a look at Minister Schwarten’s ICT achievements. Labor’s previous broadband revolution, Project Vista, disappeared without a trace. Premier Beattie called this a leading Smart State project. It was due to start in 2007 with a network to run along existing power lines--another failed project; another broken promise.

Queensland Health’s payroll system, Schwarten’s $40 million plus white elephant that cannot pay health workers correctly, has cost $4 million plus since the go live and there is no solution in sight. But then there is the Shared Service Initiative--a $900 million turkey that governments across Australia point to as a textbook example of how not to run government IT projects. With this track record of achievements it is no wonder taxpayers should be highly suspicious about trusting Gillard, Bligh and Labor with their $43 billion NBN promise.
An article last week in the Australian by Grahame Lynch, the founder of telco newsletter Communications Day and a former editorial director of America’s Network , said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The ALP government’s $43 billion policy, at $2000 a head of population is the most expensive government intervention of its kind in the world. The Coalition policy--at $300 a head--actually ranks comparably to that of Singapore’s national broadband network ... which costs about $200 a head, and New Zealand’s at about $330.
XML.Hansard-Body: Grahame says that many of the benefits touted by Labor can be delivered by platforms in the coalition’s plan which excels economically by acknowledging the already substantial broadband infrastructure in place capable of supporting speeds of 30 to 100 megabits per second. This was recommended by the government’s own NBN implementation study. True to form, though, this Labor government will say and do anything to get a vote. After all, it is in their DNA.

Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health)
(4.50 pm): Queensland is Australia’s most decentralised mainland state. Unlike very large states such as Western Australia, we actually have people living outside the south-east corner and in major settlements up and down the coast and west of the Great Dividing Range. The story of Queensland has been the story of the development of logistics. It has been the story of airlines such as Qantas. It has been the story of the Royal Flying Doctors Service. It has been the story of Main Roads promulgating roads throughout the state. It has been the story of a rail network being rolled throughout the state in various places.
An honourable member interjected.
Mr LUCAS: I take the honourable member’s interjection. Yes, Australia National Railways was sold by a Liberal National Party government of which Tony Abbott was a member.

This depended upon people of foresight. Of course, in this country we have learnt the lessons of a lack of foresight, a lack of judgement and a lack of leadership at a federal level when it comes to logistics. We know, for example, that we have a broad gauge railway system in Victoria, a standard gauge railway system in New South Wales and a narrow gauge railway system in Queensland. At the time, New South Wales and Victoria were the only players in the game and Queensland did not count and went for the cheapest option. What was lacking at that point in time was any understanding that at a federal level they might have had responsibility for something like rail.

If rail was what happened in the 19th century, in the 21st century it has to be fibre optic. There is clearly a role for governments to deal with that, but more importantly for federal governments to deal with that.

The challenge in health is the challenge of distance as well. It is the challenge of how we might provide those services in a state that is very decentralised--not like, as the member for Currumbin says, Singapore which frankly is a city state. We are the opposite of that.
So it is not just about fibre going past people’s homes.
Mrs Stuckey: How about Tasmania, then? You can’t make it work in Tasmania.

Mr LUCAS: The population of Tasmania exists on the Gold Coast, I would remind the honourable member. It is not just about fibre going past people’s homes. It is what it allows them to do in terms of telecommuting. It is what it allows them to do in terms of seeking medical consultations. Not only did Julia Gillard say the other day that she will actually build on NBN to provide services as a result thereof but she will actually allow people to access health consultation at home on an after-hours basis using video streaming. That is actually about using it.

In terms of the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition in the debate tonight not only did he fail to articulate an alternative vision by stating what the opposition’s plan would be but he did not even say what it would do in the fibre network. Those opposite are not used to policy thought. The network is nothing if it does not have those things done on it that actually make a difference to people’s lives.

In fact, the federal opposition’s policy, I understand, is based upon a wireless rollout. Here we go. I can remember it. We have just got over the hump in terms of people fighting with federal governments with regard to telephone towers throughout their electorates and their streets. Coming to a suburb near you is the Tony Abbott inferior solution of telephone towers everywhere to give you sufficient density to allow you to rollout a broadband option. I look forward to the speeches in this House from people complaining about that and running a mile away from Tony Abbott’s policy point of view.

This is actually about what those opposite would do. It is about vision. They have no alternative vision either when it comes to rolling out the broadband--that is, the optic fibre spine itself--or what they want to do with it. As far as they are concerned, it is about emails. As far as they are concerned, it is about sending notes to their friends and that sort of thing. It is not actually about what services they can provide with it because they are not wired in that direction. They are not wired as to what they will do with those services they provide.

We are and we understand. One does not need to be an IT guru to do it. Frankly, one does not need to think in that way. What people need to do is think about the services they want to provide and what it could enable them to do. If people are in health that is what it enables them to do. If they are in commerce that is what it enables them to do. If they are in consulting that is what it enables them to do. We now know that with teleradiology people can read anywhere in the world an x-ray that is taken anywhere in Queensland that is part of our digital network. Those are the opportunities this offers us.

Those opposite will consign people in regional and rural Queensland to a life of penury.
