We know that one thing that people in rural and remote Queensland have been able to do, frankly--for example, with mining--is stay on the farm because they have been able to work in mines as well. What we will be able to do in the 21st century with a decent fibre optic network in this country is say to people in rural and remote Queensland, ‘You can keep that wonderful lifestyle that is the envy of people in the city and still have an opportunity to have a professional or other career at the same time.’
This is about actually using your brains to achieve anything. It is no wonder that those opposite are not capable of thinking of what this actually means in a policy sense. It is a very sad thing.

Ms SIMPSON (Maroochydore--LNP)
(4.55 pm): Remember when Labor and Kevin Rudd claimed to be economic conservatives? Well they dumped that pretence quicker than they knifed Kevin Rudd as Prime Minister. I never go into a shop without checking the price tag of what I buy. Price does affect my choices and determines the value of a product. I know that it certainly impacts on the choices of the residents of Queensland and certainly impacts on the choices of those who live in my electorate. It particularly impacts on the thousands of ordinary Queenslanders who do not have a government pay packet to rely on.

Why then does Labor want to keep it secret as to how much it will really cost Queenslanders to connect to its $43 billion NBN plan and how much it will cost people in terms of ongoing costs? We in the LNP are fighting for Queenslanders to have a fast, reliable and affordable internet service, not Labor’s proposal which is the world’s most expensive. There is no business case.

I heard Minister Schwarten bag the importance of having a business case just a few minutes ago. We think that a government that has sent this state broke in a boom should wake up to itself and realise that it does matter what we pay for our infrastructure because eventually people have to pay it back. And guess what? It is poor old taxpayers--the ones it treats like mugs--who have to do that.

Business cases do matter. This minister and the modern Labor Party still believe that they do not matter and they can force this cost upon people. It is embarrassing to see the abuse of power by this government and the way it spends billions and does not do a business case or a cost benefit analysis. Instead it is asking Labor members and other parliamentarians to turn off their brains and vote blindly in favour of the NBN and jump over the cliff like the proverbial lemmings who followed the leader without checking the direction they were going in. Doing that has a very high price.

Labor’s NBN is a new monopoly which Australians will pay more for in their taxes in access fees. The creation of a new telecommunications monopoly by Labor is not a virtue; it is a vice. It has been forced on people. In the days before Telstra was open to competition Australians paid some of the highest telecommunications costs in the world. Rather than taking us to the future, Labor intends to take us back to the past where government controls things by costly monopoly which is anti-innovation and is just jobs for boys. The government’s role should be to stimulate competition and ensure that where there is market failure people have access to services. It should not be, as Labor’s plan is, to strangle competition and remonopolise services with mandatory higher costs.

Do not forget that Labor’s NBN will be brought to us by the same mob who gave us Australia’s pink batt fiasco of burnt houses and, tragically, people who lost their lives as well as the school building rip-off. They now think they can build a more cost-effective internet service for the nation than the private sector. Well, pigs might fly! This is being endorsed by state Labor--this mob that went broke in a boom and then decided that it would help others go broke by putting up their taxes in an economic downturn.

We say that Australians have a right to know how much it will cost them individually, and certainly the residents of my electorate of Maroochydore want to know how much it will cost. We have heard that in Tasmania the expected connection cost is between $300 and $800. That is not to mention the ongoing operational costs. But, no, Labor does not want to talk about that individual cost to people. It wants that to be a secret. The NBN should be renamed ‘NOM’--‘not our money’, brought to you by Labor pollies on high salaries and their indentured help who forget that it is ordinary Australians who end up repaying that debt.

I also call on this Labor government to explain what happened to the other internet programs and Reef access that it was promising and access to some of the highest speed internet along the rail services in Australia--I table a number of clippings in relation to that--because we deserve to know what happened to these programs.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Bundle of documents, including newspaper articles and ministerial statements, relating to broadband cable [ 2774 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: When Telstra was being opened up to competition, Chris Griffith stated that that was good because it would be more competitive, more technologically advanced and cheaper for consumers. It did not rely on a platform of one provider!

Mrs KIERNAN (Mount Isa--ALP) (5.00 pm): I am very pleased--in fact, I am delighted--to say that Mount Isa is one of the very first beneficiaries of the Gillard government’s national broadband network. Along with Townsville, Mount Isa was chosen as the first place in Queensland to begin work on the NBN. Around 500 kilometres of optical fibre cable has already been laid from Mount Isa. This includes cable from the border to the Northern Territory and down to Winton. Eventually we will be a key point on the massive NBN cable running from Toowoomba to Mount Isa and on to Tennant Creek and Darwin. Mount Isa is proud to be such an early site for the NBN rollout. We are a perfect example of the great benefits that the NBN brings. The expression ‘tyranny of distance’ has always been particularly relevant to Mount Isa and the north-west, even though we are a world-class centre for industries such as mining.

With the NBN, Mount Isa can look forward to a revolution in e-business, e-learning and e-health, in employment and in opportunities for our children. We do business with the world and we want to be connected to the nation and the world. Further, Mount Isa and Queensland are very keen to get as many of the 25,000 jobs on offer as the NBN is rolled out over eight years. It would be a tragedy if these jobs were lost to Queensland because the federal opposition leader, Tony Abbott, scrapped the NBN.

Queensland is the most decentralised state in Australia, but we still want to steer more people towards our cities and towns in rural and regional Queensland. Many regional areas of Queensland have strong job opportunities--don’t we know it?--and a lifestyle that is the envy of the world. However, if the NBN is scrapped, decentralisation will be dead in its tracks. Few people will want to live in a broadband backwater where the digital world is passing them by. We need to get IT experts, doctors, lawyers, manufacturers and other leaders into our regions to revitalise them. But people will not come if we do not have high-speed reliable broadband. These people want to be connected to the nation and the world, not taken back to the era of the pedal wireless by Tony Abbott. I have to say that the pedal wireless was in fact discovered in Cloncurry in my electorate. They want top-class education, business, health and other services.

I notice that Prime Minister Julia Gillard has assisted this process this week in Brisbane by announcing a new Medicare rebate for online consultations. Other NBN benefits for regional Queenslanders include new trade opportunities and better communications; regional businesses can benefit from improved access to online services, including finance and banking, research and information; and regional companies can reach new trade partners and opportunities in Australia or across the globe.
The Queensland bush is crying out for the NBN. Just this afternoon I sat with the minister for communications, Robert Schwarten, and the member for Gregory--our good and great advocate for the bush--
Mr Johnson interjected.

Mrs KIERNAN: I take that interjection. We sat with the mayor of Barcoo, Bruce Scott, who gets 10 out of 10 for tech talk. Doesn’t he know his stuff? Rob Dare, the mayor of Diamantina, and others know about the great benefit of the NBN. Make no mistake about that. I ask LNP members if they will stop Cloncurry, Charleville or Charters Towers being connected to the NBN.
An opposition member interjected.

Mrs KIERNAN: There is no alternative, believe me. Will they doom Hervey Bay, Toowoomba, Roma, Warwick and 100 other regional centres to be IT also-rans? Never in a day! I note that Liberal MPs in Tasmania have told Tony Abbott to keep his hands off the NBN. According to the Courier-Mail of 24 July, a number of LNP members have broken ranks in Queensland--good on them--including a Senate candidate, the candidate for Dawson and members and candidates in Dickson, Groom, Ryan and Bonner. If all of these courageous people can put their constituents first, so can those opposite. Do it for the bush!

Mr HOBBS (Warrego--LNP) (5.06 pm): Queensland needs a fast, reliable, affordable broadband service. Queensland is a decentralised state with vast distances. We need a mix of optical fibre, of HFC, of wireless, of DSL and of satellite. We need an affordable and a fast network. We do not need a Labor BER $16 billion type broadband scheme where Labor wasted billions. We do not need a Labor home insulation $2.45 billion type broadband scheme that killed insulation workers and wasted hundreds of millions of dollars. We want a credible scheme, a genuine scheme and an affordable scheme.

Queensland Labor said, ‘Let’s build a water grid,’ and now we have the highest water prices in Australia. Labor said, ‘Let’s manage the electricity distribution system,’ and now we have the dearest electricity prices in Australia. We cannot trust it! Why would we want to put it in charge of broadband, for heaven’s sake? Haven’t we been burnt enough by those people over there and their federal colleagues in Canberra? Our AAA rating--gone under Labor! How on earth is it going to run a broadband service?

The coalition will deliver a broadband service sooner than Labor. In 2016 the coalition will roll it out--not 2018 as proposed by Labor. So we are ahead of Labor. Rural Queensland needs more wireless and satellite. It does not necessarily need the rollout of fibre-optic cables. The rollout at Scottsdale in Tasmania that has been talked about has shown that homeowners five kilometres out of town cannot get service, so how are people in Western Queensland going to get service if they are two or five kilometres away? So it does not always work, and it is dear. Rural Queensland will have to wait many years to get a fast broadband service from Labor under the NBN. The coalition will deliver it sooner--two years sooner, and to all of those towns.
Mr Shine: Rubbish!

Mr HOBBS: The honourable member says ‘rubbish’, but can you read, old son? Read the stuff that has gone out there. We will deliver these things. Let me tell the House all about it. We need wireless. We need satellite. The technology is improving. Twenty years ago we never had a mobile phone. In terms of the systems out there, the cabling is expensive. There are distance related expenses. Many areas use wireless because it is far more sensible and easier. My property in Western Queensland was one of the first to use a satellite internet connection. We have done away with that and are now using wireless connections because it is faster, more efficient and cheaper. I am sure that down the track even better satellite systems will be put in place. We want e-health for doctors to diagnose and treat patients remotely. While this is already happening now, a full rollout will happen faster under the coalition than Labor proposes in 2018. The coalition will deliver this two years sooner to all of those places.

Minister Schwarten, who co-installed the health pay system--do members remember him?--said that rural towns would miss out. Can we believe it? He wants to be in charge of rolling out this damn thing. He cannot even pay the nurses and he wants to roll out broadband! How bad is that?

The coalition is entirely committed. Some people are having difficulty reading. Let me tell members about the coalition’s plan to establish a national broadband commission that will be designed to manage the competitive selection process to select private sector companies, not a Labor run sister company to try to roll out this thing. We want to have private companies do this. That is sensible.

What about committing $2 billion in funding for a new fixed wireless broadband network? That is what we want to do. We want to improve the system. We want to make it better. We want to make it faster and roll it out to those areas that cannot get cable. Look at Birdsville. The people in that area are only just getting mobile phones today. They have finally come to Birdsville. But Labor is talking about rolling out hundreds of kilometres of fibre. They do not have to do it everywhere. We need a mix. We want to fund new satellite services for the remaining three per cent of the population who are not covered by other technology. There is going to be a system.

The coalition has promised that it will put in place a better system and a faster system than Labor will. The members opposite should get that into their heads. It is going to happen and it is going to happen after this coming Saturday.

Ms NELSON-CARR (Mundingburra--ALP) (5.10 pm): That was pretty incredible. It really was. We actually have another failed coalition policy. By not supporting the government’s superfast broadband for all Australians, will we see an NBN shutdown, 25,000 NBN jobs gone each year of construction, no guaranteed connections, no fibre optics to the home and, in fact, no structural reform to the telecommunications industry, per se. Abbott’s failed policy is a return to the bandaid era, where we will continue to be left behind. This short-sighted focus shows an enormous lack of insight and understanding in a possible Prime Minister. In fact, I think Abbott’s understanding is limited to shared access at home or an internet cafe where we can send or receive an email. If he had his way, Abbott would go back to horse-drawn carriages and pigeons.
Mr Hobbs: That’s not true.
Ms NELSON-CARR: Yes, it is true. The national broadband network had its genesis in Townsville--indeed, in my electorate of Mundingburra.
Mr Hobbs : We are ahead of you.

Ms NELSON-CARR: I say to the member for Warrego that the electorate is delighted to be part of much needed reform that only a government with courage and conviction to deliver affordable high-speed broadband to everyone can deliver.

Australia lags behind the developed world in internet speeds, and this scheme will provide speeds of up to 100 megabits per second to 90 per cent of the population. Even rural Australia is calling out for nation-building infrastructure. The New South Wales Farmers Association is supporting the nation-building development of the current NBN. It just is gobsmacking listening to you, member for Warrego.
Mr SPEAKER: It would be better to direct your comments through the chair.

Ms NELSON-CARR: Thank you, Mr Speaker. I am really horrified to think that Tony Abbott plans to scrap the NBN, taking regional Queensland backwards and costing jobs in my electorate. The Townsville suburbs of Aitkenvale and Mundingburra were announced as the first and only Queensland sites in the initial NBN rollout. Further to this there has been an NBN second site announcement, and Townsville has once again been flagged as the location to receive the progressive fanning out of services, which will provide another 3,000 connections to homes in my electorate.

With the announcement of Ergon Energy as the construction contractor for the passive optical fibre network, I expect about 80 to 100 new jobs to be created in the initial construction in the coming months. In fact, 3,100 premises in my electorate are eagerly signing off on fibre-optic connections into their homes as we speak. Yesterday, the Prime Minister herself was here to see the rollout in Aitkenvale.

As members have heard, Townsville is a fast-growing economic hub in North Queensland. So we need the very best high-speed broadband to match that growth. Let us face it: the future is digital and the national broadband network will bring us into line with our regional leaders of Singapore and Japan. The NBN will pave the way for Australian business, particularly regional businesses, to access the world quickly. Sending huge amounts of data will take minutes, not hours and high-definition conferencing will be available to all.

Australians live in a very decentralised country and we pride ourselves on our innovation and resourcefulness. We are at the forefront in so many areas, just not broadband. In fact, we are ranked 50th in the world--well below Japan but also behind New Zealand, South Korea and all of our regional competitors. My colleague the member for Capalaba says that one in four jobs in our state is in trade. Our trading partners China, Japan and Korea all have broadband speed. The NBN will cut travel time and cost by doing business online, rural health can have real-time consultation anywhere in Australia, telemedicine will save lives, remote monitoring will keep patients in their homes and, in education, virtual classrooms will mean so many greater options--networking possibilities, rapid access to data and so on.

Tony Abbott will destroy jobs and keep most Australians in the dark. The Gillard Labor government will take us into the future and we will not have time to look back. We need to take that into account on Saturday. We have too much to lose.

Mr HORAN (Toowoomba South--LNP)
(5.15 pm): It is time to stop these obscene multibillion dollar scams of the Australian tax-paying public that masquerade as political stunts and political schemes. The people of Queensland know what deceit and deception is and to see debt, interest and costs go through the roof. That is why they are going to vote against Labor this Saturday.

We now have another one of these schemes that has been brought forward by the Commonwealth government that will mirror what we have seen with the insulation debacle and will mirror what we have seen with some of the waste and corruption that has happened in the BER scheme. The coalition has come up with a plan that will give us fast-speed broadband two years before the completion date that has been put forward by the Labor Party. It will be fast, it will be efficient and, most importantly, it will be affordable. That is what Australians are looking for today. They have had enough of this obscene waste of their money masquerading as these political schemes.

The insulation scheme never had a chance of working. Someone just stood up in the federal parliament and said that they were going to insulate every house in Australia when they did not even have the practical common sense to know that there were not enough people trained to do it, that there were not enough pink batts and insulation to do it and that you could never do it in two years anyway. The consequence of this harebrained scheme was that four young men died and probably a whole lot of others were burnt, 96 houses were burnt down, $2.5 billion was wasted, electric wires were stapled to the roofs of houses and it will cost another $1 billion to fix up this rotten, obscene mess, this waste of the hard-earned money of the people of Australia. The scheme never had a chance. It was just a political stunt. If someone were sensible about it they might have said that they would do it over 10 years.

Now, another similar scheme has been dreamt up--a scheme that originally was going to cost $4.7 billion. It is now $43 billion--nearly 10 times more--and everybody in Australia, and particularly those of us in Queensland, who knows the track record of this Labor government would know that that $43 billion is peanuts compared to what it will eventually cost to have this federal government owned monolith that they want to, as Mr Schwarten said, sell to someone in the future. How are you going to sell something that is no longer contemporary, that has been overtaken by wireless or some other form or system, that is overcapitalised, that has no return and is just so cumbersome because it is ill thought out, it is not flexible and it is not contemporary? Once again, billions and billions of dollars that could have been spent on water supplies, hospitals, schools, roads, ports--on things that would give Australia something decent with which to work--will be wasted.

The waste of this federal government knows no bounds. There was the $900 that was handed out twice. Some sensible people put that money into their bank accounts. That did not help avert the global financial crisis. Some people put that money towards paying for their children’s school fees, but most people spent the money on poker machines and flat-screen TVs. The money went to Samsung in Korea and to Harvey Norman. The money went all over the world. It was an absolute waste of $22.5 billion that could have made real things happen in Australia that would have lasted forever. In the Depression the Sydney Harbour Bridge was built and that has been half handy ever since.

The waste that has happened with Building the Education Revolution is unbelievable. Contractors and subcontractors have been told what they can quote to. They could have given a price and made a good profit, but they knew that they could go to a higher price because the government wanted things built quickly. So they added a few more million on top and away that goes.

We have seen the debt and deceit in this state. The people of Queensland know that the harebrained schemes of this Labor government have led to massive cost increases in water, rego, petrol and gas. Mr Mike Kaiser was kicked out of this parliament for vote rorting. He went down to New South Wales and sent it broke. He then came back up here and made us broke. Now we will see him send the NBN scheme broke. He has a track record for that.

The scheme that has been put forward by the coalition is practical. It uses a number of options, including fibre, wireless, DSL and satellite technologies. It is programmed to have fast broadband to people two years before the Labor scheme. It is contemporary. It will allow for flexibility. Telstra has already said that in one year its wireless technology will be 84 megabytes per second. We are moving that way anyway. We will end up with big cables on the wires of the overhead powerlines disfiguring our suburbs at a massive cost and waste. It can be done faster, more efficiently and more reliably through the coalition at far less cost to individuals.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development)
(5.20 pm): I support the motion put by the Premier to this parliament. The parliament of Queensland, representing as it does the people of Queensland, should be rushing to support this motion and the rollout of game-changing, nation-changing, nation-building infrastructure like the NBN. Imagine if those myopic folk on the other side, as indolent as they are in this parliament to not put forward a single policy to the people of Queensland, were in charge of the future of this nation? What would have happened if this motley crew were running Brisbane when Clem Jones decided to sewer Brisbane? We would all still be in outhouses.

What would have happened if those opposite were in charge at the time when it was proposed to roll out electricity across the state of Queensland? As the OECD has noted in the past, back in the 1930s only 10 per cent of America was covered by electricity. By 1950 the coverage was universal. Imagine for a moment the nation-changing capacity that the NBN has in terms of radically changing the way the growth path of the economy of Australia moves. Imagine if we could harness the productivity-lifting power of an NBN providing for high-speed broadband to the people of Australia. What would that do? As has been commented on in the past, it has the capacity by and of itself to lift the productivity of the economy of the nation by more than one per cent. The benefits that flow have been well set out in this debate, whether it is about delivering e-health, telecommuting and the reduction in emissions that comes from that, or the lift in productivity that comes from a person’s ability to work across different time zones through the power of the internet and through the power of broadband. That is what should be the guiding light for those considering this motion here today. The proposal from this federal government is to put in place the economic infrastructure of the 21st century.

It is no mistake and there is no doubt or surprise that, pitifully, it is yet again the conservatives who are the great wreckers of the Australian economy. While we are the builders, they are the wreckers; while we are the ones who propose, they are the ones who oppose. The story of the development of this nation is the story of Labor governments which can actually look to the horizon. The story of the tories in this nation is to look straight in front of their face at what is in it for them. When it comes to the sort of nation-changing infrastructure that is proposed by the NBN, this state of all states, and those people who represent the more disparate parts of the state of Queensland in this parliament, should be the first to support the NBN. But of course they do not. They wanted to find a cheap line on day one. They have struggled ever since. Tony Abbott has contorted himself and wrung his hands over trying to come up with an alternative to the NBN. He never got it from the start. All he saw was a political line. What he has seen since then is, in fact, the harsh reality that this is the sort of investment in the 21st century that a state like Queensland should be welcoming and that a federal government in the nation of Australia at this point in time should be working hard to put in place. The reality, of course, is that it is these types of visions, these types of views to the future and this type of effort that has the capacity to radically change our growth profile and therefore the prosperity of the people of Queensland and Australia.

Imagine for a moment it is 80 years ago. I heard the member for Toowoomba South say that he does not want to see poles and wires across the nation. Imagine if that was the view at the time when we rolled out electricity. Those opposite would be happy sitting beside the crystal set, pedalling along, listening to Don Bradman score in the cricket. That is where we would stay. Of course, there is an ability to hope for so much more. There is an ability in this nation to look to the future. This is a debate that was had in this nation 100 years ago about railways. It is appropriate at this stage to have the debate about a national broadband network and to look at what a difference that can make. It has the capacity to game change the economy. It is entirely appropriate for the federal government to propose this infrastructure in the way that it has. On Saturday let us hope that the Australian Labor Party is once again given the chance to build the future of the nation. The nation will long be better off for it.

Mr NICHOLLS (Clayfield--LNP)
(5.25 pm): This afternoon in this debate we have heard it all, but to cap it off, to hear the Treasurer come in here and talk about the Labor Party building the future of Australia, the Labor Party having the financial wherewithal and the financial nous to deliver an outcome that is of benefit to all Australians, takes the cake. It is quite frankly unbelievable that the Treasurer even spouts those words, let alone believes them. I think the great worry for the people of Queensland is that he probably does believe them.

The members of the Labor Party are, of course, the great wreckers of the Australian economy. They are the people who took a $60 billion inheritance and turned it into a $24 billion debt that has not yet been repaid and for which there is no repayment plan. It is the Labor Party that introduced a resource super profits tax in order to try to con the people of Australia that they would be able to balance the budget. They are the people who rack up federally $100 million worth of debt each and every day, 365 days a year, on top of the $400 million each week that is being racked up in Queensland as we refinance $20 billion worth of debt this year alone. That is the economic record of the Labor Party in Queensland. That is the record of the Labor Party in Australia. It is a record that is sending businesses and individuals to the wall in Queensland in record numbers, as we discussed this morning. What does it want to do now? It wants to put another $43 billion on the taxpayers’ tick and drive more businesses to the wall, drive more personal bankruptcies and send more people broke as it goes about increasing taxes and charges, making the cost of living unaffordable and increasing the waste.

What we see today in this motion is not driven by any concern for the people of Queensland. It is not driven by any concern for the future of our education system. It is not driven by any concern to deliver better medicine to rural and regional Queensland. We know what Labor’s record on those particular issues is. We have the worst literacy and numeracy rates in mainland Australia. Labor has closed down hospitals in the bush and failed to deliver services. The moving of this motion tonight is an attempt by a discredited long-term state Labor government to prop up its equally discredited federal cousins. What we see here is the discredited hand of the former and disgraced chief of staff of the Premier, Mike Kaiser, earning his $450,000 for his paymaster Stephen Conroy. In the dying days of a desperate federal Labor government, this motion is floated to try to con Queenslanders into thinking Labor can and actually will deliver a national broadband network solution.

One has to ask oneself this question: if the solution was so good, if the plan is so wonderful, why did they knife the architect of it in the back just six weeks ago? The electorate in Queensland is wise to Labor’s tricks. As we always say on this side of the House, when it comes to Labor, do not look at what they say or promise; look at what they deliver. Talk is cheap over at Peel Street, talk is cheap in Sussex Street and talk is particularly cheap in the Prime Minister’s suite of offices in Canberra. Queenslanders should consider any promise regarding broadband made by Labor and measure it up against what it has delivered. In Queensland what has it delivered? The Traveston Dam: a failure. Today it was admitted by Minister Robertson that $400 million was wasted. Let us look at the Tugun desalination plant: $1.2 billion and still not working. Let us look at Airport Link: $47 million blown out to $260 million. The Queensland Health payroll system: not delivered. There is an ICT solution delivered by Labor! The Tugun bypass: $47 million. The CAMCOS blow-out: $2.2 million.

What about federal Labor? Why isn’t it talking about the home insulation program? We never hear about that in its ads. The school stimulus program provided $1.7 billion of identified waste to build glorified barbecue sheds. We have had FuelWatch, Grocery Choice, computers in schools, child-care centres--all those promises were ditched on the way through. The GP superclinics and, of course, the great moral challenge of our time, an ETS, do not get spoken about.

We need a fast, affordable and reliable broadband service. That is what is promised by Tony Abbott and the coalition. We need a government that knows how to deliver on its promises, not a government that continually promises. We need a government that has a plan to end the waste, a plan to repay the debt, a plan to stop the boats, a plan to stand up for families and a plan for real action for real Australians that is affordable.

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (5.43 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House recognises the importance of recreational and commercial fishing and associated industries to Queensland and opposes the secrecy of the deal between the Greens and the federal Labor Party that will close off a minimum of 30 per cent of Australian waters to fishing.
XML.Hansard-Body: This Saturday when we vote in the federal election we will not just be voting for representatives and a government way down south in Canberra. In this election, there are a lot of issues that will fundamentally affect Queensland and the lifestyle we enjoy. We all know about the Rudd-Gillard super mining tax in the last couple of months and how it would have destroyed, and may possibly still destroy, jobs and communities in Queensland and how it cost Kevin Rudd his job. Since then Julia Gillard, the Prime Minister, has done her best to keep her backroom deal with the big miners quiet. Of course, there are still questions to be answered by the Premier, who failed to come out and stand up for Queensland jobs even though we were asking about what projections had been done.

There is no doubt that this Rudd super tax would have cost many jobs and hit Queensland hard. We saw companies withdrawing their investments. Until there was a backflip by the three big companies after negotiating with the government, there was clearly disquiet throughout the economy and in Queensland, which along with Western Australia are the biggest two mining states.

But there is another very important issue that will also cost jobs and affect the lifestyle of tens of thousands of Queenslanders--that is, the deal to lock up vast areas of sea right along the Queensland coast that are now open to limited commercial fishing and to the public for recreational fishing. It is the sneaky preference deal that Bob Brown and the Greens have done with the ALP to get Julia Gillard and Labor over the line. This is the deal they have done that is just like the sneaky preference deal the Bligh Labor government did with the Greens on the eve of the last state election that has locked up vast areas of the cape and denied local Indigenous communities their right to self-determine and set their economic future.

I have spoken in this place before about having been in Mapoon where the Wenlock River has been subject to a recent declaration by the minister. Those communities are concerned about jobs and job opportunities for their children that have now been taken away from them due to the changes that have been made in the declaration by the Minister for Natural Resources. This deal will lock up 30 per cent of the areas along our coastline and Peter Garrett, the federal minister, has been out there spruiking it. This will destroy commercial fishing and unfairly restrict what is an essential part of Queensland’s way of life--recreational fishing, a healthy and enjoyable activity for generations.

The Greens like to make out that humans are not a part of the world’s environment, that they are actually intruding on it. That is wrong because we are a part of the world’s environment. They think we should be excluded from it. They prey on the worst fears of our children--and that is about the future, the future for our children. I am very confident in the future for our children, but the Greens like to demonise development and demonise many of the things that have made this country a great one.

There is no doubt that earlier generations--and even mine; I am a typical member of the post baby boomers generation--have taken the environment for granted without a lot of thought for managing our natural assets for future generations, but my children and others have taught me to appreciate that we need to protect our environment and manage our resources and our fishing areas sustainably. We do that but not everybody in the world does it.

Our fisheries are recognised internationally as amongst the best managed in the world. They are sustainably managed so that healthy, locally caught seafood can be enjoyed by Queenslanders and so that recreational fishing can be enjoyed by generations to come. This is done through common-sense bag limits and seasonal closures that I know are respected and observed by the overwhelming majority. In fact, the shadow minister for primary industries, the member for Condamine, and I regularly meet with primary industries groups who tell me about the standards that they have to uphold that are not upheld in other countries, and this is a classic example in fishing whether it is farm fishing or natural fishing.

Let us be clear about what is at stake here through Labor’s deal with the Greens, because if Green preferences get Julia Gillard and Labor across the line on Saturday Queenslanders need to be aware of all of the consequences not just for our economy or our jobs or for increased taxes and higher cost of living expenses, but also for our way of life. If Labor wins through Green support on Saturday, vast tracts of sea off the Tweed, the Gold Coast, the Fraser Coast and further north in the Coral Sea and the gulf will become out of bounds for commercial and recreational fishing. The effects will be devastating. The effects of this Labor-Greens deal will not just be felt on the cape like the wild rivers deal; they will be felt right the way along the coast. In my own area, I know of the cost to commercial fishing families. I know of the effect on the supply of fresh, locally caught, healthy seafood. I also know of the damage being done right along the coast and particularly up north.

A couple of months ago, I was in Cairns at a public housing development that the local community did not necessarily want. I spoke about this at length with a local resident and commercial fisherman, Bill Izard of Trinity Park, when I was at the Trinity Park development that the Cairns community does not want foisted on them. Bill Izard is the last trawler operator between Cairns and Port Douglas. He has been in the industry for 30 years. He operates a small, 30-foot boat. It is a pity that Bob Brown and the ALP do not bother to take the time to listen to local people in the industry and listen to what is really going on because they would then hear the truth about how bad their policies really are. They are not interested in how their policies will affect the people who are affected by them; they are only interested in how it will play into inner urban areas where people love the idea of voting Green as opposed to the major parties.

The lock-up of the Coral Sea is irrational. What the Greens and the ALP will do is lock up what is a deep water fishery that is currently fished sustainably by just four boats out of Cairns. They fish for deeper water pelagic fish. Let us be very clear about this: we are not talking about trawling the Coral Reef and taking reef fish viewed by tourists in glass-bottom boats and by snorkellers; we are talking about deeper water fish away from the reefs. Just four boats operate in the Coral Sea, as I have mentioned. They catch pelagic species on lines, not with nets. The species they catch include the migratory yellowfin, the bluefin and particularly the bigeye tuna, a valuable food and recreational game fish. This key point is being ignored, perhaps deliberately, by the Greens and Labor.

Just four boats using lines, not nets, take these fish in the Coral Sea off Queensland. Another key point is that these species are migratory--that is, they swim up and down the coast. They swim north, and once they move through the highly protected Australian waters of the Coral Sea they move on to New Guinea, where its government has sold licences to foreign fleet operators including big operators from the United States. These fleets are big and they use nets. Huge numbers are netted by these fleets and then taken to Thailand for processing, and we then buy tuna back from Thailand. What the Greens and Labor want to do is illogical. It has nothing to do with protecting our environment and saving our fish species.

Australia has the largest economic fishing zone per capita of any nation on earth. Our fisheries are already among the best, if not the best, managed of all fisheries in the world. Surely, if we are to be honest, if we are to be genuine about protecting the environment, we must also be genuine about protecting our ability to sustainably produce food in Australia and in Queensland. Where is the sense in the Greens and the ALP whipping up fear and hysteria and locking up 30 per cent of our oceans and, in so doing, destroying what is left of our commercial fishing industry and forcing our population to eat imported seafood, seafood that is increasingly being sourced from regions where there are few, if any, controls and the big trawls are anything but sustainable? People in the fishing industry tell me that places like Vietnam and other countries of Asia where they do this type of fishing have completely different standards from ours.

After all the shutdowns and lockouts that have already occurred, there are now probably fewer than 150 fishing boats still operating on the Queensland coast. Labor and the Greens want to shut these down further and force us to eat more imported seafood. That is not healthy, that is not sustainable and that is not caring for the environment.

On Saturday, I urge all Queenslanders to ignore the hysteria, ignore the untruths and reject Labor and the Greens, who will destroy our commercial fishing industry and further restrict Queenslanders from catching a few fish and enjoying a fresh, healthy meal with their mates and their families. What the Greens and Labor want to do is unfair. It flies in the face of the facts.

As I say, I do not believe that the people of Queensland and our children are not part of this environment. People need to look more at what the Greens are proposing. They want to reduce tax breaks; they want to remove capital gains tax concessions; they want to introduce an estate tax with provisions to protect the family farm, the family home and small business with a threshold of $5 million; and they want to abolish the private health insurance rebate. That is what members will not hear about the Greens. They are a danger to all modern-day Australians.

Mr HOPPER (Condamine--LNP) (5.53 pm): I rise to second this motion and speak about something very dear to the hearts and minds of many Queenslanders, including me, and that is fishing. Fishing is a part of the Queensland way of life. Whether it is outdoors on a river, in a tinnie on the bay, with a rod on the beach or out in a bigger boat, fishing is a part of life for all Queenslanders. However, this is under real threat this Saturday. It is under threat from Bob Brown and his crazy Greens supporters who want to lock up huge areas of our coast from fishing. This will destroy commercial fishing and wreck fishing for hundreds of thousands of Queenslanders and their families.

Bob Brown and Labor have done a sneaky preference deal. The big risk for Queenslanders who love fishing is Greens preferences. The current Gillard Labor government could well win government again. That is when Bob Brown and his crazies will demand their pound of flesh. That pound of flesh will affect the common person who wants to go and catch a fish. For Queenslanders who love fishing, that will mean that vast areas of traditional and much loved coastal fishing spots will be locked up from parents, their children and grandchildren. What are now open waters for families to enjoy will be locked up and no more fishing will be allowed.

If the Gillard government wins with the support of Bob Brown, it will also mean that our well-managed and sustainable local fishing industry will be further shut down and that more and more seafood will be imported, as our leader just spoke about, from foreign waters that are often already overfished--from seas and river farms with virtually non-existent hygiene and environmental standards. We had those standards in place in this nation, we had those standards in place in Queensland and because of a sneaky deal with the Greens we are going to see that totally eroded. We will see it totally eroded so that when a shopper goes into the supermarket she can only buy overseas products, which are not guaranteed to be clean.

I urge every Queenslander to think very carefully on Saturday and examine the policies of all the parties before casting their vote. The latest polls show that Bob and the Greens may account for 12 per cent to 14 per cent, which is an absolutely frightening thought for many of us and for me as someone who loves fishing and loves eating healthy seafood. Bob Brown and his supporters would have us believe that only they are concerned for the environment, that only they are concerned about climate change and that only they are concerned about sustainable fishing. I say to Senator Brown that, as a farmer on the Darling Downs and a landholder, I am very concerned about the environment. I am very concerned about how Labor has ignored the need to protect prime agricultural land. I am very concerned about how Labor has ignored the need to protect our water, our aquifers and our Great Artesian Basin. As a keen recreational fisherman, I am doubly concerned about how the Greens and Labor are planning to stop families fishing on the pretext of protecting the environment.

Bob Brown and the Greens are a pack of shysters. I strongly urge anyone who is contemplating voting green, especially for the Greens in the Senate, to look carefully at all their loony left policies, not just on fishing but also on so-called asylum seekers, free heroin trials--
A government member: What’s this got to do with fish?

Mr HOPPER: And members opposite have done a deal with them--carbon tax, company taxes and the lunatic industrial policies to abolish secondary boycotts. They are being backed by the left wing unions which are directly funding the Greens. I urge all Queenslanders to keep our waters open for fishing because they are already recognised as being among the best managed in the world. Say no to Bob Brown’s idiotic plan to shut down fishing. Say no to a sneaky plan with Labor.

There are 750,000 recreational fishermen in Queensland who love to fish and 30 per cent of our coastline is going to be locked up. We heard the member for Pumicestone going off her head last night. She should be out there against this, but she is very worried because her husband is going to lose his seat at five past 12 on Saturday night to one of the youngest, most vibrant politicians that this nation will ever see. That is why she was screaming out in this House last night. She is very concerned because her pay is going to be cut in half. Do honourable members know why he is going to lose his seat? Because he is married to a member of the Queensland Labor Party. He is married to a member of this government who has put policies in place and done deals with the Greens.
