• notes the Queensland Government’s support and promotion of sustainable recreational and commercial fishing in Queensland as outlined in the Queensland Fisheries Strategy 2009-2014;

• recognises that it is necessary to provide protections to habitats and breeding grounds for a long-term sustainable fishing industry in Australian waters based on the best scientific research and that such measures effectively increase fish stocks; and
• calls on the LNP to disclose what financial or in-kind (advertising) agreement they have with the Australian Fishing and Lifestyle Party.
XML.Hansard-Body: The motion before us tonight accuses the federal branch of the Australian Labor Party of doing a secret deal with the Greens. It is one of those ‘secret’ arrangements that the Australian Labor Party put out to the media. I recall very vividly--if my memory serves me right, it was 19 July, just two days after the election was called--that every major media outlet in this country covered the story that was out there from the Australian Labor Party. I heard people being interviewed about it and they went into some lengthy discussions. In fact, there were not just small news items; there were lengthy interviews with ministers and spokespeople like Chris Bowen. I would refer the members opposite to a Sky News interview held that day on the midday program. It went extensively into this issue.

So I think it bears absolutely no scrutiny to suggest that there is any secrecy about this. It is in fact a well-known, well-publicised, well-established fact that the Australian Labor Party has entered into an arrangement in relation to preferences with the Greens. That is what happens in a democracy. It happens all the time and every political party does it.

In my view, there is absolutely no secret about why a party like the Greens, which has a commitment to the environment, would choose to recommend to its supporters to preference their second vote to the Australian Labor Party. We are the party that has the record and the form on the environment. We are the party that is committed to meeting the challenge of climate change. The federal leader of the LNP, Mr Abbott, had to say about climate change that he believes it is absolute c-r-a-p.
Opposition members interjected.
Ms BLIGH: I did not say it; Tony Abbott said it. I am not prepared to repeat it on the parliamentary record although, as I understand it, Mr Abbott did.
Mr Knuth: He could be right.

Ms BLIGH: I take the interjection from the genius across there who has just backed up my allegations. Why on earth would the Greens ever contemplate giving a second preference to the Liberal National Party?

It is interesting to note where the allegiances are in the upcoming federal election. I think in the context of this motion tonight I need to draw to the attention of the House that there may be arrangements between the LNP and the Australian Fishing and Lifestyle Party in exchange for political advertisements that have not been disclosed in the public arena and have not been disclosed as they are required to be.

I have a document here which I will table in a moment. I would like to read it out for the benefit of the House. It is an email from Mr Peter Todd. Mr Peter Todd has sent this email which has been replied to by Mr Donald Jones, the chief executive officer of Marine Queensland. Mr Todd says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It’s been suggested that as the peak bodies representing fishers, and I emphasis united fishers, we should run a campaign in regional marginal seats for the last two weeks of the election leadup.
Our message could be with preference swaps a vote for Labor is a vote for the greens--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: and I think we might have just heard that story then--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: and this what they want to do; cut to Bob Brown saying they want to close 30% of Australian fisheries.
We then finish with the ramification of closures; no local fish for your fish and chips, no local prawns, etc accompany words with vision of Indonesian prawn farms.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: But then it says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The LNP are offering their ‘machine’ to get the ads to air on time. We need money from you three to get it going.
I’ll call each of you tomorrow.
XML.Hansard-Body: The LNP is offering the Australian Fishing and Lifestyle Party in-kind support to use its machine to get these ads to air. This has not been disclosed before. I table the document.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Email, dated 18 August 2010, in relation to a TV advertising campaign organised by the Australian Fishing and Lifestyle Party [ 2775 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: I am taking advice on whether this material is evidence of an arrangement that may in fact contravene the Australian Electoral Commission’s requirements. Do not come in here talking about secret deals. Every arrangement with the Greens has been fully disclosed, talked about by the Australian public, put out in the media. Everybody knows about it. Everybody is talking about it. It is no secret whatsoever.

What we did not hear from the member for Condamine was his dirty little arrangement that he uses the LNP machine to get the ads to air. Let us hear from the rest of the members of the LNP what their special relationship is. If it is all so good, why have you not been talking about it? You know that it is wrong.

Hon. TS MULHERIN (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland) (6.03 pm): I second the amendment moved by the Premier. We recognise that fishing is integral to the Queensland lifestyle and economy. In this year’s state budget the Bligh government invested $48.94 million in Fisheries Queensland. We understand the day-to-day challenges faced by recreational and commercial fishers, whilst the LNP and the coalition are merely using fishing as a political football. Every year almost a million people in Queensland fish for a living, for recreation or for traditional and customary purposes. Countless others rely on sustainable fisheries as the focus of tourism and other businesses.

Our fisheries resources are facing challenges such as the potential for overexploitation, increasing consumer demand for seafood, growth in coastal development and the effects of climate change. That is why the Queensland Fisheries Strategy 2009-2014 aims to ensure we derive the optimum economic, environmental and social benefits from Queensland’s fisheries resources. We are dedicated to supporting recreational fishing and protecting the fantastic way of life we enjoy by allocating $15 million per year to support recreational fishing. As part of an election commitment we have held 100 free fishing clinics for young people with a further 100 free fishing clinics being held over the next three years.

Commercial fishing plays a vital role in the Queensland economy. The gross value of production of Queensland’s commercial fishing sector is $275 million, with the total value chain estimated to be around $460 million. The Queensland industry accounts for approximately 17 per cent of the Australian commercial fishing industry. We continue to work with the commercial fishing sector every day to develop market opportunities. We are also working with industry to reduce the regulatory burden in the commercial fishing sector. We are also working with industry to improve efficiencies in both the commercial and the recreational sectors to foster sustainability along the whole supply chain. These are just a few examples of what the Bligh government does every day to support sustainable recreational and commercial sectors in Queensland. We care about the long-term prosperity of the industry and would not insult fishers by using the issue as a political football.

Meanwhile, the LNP and the coalition are waging a dishonest fear campaign on the future of commercial and recreational fishing in Queensland. Its scaremongering is deliberately misleading fishers and their families and causing unnecessary concern. The LNP and the coalition need to come clean about what financial or in-kind support they have given to the Australian Fishing and Lifestyle Party for advertising. How much of the $17,000 spent on the last two weeks advertising blitz in regional seats by the Fishing and Lifestyle Party did the LNP pay for? I note that Warren Entsch, the LNP candidate for Leichhardt, attended the campaign launch of the Australian Fishing and Lifestyle Party in Cairns last month.

While the ALP has been upfront, open and accountable from the outset with our Greens preferences, the LNP and the coalition are doing their normal thing--dodgy backroom deals with fishing parties to secure votes for the Senate. The LNP is offering its machine to get on air and speak against the review of the Commonwealth waters--a process that started under the Howard government. The Leader of the Opposition, Tony Abbott, acknowledged that the process started under the Howard government when he was in Mackay. Hypocritically, Mr Abbott also announced that his government would immediately suspend the marine protection process and would not make any declaration without further consultation. The average person on the street thinks there will be nothing more done.

The Gillard government has already committed to extending the process to allow further consultation with industry, fishers and other users. In true LNP and coalition form, Mr Abbott has offered no alternative plan for the industry. He has only offered to suspend the consultation process which is underway. I fail to see how suspending the consultation will leave industry informed and reassured about the process. It would leave the industry in limbo and leave fishers with more uncertainty. While the coalition and the LNP continue to alarm and misinform the industry and recreational fishers, it is evident that the Bligh government supports commercial and recreational fishing and its economic, environmental and social benefits for Queensland.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP) (6.08 pm): I support the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition. With a federal election literally upon us, it is unforgivable that federal minister Peter Garrett refuses to reveal what his Labor government plans to do about recommendations in the marine bioregional planning process. He has sat on this report for some nine months. An election campaign period is the proper time to advise all of us whether Labor intends to lock up fishing waters around Australia. Failure by Labor to reveal its plans must be condemned at the ballot box next Saturday. Considering that Labor has been given preferences by the Greens yet again the whole deal smacks of Peter Garrett doing an Anna Bligh.

Only 18 months ago Premier Bligh put her hand on her heart and said, ‘You can count on me.’ As a result of doing deals with the Greens, once she won government it did not take long for legislation to be urgently rolled out to pay back the Greens and it also did not take long for the Premier to announce that she would sell off Queensland’s assets, much to the horror and outrage of the majority of Queenslanders. By contrast, the coalition has been upfront supporting a balanced approach to marine conservation. It was in fact the Howard government that commenced the process of establishing marine protected areas around Australia’s coastline, so do not take the moral high ground on the environment with us! Obviously Labor has no intention of engaging in extensive consultation, which is what the coalition has committed to in the past and has committed to once again for this election. Tony Abbott said that the coalition will put a halt to announcing any more of these marine protected areas until the process of thorough and extensive consultation takes place.

One should not underestimate the recreational aspect of fishing. It is the No. 1 lifestyle pastime of Australians and many believe it is their right to be able to cast a line. In my local area residents have deep concerns about Labor’s intentions for the coastal area from Tweed Heads to Byron Bay. Tweed Heads and surrounding towns rely heavily on fishing and its associated activities. In this area alone thousands of people depend on fishing for their livelihoods, as the activity employs people across a wide range of industries--from the obvious like commercial fishing to retail, tourism, charters and boat building. At a rally at Tweed Heads attended by several hundred concerned residents last Saturday, people expressed their very real fears that their livelihoods will be destroyed with the stroke of a pen, that their industry will be decimated and that they will not be able to pay their mortgages or their weekly grocery bills. Labor’s failure to come clean is putting a huge number of people under intense stress that is completely unnecessary and downright deceitful. The emotion and anger last weekend was palpable. So much for jobs, jobs, jobs!

Labor pretends to stand up for the worker, but that is only if you are in a union that fills the election campaign coffers! Too bad if you work for yourself or if you fish for a living! A coalition federal government will immediately put on hold these processes to restructure it so it will deliver a bigger, better, fairer say for recreational and commercial fishers and associated industries in all stages of the process. Importantly, new bioregional advisory panels will be appointed for each marine bioregion to provide the vehicle for this expanded industry and community consultation. In line with pre-existing coalition policy and practice, the coalition will genuinely seek to minimise socioeconomic impacts of marine protection areas. In those situations where consultation and negotiation cannot reduce the impacts of the proposed MPAs below levels that are reasonably compensable, compensation, structural adjustment or other appropriate measures will be delivered before any constraints are implemented.

Labor’s marine bioregional planning process is secretive and skewed towards satisfying extreme Green groups. Whilst the coalition is determined to give fishers a fairer go, the Greens policy supported by Labor to ban fishing in a minimum 30 per cent of all Australian waters would literally cripple the nation’s seafood industry. Many say this would only be the tip of the iceberg before a larger percentage of Australian waters are claimed. People from the Queensland Seafood Industry Association acknowledge that this policy will close down the Queensland and Australian seafood industries at a time when there is a rising demand for seafood and simply encourage overseas production and more imports. Australia has high food safety practices. These are not employed by some other countries and there is every chance an inferior product would be on our shelves. On 21 August we must vote down--
Mr HOOLIHAN (Keppel--ALP) (6.13 pm): So much for the belt around the head with the wet lettuce leaf from the member for Currumbin!
Opposition members interjected.

Mr HOOLIHAN: It may interest those people with shell-like ears on the opposite side of parliament that in 2003 when dealing with Queensland fisheries the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority locked up 33 per cent of the Great Barrier Reef in green zones and our fishing industry was going to collapse. Surprisingly, the federal government at that time was the Liberal Party and it was in agreement with it--it was by negotiation--and today those green zones are working. In speaking to the amended motion, one issue that gets totally overlooked is that the Labor Party has a better environmental platform than any other party and there is no need to enter into any deals in relation to the closure of waters with the Greens. Certainly there is a preference deal, but by the same token we heard about the preference deal with the Australian Fishing and Lifestyle Party. Let us ask those opposite to put up their hands as to whether or not they endorse that.

One of the issues that should be put before this House is the Queensland government’s support for both recreational and commercial fisheries. Over three years there will be an investment of $34 million in constructing new pontoons, floating walkways and boat ramps and improving safety and access. In my electorate alone there will be a new boat ramp at Coorooman Creek, a floating walkway at Rosslyn Bay Boat Harbour, and another boat ramp will be completed with a floating walkway within the next 12 months.
An honourable member interjected.

Mr HOOLIHAN: I reckon I can do pretty well with the member for Coomera. When you throw out a line with bait on it, he bites every time. As I said, there will be a new boat ramp and floating walkway constructed within the next 12 months. One issue that should also be taken into account is that earlier this year there was a stock status report released showing strong results for fisheries in Queensland. A new traffic light system was applied and it showed that Queensland fish stocks and fisheries management reform was in good form when approximately 25 per cent of the world’s fish stocks are either overfished or depleted. We heard about pelagic fish where tuna in the Mediterranean and the Atlantic is almost fished out.

Under the new traffic light system, 62 Queensland fish stocks were considered and 47 have been put through rigorous scientific assessment. Only the snapper stock received a red light. Stock assessment shows snapper at less than 35 per cent of its unfished levels, and it is internationally recognised that fish stocks at 40 per cent or less of their unfished levels are classified as overfished. In actual fact, in Western Australia snapper is also overfished and closures are in place for several months at a time and there are limits on total annual take. A recovery strategy is also being developed in New South Wales to address the overfished status of the snapper stock. So perhaps if parts of Australian waters are closed off for any period of time it is in the interests of increasing fish stocks. The whole approach to fisheries in Queensland has been on the basis of scientific data. Of 61 fish stocks, 21 Queensland fish stocks were being sustainably fished, three were considered not fully utilised, 25 species fall into the yellow light category--which is listed as uncertain--and there is no assessment of 15 fish stocks. We heard the complaints about locking up waters for recreational and commercial fishing. They are not locked up. They will not be locked up, other than in relation to sustainable fishing.
An opposition member interjected.
Mr HOOLIHAN: You can have a look at the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park green zones yourself. Obviously you know nothing about them, so why call out about them?

Dr ROBINSON (Cleveland--LNP) (6.18 pm): I support the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition. Recreational and commercial fishing and its associated industries are worth a great deal to Queensland and Queenslanders. Hundreds of millions, perhaps billions, of dollars of investment and thousands of jobs exist in the industry and allied industries. Fishing is an important industry that in Queensland has continued to flourish in contrast to the problem of overfishing that exists in other parts of the world. Fishing is an important industry and leisure activity in my electorate of Cleveland, as it is in many other parts of coastal Queensland.

Many bayside residents on the mainland and on the islands of Moreton Bay own boats and fish. Many of those boaties and fishers in recent years have become disturbed by the trend under Labor governments to close off areas from fishing without the demonstrated need to take such harsh measures. This Saturday, Queensland boaties and fishers will be faced with the stark choice: to vote for a federal Labor-Greens alliance that has a plan to close at least 30 per cent of Australian waters to fishing or for the LNP and sensible fisheries management.

Since entering this House I have consistently spoken out about the dangers posed by the Greens-Labor alliance upon recreational and commercial fishing in Moreton Bay. Whether it is the overall failure of state Labor’s approach to the Moreton Bay Marine Park plan, the joke of the government’s approach to artificial reefs, the sending of the Tiwi Pearl --aka the SS Minnow --into a storm and losing control of its resting place, the incomplete rollout of the boundary markers for the Moreton Bay zoning plan, or the banning of inverted crab dillies based on one turtle death in five years, I have consistently pointed out that the Labor-Greens alliance has lost its way when it comes to fisheries management. It sends shivers down the spines of boaties and fishers to think that, should Julia Gillard win the election on Saturday, a similar approach to Labor’s failed formula for Moreton Bay is going to be rolled out across Australia by a federal Labor-Greens alliance.

I am deeply concerned about the Labor-Greens 30 per cent closure plan for several reasons. I am extremely concerned about the secrecy surrounding the decision. Instead of putting a detailed plan out to the public, Minister Garrett has kept the details secret until after the election. It can mean only one thing: that there is a lot of devil in that detail. They cannot be trusted. Secondly, I am concerned that Labor, under the influence of the extreme Greens, have created an imaginary problem--that overfishing is rife in Queensland waters--and then devised desperate measures to protect the last few remaining fish when, in fact, the recent Queensland fish stock status report states that only one of 64 species in Queensland, snapper, is at risk of overfishing. But Labor governments, dependent on green preferences to remain in power, have blown out of all proportion the level of risk to our fisheries. Whatever happened to the old adage ‘If it ain’t broke, don’t fix it’?

I studied marine science at James Cook University and since that time I have noted that two kinds of marine science exists. There is the approach that believed that Australian fisheries were broken and needed fixing. Back in the eighties, some of those false prophets of doom predicted that many Australian fishes would not exist by the year 2000. They were clearly wrong. Then there were those who based their views on hard fisheries data and held the informed view that fish stocks regularly come under pressure but, if fisheries are well managed, commercial and recreational fishing does not pose a high level of risk to their viability.

It is clear today that federal and state Labor governments have been listening exclusively to the prophets of doom. Like the clucky luckys of this world, they are always thinking that the sky is falling in. They continue to falsely believe that the fish stocks are in such decline that the only solution is to close off huge areas of fishable ocean. This is clearly misinformed and wrong.

Thirdly, gone are the days when Labor had men who were prepared to stand up for the right to fish. Men such as Tom Burns are well and truly gone from this place. Tom Burns was once seen by anglers as a political patron saint, even calling his boat the Electorate . He had his finger on the pulse of fishing. How things have changed since the green algal bloom has beset Labor.

I am also concerned that common sense has gone by the wayside in such Labor governments. One of the best examples of crazy extreme green science was the banning of inverted crab dillies based on one turtle death, as regrettable as one turtle death is. What a ridiculous decision. The Greens have espoused different positions--three of them. Which one will Bob Brown push on to Garrett this weekend? In conclusion, the answer to the Labor-Greens fishing dilemma is a vote for the federal coalition and for a sound fisheries management strategy.

Ms JARRATT (Whitsunday--ALP) (6.23 pm): The pastime of fishing is as Australian as eating meat pies. Most of us have childhood memories that involve fishing. Mine include learning to thread a worm on a hook and bobbing a cork attached to a fixed line over a muddy waterhole in the local creek. We caught yellow belly and jewfish, but I never did grow to enjoy the muddy tasting flesh. I have become much more partial to eating the wonderful array of seafood that comes from our oceans and I have a particular liking for butterfly filleted whiting, crumbed and deep fried. We all love to eat seafood. So the notion that any Australian government would attempt to stop people fishing, as I have heard claimed by that thinly disguised offshoot of the National Party, the Fishing and Lifestyle Party, is hysterical scaremongering to say the least. Make no mistake: the claims made here today by the LNP are nothing more than a political smokescreen to scare the voters. I have seen it all before and by my reckoning Ronny Boswell owes his seat in the Senate to the work of the Fishing Party when it mounted a similar scare campaign at the 2004 election.

So what are the facts around the federal government’s plans for our fisheries? Minister Mulherin hit that nail on the head yesterday in his answer to a question without notice when he reminded us that it was the Howard government that initiated the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and began the investigations into the Commonwealth’s bioregion program. And why would it do this? What possible motivation would it have for interfering with our God-given right to throw a line in wherever and whenever we want? If members have ever travelled to Asia, they might know the answer. Our fish stocks simply could not sustain unregulated harvest. As the world’s population grows and as demand for fresh seafood becomes insatiable, steps simply had to be taken to ensure that we in Australia establish a sustainable wild fishery. Yes, there has been some pain associated with reducing the commercial fishing and trawling fleet and learning to abide by bag and size limits, but the truth is that we needed to put some limits in place to protect the viability of our vulnerable fish stocks.

I have no doubt that the monitoring of our fisheries will continue--and so it should--and, where necessary to promote sustainability, I support additional regulation of our fisheries. But I am disgusted by the scaremongering and outright dishonesty that has been peddled by the Fishing and Lifestyle Party and the LNP for base political purposes. Here is what Peter Garrett has to say about the Commonwealth government’s intention for fisheries management--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... the key thing to understand about the planning processes the Government has in place in relation to future marine protected areas is this--it is a process which requires significant consultation with communities and with fishers and that consultation process is underway. It is a process that identifies Areas for Further Assessment and that is the stage that we are at now, where we are drawing more information, more data and more science into our considerations. And most importantly of all, the marine planning process is intended to balance the needs of those communities of users, including fishers, with the need to protect the environment in the long term.

I am absolutely confident that we can reach the right balance in that process. I don’t expect there to be a process which is rushed. I want a process which happens drawing on good science--not one which is politicised by our political opponents who run around claiming that the sky is going to fall in as a consequence of a marine planning process.
XML.Hansard-Body: So there it is from the mouth of Minister Garrett. So let us have an end to the hysteria and dishonesty. Only an incompetent government would ignore the need to protect the sustainability of our fisheries. John Howard did not do this and Peter Garrett has not done this and even Mr Abbott has rightly committed to continue the consultation process that has been established by Garrett. Here is what Peter Garrett had to say about the claim that he has done a secret deal with the Greens to shut off 30 per cent of Australian waters to fishing--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... there is no intention on the part of the Government to set arbitrary limits in terms of a planning process.
Senator Brown might make ambit claims of some figure or other, that too is a completely unproductive contribution to what is a very important, rigorous and balanced process.
XML.Hansard-Body: Tonight, I support the amended motion as moved by the Premier. As a member who represents an area that supports both commercial and recreational fishing, I am proud of our role in the protection of our unique reef fishery. Our actions mean that some areas are out of bounds to fishers and at some times of the year certain fish are off the menu, but ultimately this means that there will be fish in our sea when my great-grandchildren dangle their fishing lines in the water.

Mr CRIPPS (Hinchinbrook--LNP) (6.28 pm): When the people of Australia found out in mid July that the Gillard Labor government and the Greens had entered into a preference deal for the coming federal election, many started to get concerned about what Labor had promised the Greens in return for their preferences. It is no surprise that the disconcertedness and the deep sense of foreboding has been the most acute in Queensland, because many Queenslanders were suddenly struck by a terrible sense of déjà vu. It was as if the story of the last Queensland state election was repeating itself. Just as the Bligh Labor government struck a preference deal with the Greens before the last state election, the Gillard Labor government has now struck a preference deal with the Greens ahead of the coming federal election. I represent the electorate of Hinchinbrook in North Queensland and North Queensland has suffered badly after the re-election of the Bligh Labor government, with the implementation of the policies that were part of its deal with the Greens in return for their preferences.

In North Queensland Labor has extended the wild rivers declarations across vast tracts of Cape York Peninsula. It has introduced the so-called reef protection regulations that are set to keep canegrowers and graziers filling out paperwork for several hours a day without any justification instead of undertaking basic farming activities. Labor has also introduced a ban on the management of regrowth vegetation and created buffer zones that will result in lost production.

All of these new layers of regulation and red tape have come in in North Queensland within 12 months of the last state election because the Bligh government did a preference deal with the Greens. North Queensland will again be in the firing line if the Gillard Labor government is re-elected and the terms of its preference deal with the Greens are implemented. Now that the Gillard Labor government has done a deal with the Greens, what can we expect in the 12 months after the coming federal election? We can certainly expect that the Labor-Green alliance will force through an emissions trading scheme. We can also certainly expect that the Labor-Green alliance will impose a super profits tax on the mining industry.

But the Labor-Green alliance will not be content with targeting our major industries with new taxes. Tonight’s motion focuses on the fact that the Labor-Green alliance is also looking to impose restrictions on one of the iconic aspects of our lifestyle in North Queensland with the proposal to turn one million square kilometres of the Coral Sea into a no-take marine park and around Australia close off a minimum of 30 per cent of Australia’s waters from all types of fishing, both recreational and commercial. These so-called bioregions have been developed and extended out of the declaration of the Coral Sea Conservation Zone by the federal Labor environment minister, Peter Garrett, who took this extraordinary decision following lobbying from the American based Pew Environmental Group.

I heard the Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland in question time here yesterday claiming that these no-take zones were being developed through a consultation process with stakeholder groups. That is a breathtakingly dishonest statement because the Coral Sea Conservation Zone was declared without any impact statement. It was declared without any consultation and without any scientific process. The federal Labor government completely capitulated to the demands of a foreign lobby group and announced the establishment of a massive conservation zone in the Coral Sea off the coast of North Queensland. Minister Garrett arrogantly imposed the Coral Sea Conservation Zone on North Queenslanders without even pretending to consult with us. The claim by Minister Mulherin that there has been consultation is fraudulent and fabricated.

The rights and interests of commercial fishing families, of charter boat operators and of everyday Queenslanders to pursue that most simple of recreational activities--going fishing--have been completely sold out. The future of businesses attached to commercial and recreational fishing, such as bait and tackle shops, boat retailers, seafood wholesalers and retailers, restaurants, fish and chip shops that prefer to serve quality, domestically sought seafood and the tourism industry that are critical for North Queensland’s economy, have been compromised by the Labor-Green alliance.

It is a disgrace that the Bligh Labor government has proven itself to be the lackey of the Gillard Labor government. Labor MPs ought to be ashamed of themselves for selling out their constituents. North Queenslanders have seen the obscene results of the preference deal between the Bligh Labor government and the Greens at a state level. I shudder to think what North Queenslanders will be subjected to if the terms of the preference deal between the Labor government and the Greens at the federal level are implemented after this weekend. This weekend North Queenslanders will tell the Labor candidates in North Queensland what they think of their capitulation.

Hon. KJ JONES (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability)
(6.33 pm): I rise to support the amendment moved by the government tonight. The Bligh government is getting the balance right when it comes to protecting our unique marine environment while supporting sustainable fishing and recreation along Queensland’s coastline. This strong and clear articulated vision is in stark contrast to the contradictions that we see time and time again from those opposite.

While the LNP opposition here in Queensland wants to throw out the rule book and let uncontrolled fishing drain our waters of fish for the future, we know that a sustainable industry means a thriving and surviving industry. That is why my ministerial colleague the Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland released the Queensland Fisheries Strategy last year. It aims to ensure that we derive the optimum economic environmental and social benefits from Queensland’s fisheries resources.

Our fisheries resources are facing challenges, such as the potential for overexploitation, increasing consumer demand for seafood, growth in coastal development and the effects of climate change. We recognise that these are challenges that the industry faces and we are taking action. We have a plan. Tonight we heard the member for Currumbin boast in her contribution about the 30 per cent closure introduced by the Howard government, yet the rest of those opposite denied it. What is their position? The member for Currumbin was telling us not to get excited over here because they were the ones who introduced that. The rest of the LNP was saying that it was bad policy and should not have been implemented. Where do they stand? I guess it depends on which member one talks to.

The member for Cleveland in his contribution talked about the phony science behind green zones and the fact that they do not work. I want to put on the record tonight his total disregard for any turtle dying in Moreton Bay. That is in stark contrast to the crocodile tears we see consistently from the member for Noosa, who, as the shadow minister for climate change and sustainability, is someone who is meant to care about the environment and who did not bother to make a contribution tonight.

Let us have a look at the independent science in relation to green zones and how they work--the bioregions that the member for Currumbin boasts about and the rest of them deny have any effect. The CSIRO in its latest research has found between four and 11 times more legal size male mudcrabs in sanctuary zones. Fish catch rates have also shown similar trends, with many more legal size fish in these sanctuary zones. These were the first results from a five-year scientific monitoring program in Moreton Bay by research partners including the CSIRO, the University of Queensland and Griffith University. The evidence continues to get stronger. I am pleased to inform the House tonight that the most recent results from the study of the green zones, which have been in place for just over a year, show that mudcrabs from this area are already larger and more abundant than they are in the adjacent non-green zones. Data is also indicating that certain fish species are becoming more abundant in new offshore green zones around Henderson and Flat Rocks.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Stop the clock. I will wait for the House to come to order. There is an awful lot of biting going on.

Ms JONES: The fish are biting tonight. We have exposed just how fraudulent the argument of those opposite is. They are the ones who came into this House and pretended that there was some secret deal between the Labor Party and the Greens. The first sentence from the member for Hinchinbrook started with the words ‘in July’. What is the date today? That is right; it is halfway through August. The contribution from the member from Hinchinbrook was, ‘The secret deal which was revealed in July.’ Wake up, Australia!

Every single contribution from the LNP tonight--one after another--has actually undermined the motion it has moved in the House. The reason that is the case is that those opposite do not believe the motion before the House. This is simply base politics. The only revelation we have had tonight is the revelation by the Premier that the LNP was the one with the secret deal which actually probably contravenes the Electoral Act. Tonight, once again, the LNP has not been open and transparent. The LNP does not want to see a sustainable fishing industry, in contrast to the Bligh government’s planned approach, which is working with industry. The LNP has to resort to dirty political tactics because it has no policy, no plan and no vision for the future of Queensland. It is a shambles.

XML.Hansard-Body: Motion, as agreed--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House recognises the importance of recreational and commercial fishing and associated industries to Queensland and:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • notes the Queensland Government’s investment of $34 million over three years to construct new pontoons, floating walkways and boat ramps and improve safety and access for boaties and fishers;
• notes the Queensland Government’s support and promotion of sustainable recreational and commercial fishing in Queensland as outlined in the Queensland Fisheries Strategy 2009-2014;

• recognises that it is necessary to provide protections to habitats and breeding grounds for a long-term sustainable fishing industry in Australian waters based on the best scientific research and that such measures effectively increase fish stocks; and
• calls on the LNP to disclose what financial or in-kind (advertising) agreement they have with the Australian Fishing and Lifestyle Party.
XML.Hansard-Body: Sitting suspended from 6.46 pm to 7.45 pm
Ms SIMPSON (Maroochydore--LNP) (7.45 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That subordinate legislation No. 100 of 2010, Transport Legislation (Fees) Amendment Regulation (No. 1) 2010, tabled in the House on 8 June 2010 be disallowed.
XML.Hansard-Body: This disallowance motion concerns a number of provisions within the regulation but particularly the Transport Operations (Road Use Management--Vehicle Registration) Regulation 1999. While this regulation covers about 16 acts, it is the nature of parliament that under the rules we do not have an opportunity to amend regulations or move a disallowance against a portion of a regulation. Therefore, it is important that we bring this matter before the House.

We have heard how Queenslanders are hurting from the high costs of living and we have listened. That is why we are calling for a freeze on registration hikes, which is LNP policy, and we are giving the Labor government a chance to do the same and reject the latest increase. The question is this: is this Labor government willing to listen and respond to the pain of Queenslanders who are really struggling with the high costs of living? That struggle has been added to by the fact that over the past couple of years this Labor government has increased vehicle registration costs by up to 27 per cent. Two hundred thousand Queenslanders have signed two petitions calling for relief from this registration hike.

I call on the government to freeze vehicle registration charges, to listen to the people of Queensland and to understand that what is occurring in Queensland has resulted from a government inflicted downturn being felt by many businesses. This morning we heard how the number of failing Queensland businesses is significantly higher than in the rest of Australia. Queensland is bearing the burden of a government that has put up costs beyond the other states of Australia. Queenslanders cannot pay for this cumulative impact, which is reaching into their pockets and causing real hardship. It is time for Queensland motorists to have relief rather than rebuff from this government. I am calling on the government to listen to the people. They are hurting, and a lot of that hurt is the result of a range of costs that have been imposed through this government’s decisions and directly through higher taxes and charges.

In the past two years we have seen the cost of registration go up by up to 27 per cent. This regulation also brings significant increases to heavy vehicle registration and those costs are passed on, through business, to consumers. As I said, it is LNP policy to freeze vehicle registration charges in our first term and give people relief. However, tonight Labor has the opportunity to hear the message of the people and also freeze registration price increases. In that way, it can make up for what it has done in regard to the other taxes and it can start to listen to the people.

This government went to an election promising not to get rid of the fuel tax rebate. It broke that promise and now Queenslanders are paying more than $500 million out of their pockets for that petrol tax.

We have also seen this government significantly increase the tolls on the motorways. That is having an impact on pensioners, people who work and commercial businesses, some of whom have found that their costs on the motorways have gone up by 350 per cent. So the government needs to listen to the people. There is an opportunity to stimulate the economy in Queensland by listening to the people and not burdening them with these accumulative increases in costs.

The RACQ estimated that the average Queensland motorist was paying up to $220 more this year as a result of the petrol tax, increased registration fees and toll fees being forced upon them. There is an opportunity for the government to redress this or it could once again ignore the will of the people. I want to remind government members of some of their own promises. We heard that they have broken their promise in regard to the petrol tax. Queenslanders have now had that fuel tax rebate taken away from them, and the imposition of that tax has flowed through the economy and has had a significant impact. When state Labor government members were talking about the first increase in registration fees, they did not come out publicly and say what they were going to do with that money. Publicly they tried to say that they would put that increase into roads. I want to table a letter signed by the Treasurer, Andrew Fraser, on 8 December 2008 which puts the lie to that claim that it was all about money going back into roads.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr O’Brien): Order! Member for Maroochydore, that word is unparliamentary and I ask you to withdraw.

Ms SIMPSON: I withdraw. This puts a focus on the extreme falsehood and determination of this government to mislead the people of Queensland. This letter from the Treasurer reveals that the money was not going back into roads. The letter is to the main roads minister at the time, Warren Pitt, outlining what the government was actually going to do with the money from that registration hike. He wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Further to that advice, I can inform you that CBRC has also agreed to increase motor vehicle registration fees by 20 per cent from 1 July 2009 with the revenue derived from the increase to pass fully to the Consolidated Fund and not to the Department of Main Roads as currently occurs.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I table that letter.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Letter, dated 8 December 2008, from Hon. Andrew Fraser MP, Treasurer, to Hon. Warren Pitt MP, Minister for Main Roads and Local Government, in relation to allocation of revenue from motor vehicle registration fees [ 2776 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Government members tried to keep this myth going that it was all about increased funding going to roads, but we saw in the budget this year that road funding for the state of Queensland was slashed by $250 million, not increased. They cannot lie straight in bed in regard to what they tell the public and in regard to their promises before the election about taxes and what whey do afterwards. We want to see some honesty and we also want to see some relief for those who are hurting the most. People really are hurting with the accumulative impact of the government’s costs on them. The sticky fingers of the government keep dripping into their pockets and ripping out their last dollar.

I also mentioned the truck registration hikes which are flowing through. These come on top of another increase, which is in fact the increase in the fuel excise which adds 9c a litre. The decision of the transport ministers throughout Australia to agree to this truck registration hike has meant that, firstly, this huge increase will flow on to consumers and, secondly, an unintended impact may be that it is more likely that people will go away from some of the more efficient combinations--
Mr Rickuss: We are so diversified in Queensland also.

Ms SIMPSON: That is right; Queensland is diversified. There is a real likelihood that, because it is in fact favouring other combinations, we will see an increase in the number of trucks on the road, not a decrease, as people opt to go for a combination that cuts their registration fees but makes a bigger impact on our roads due to the fact that you cannot move that amount of freight with the B-double combinations under this current cost. There is a real concern that this move has not taken into account the unintended consequences in that it actually discourages some of the more efficient combinations.

I call on the minister to heed the concerns of Queenslanders about this particular impact. While there is a place for appropriate national regulation, ultimately and firstly the minister has to stand up for Queensland and stand up for understanding the impacts on the cost of living in this state. We are not like Victoria. If you drive three hours out of Melbourne, you are close to the borders. If you drive three hours out of Brisbane, you are not even halfway across the state to the west and you are certainly nowhere near even getting halfway up the coast of Queensland.
Mr Rickuss: Not even in Bundaberg.

Ms SIMPSON: Correct. This state is different because of the nature of its geography and that requires an understanding and a respect. This is something that we are aware of from talking to people in freight and also from talking to those consumers who, at the end of the day--
Mr Wettenhall: Fascinating insight!
Mr Rickuss: That goes to show North Queenslanders don’t even realise how it is affecting them.

Ms SIMPSON: It is a bit stunning, isn’t it? This state is a very large state in regard to moving freight and there are particular cost impacts that Queenslanders have felt as a result of that. I want to table an article from the Toowoomba Chronicle that talks about some of the registration hikes and the costs to consumers. The words of some of these transport operators clearly outline how this has had such a negative impact.
Government members interjected.
Ms SIMPSON: I can hear that there is some guffawing and laughing from Labor members who do not think this is serious, but when I talk to Queenslanders who are hurting--
Honourable members interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Treasurer!
Ms SIMPSON: I table this document.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Article, dated 25 May 2010, from the Toowoomba Chronicle titled ‘Truck rego hike to cost consumers’ [ 2777 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: I note that this government has no remorse for the pain it is inflicting upon ordinary Queenslanders, be it through increased freight costs or directly through their registration for their cars. It stuns me that government members do not get it. People are fed up with the way that they have abused their trust. They deliberately misled them in regard to removing the fuel tax rebate and imposed a tax upon them through the petrol bowser and now there are ongoing costs accumulatively through registration. If they do not get it now, when will they get it?
Honourable members interjected.
Mr Rickuss interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Member for Lockyer, please!
Mr Rickuss: I am being provoked.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Bring yourself to order.

Ms SIMPSON: We have also seen reports about how the average cost of living for Queenslanders has risen by about $1,200 a year. Across the board, we are seeing increases above CPI, particularly driven by higher power costs as a result of this Labor Party misleading the people of Queensland. We have higher water costs, higher toll prices, higher registration fees and certainly higher petrol costs, and there are many other areas that the government has a direct responsibility for. I want to table this article as well because it outlines again the stress that people are under in Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Article, dated 30 May 2010, from News.com.au titled ‘Cost of living in Queensland rises $1200 a year’ [ 2778 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: When will government members ever listen? When will they understand? When will they respond in a way that will finally give some relief to people where it matters and allow them to get on with their lives? If government members really cared about the people of Queensland, if they cared about stimulating this economy throughout the regions of Queensland, if they cared about saving businesses that are no longer viable due to higher costs imposed by the government and the fact this is the most regulated government in Australia--with double the number of pages of regulation of some of our near state neighbours--then they would change that.

I call on government members to heed LNP policy, freeze the registration increases, listen to the people about those impacts, stop putting their heads in the sand because Queenslanders are hurting and that is why they are crying out for a government that understands. If government members do not support our motion to see the freezing of this registration hike, then clearly they have not listened to the people of Queensland.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (7.58 pm): I wish to second the motion put by the shadow minister, the member for Maroochydore. Governments must not do things that can be reasonably avoided if the implications of their actions are unfair and unreasonable. Unfair and unreasonable actions should be decided on the basis of available evidence made in an environment of the impartial application of principles and processes that are deemed appropriate by consensus support of the quorum of democratically elected representatives responsible to develop such principles and processes.

Similarly, agencies designated by the quorum are charged with delivering the policy in a framework to the public that reflects the intent of the policy and allows the public to self-select those regulations that include them where their own individual situation or actions are prescribed by legislation. As such, there is a debate about whether this action by the Bligh Labor government has the right to increase the registration beyond what is reasonable, in this case by CPI, and a fixed increase over and above that of the previous registration fee applying to the Transport Operations (Road Use Management--Vehicle Registration) Regulation 1999 part 16, primarily this regulation.
In the past two years registration has gone up by 27 per cent, as has been raised, and 36 per cent for commercial vehicles. We also understand that we cannot--
Mr Wettenhall: How would you pay for the roads?

Dr DOUGLAS: The member for Barron River should just listen. I am trying to say that there is a clear case of, firstly, gouging fees from motorists in Queensland unreasonably and, secondly, a potential breach of section 51 of the Constitution. It is the second point that I would like to emphasise primarily.

I completely agree with the sentiments expressed by the member for Maroochydore regarding price gouging. To all her comments I would add the following facts, which may have escaped the Bligh Labor government’s attention. Motorists’ costs are increasing by $220 per person. The 8c per litre fuel levy was scrapped, adding an extra $500 million in costs to Queensland motorists. Queensland is the most expensive state in Australia to own and operate a car, yet we are the most decentralised state. When added to tollway increases of between 30 per cent and 100 per cent, we have a clear case established for unfair cost recovery and unreasonable charges by this government.

If we are truly the Smart State, firstly, should it not be cheaper to own and operate a car in this state? Secondly, should registration not go up by CPI only, if at all? Thirdly, if times really are so tough because of the GFC and the recession we did not have to have, why would this government increase the cost to average Queenslanders of getting around? Fourthly, why would the state need to charge more than any other state for cost recovery? The truth is that there is no justification for any of these things. This was a decision made in a vacuum by desperate people--Labor. Therefore, the LNP and I are calling for a fair go, a fair go for families, small business and for all motoring Queenslanders.

I suspect that this exorbitant fee could also be deemed constitutionally illegal and may be challenged under section 51, chapter I, part V of the Commonwealth Constitution. Specifically, it appears to breach the major provisions relating to discrimination between states. Motor vehicles do move beyond state borders and routinely do so. Commercially, it is more likely. Members need to know that a B-quad used for cattle transport from western Queensland to South Australia now attracts $28,000 in registration in Queensland. There is considerable evidence to support a section 51 challenge.

Motor vehicle registration is a significant component in the everyday cost of living of average Queenslanders. There can be no justification for the price hike on electricity, which is up 30 per cent, fuel is up eight per cent and rates are up seven per cent. The major component of water is up 25 per cent and potentially is up 300 per cent in six years. The average charge for water for a family for six months is currently $245. As I say, motor vehicle registration is also up.

South-East Queensland is now ranked amongst the least affordable places to live in the world, ahead of New York, London and Santa Barbara in the US. In a study of 272 markets in the Demographia International Housing Affordability Survey, 62 markets were identified as unaffordable and 22 of those were Australian. The Gold Coast comes in at No. 4 just after the Sunshine Coast, Brisbane comes in at No. 22 and Melbourne at No. 8. The factors noted are the cost of living, lower wages and rising property prices. Furthermore, in contrast to the Labor obsession with overregulation and a failed SEQ plan, the review stated that housing unaffordability has been driven by the devastating impact of land use regulation and the false belief that denser means cheaper. Twenty-four per cent of respondents to a recent poll on the website Gold Coast.com run by the Gold Coast Bulletin revealed that they were thinking of moving to another city away from the Gold Coast.

Is this ignorant Labor government listening to the public? Has it got any idea why the public hates the Premier and the Labor brand? It is because they cannot handle the intolerable increasing burden of costs due to Labor waste and mismanagement. This week Labor members should have hung their heads in shame when it was revealed that Queensland was the only state in Australia to not even grant a concession or free travel on public transport for Seniors Week. Seniors deserve a fair go for their contribution to the state and the nation.
Mr Hoolihan interjected.
Mr Rickuss interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr O’Brien): Order! Member for Keppel, member for Lockyer, order, please.

Dr DOUGLAS: Has it occurred to anyone in this chaotic Bligh Labor government that the rapid transit scheme on the Gold Coast is not linked to heavy rail but instead terminates in two locations where there is no public parking. Ten million tourists come to the coast annually but they will never use it because it is neither rapid nor mass transit. Gold Coasters and today’s editorial in our local newspaper have stated that this is a mass transit scheme to nowhere because the missing link is incomplete in the current plan, which is a link to the heavy rail, primarily at Helensvale. Yet here we are spending $1.8 billion, with the major sum going to suppliers who are well beyond our shores.

These numbers sound so familiar. We have been talking tonight about the NBN plan, this $43 billion plan that started off as a $6 billion plan in 2007. People do not realise that the annual interest bill on $1 billion alone is $46.7 million every year. Then a capital return has to be made on it as well. This comes at a time when ordinary Queenslanders cannot afford to pay their car rego because they would never have budgeted for this manifest Labor incompetence in increasing their charges. This increase is totally unjustified. It is wrong. Do Labor members really know what these significant costs are? Do they understand how hard it is to pay it back? This Labor government has lost its way. It has alienated the Queensland public and it deserves what it has got coming to it.

For its entire first term in office, the LNP will freeze registration fees for cars and light vehicles along with recreational boats, trailers and horse floats. We call on the Labor members to show some spine and deliver for all Queenslanders universal support for this motion.
Ms FARMER (Bulimba--ALP) (8.07 pm): In the 2010-11 budget--
Mr Rickuss interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Member for Lockyer, order! That is the third time in 20 minutes. Bring yourself to order.

Ms FARMER: In the 2010-11 budget the Bligh Labor government committed $4 billion to transport. Why did the government do this? Because it is committed to a safe, efficient and integrated transport system. Why is it committed to a safe, efficient and integrated transport system? Because that is what is required to connect people and communities, to move goods, to deliver services, to provide access to employment and education and to social services and recreational activities for Queenslanders.

What does $4 billion deliver? Here are some examples: $219 million for the Gold Coast Rapid Transit system; $150 million to continue construction of a busway connection between the South East Busway and Main Avenue, part of $833 million for the first two stages of the busway; $61 million to continue construction of cycle links to enhance the cycle network of South-East Queensland; funding of 100 per cent of all rail services in South-East Queensland; funding of 60 per cent of all Brisbane City Council buses; funding of 100 per cent of all new buses in South-East Queensland; a $50 million boost for bus services through South-East Queensland, providing 60 per cent of the funding for the almost 53,000 bus services per week delivered by the Brisbane City Council. What are we spending our money on in Main Roads? We are spending $3.3 billion, three times what the LNP spent on roads when it was in power. Our road building program is creating around 30,000 jobs a year.

I have never heard those opposite object to any of these initiatives. I have never heard them object to any of the services that are being introduced in their electorates. In fact, they are always wanting more. What I do hear them talking about is how the government needs to cut spending and how the government should not be raising revenue to provide the transport and road services it does provide, which is essentially what this disallowance motion is about.

What I would like to know from those opposite is what transport and road services they are going to cut. At the last election they talked about a three per cent efficiency dividend. They have reconfirmed that since. How is this going to affect the provision of services by Transport and Main Roads in Queensland? Are they going to cut public transport? Are they going to cut roads and infrastructure? Is it going to be road safety? They need to tell us.

We need to take transport and main roads seriously in our state. Thank goodness the Bligh Labor government is doing just that. We know that Tony Abbott is not doing just that. We know, for instance, that he does not even rate public transport as worth a mention. Whose jaw did not drop to the floor when we heard of Tony Abbott’s pronouncement on public transport in his book Battle Lines ? The Minister for Transport read those words to the House this morning but they are well worth quoting again, such is their reflection of the ignorance of the man about what the average Queenslander needs to do to go about their daily business. I repeat the words now--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Mostly there just aren’t enough people wanting to go from a particular place to a particular destination at a particular time to justify any vehicle larger than a car.
XML.Hansard-Body: I would like to ask the 1,100 commuters who go through the Cannon Hill Railway Station every day what they think about that. I would like to ask the 1,836 commuters who go through the Morningside Railway Station every day what they think about that or ask the tens of thousands of other commuters who travel to and from the Bulimba electorate every day what they think about that.
Mr Rickuss interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr O’Brien): Order! I warn the member for Lockyer under standing order 253A. You will come to order. The member for Bulimba has the call.

Ms FARMER: I would like to ask the 700,000 people who commute across the South-East Queensland public transport network every day what they think. Good-quality, affordable public transport is one--not the only but certainly one--of the most essential services we can provide to Queenslanders to maintain their quality of life. We know that if we can encourage public transport patronage then we are also addressing traffic congestion and helping to reduce our carbon footprint.

I do not know about LNP electorates, but these are issues that my constituents talk to me about a lot. I would like to talk specifically about public transport. Public transport patronage has exploded in recent years. The Bligh Labor government is totally committed to providing a public transport service, making it affordable and making it safe. Since 2004 patronage on the TransLink network has increased almost 50 per cent, from 123 million trips to over 180 million trips last year. This is around five times population growth. These impressive patronage figures are in response to the record level of funding injected into the TransLink network by the Bligh government. TransLink is funded to the tune of $1.9 billion to create accessible, reliant, efficient and safe public transport services across South-East Queensland.

This is not a cheap commitment from the government. It is structured in such a way as to provide the maximum opportunity for the commuter. Is this what the opposition would like to cut? For every dollar spent by the customer on public transport, the government contributes $3. Is this what the opposition would like to cut?

There are few better examples of how the Bligh Labor government is providing an affordable public transport system than the recent introduction of the go card. This initiative is a winner and it is applauded across the country. More than 62 per cent of public transport trips in South-East Queensland are taken with the go card. That is equivalent to over 113 million trips with the go card so far.

People can save money on the card. Trips on the card are on average 30 per cent cheaper than with paper tickets. The government has provided even further support to commuters by giving away $10 cards to those who have already given a lot to our community--to our seniors, to our charity organisations and other not-for-profit organisations--to help make their introduction to the electronic card a smooth transition. Over 300,000 people have taken up this offer. I think that means they like it. Is the go card what the opposition would like to cut?

The Bligh Labor government delivered 301,000 new seats in the 2009-10 financial year. This equates to seating capacity for 15 million additional public transport trips across the next financial year. The breakdown comprises 30,000 additional weekly seats on the Gold Coast, Cleveland, Ipswich, Doomben and Rosewood lines, 215,000 weekly bus seats across Brisbane, 40,000 weekly bus seats across the Gold Coast, 10,000 additional seats for school services and buses in the Logan-Park Ridge area and 8,000 additional seats on the Brisbane CityCat services. Many of these lines go through the electorates of LNP members.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order!
Member for Bulimba, just wait, please. There is too much audible conversation. Gentlemen, take it outside, please. The member for the Bulimba has the call.

Ms FARMER: Many of these lines go through electorates represented by LNP members. Which ones would those opposite like to cut? It is interesting to note that if the opposition’s three per cent efficiency dividend had been implemented there would be a reduction of 170,000 seats per week on the TransLink network. I would like to be in the LNP party room when they work out which of their constituents got to miss out.

I know that the LNP wants to talk about prices. If those opposite are talking about offering concessions and subsidies to the people who need it the most, let me tell members about some of the concessions that the Bligh Labor government offers. The government is committed to providing concessions to our pensioners and concession card holders whenever possible. It is expected that the Queensland government in 2010-11 will provide an estimated $1.32 billion in concessions to pension, concession and Seniors Card holders. Of this amount, the Department of Transport and Main Roads will provide approximately $357.8 million in concessions, with an estimated $91.7 million relating specifically to registration related concessions.

This figure increases each year due to population growth and with an ongoing growth in the ageing population. The government is working hard to ensure that this system remains sustainable and to ensure that the benefits continue to be received by those who need them most. What are some examples? They are half-price car registration fees for pensioners, discounted taxi travel for people with a disability and half-price travel for pensioners and students using buses, trains and ferries. Then there is the $24 cut to CTP insurance on car registration from which every car owner would benefit. Now, which of these would the LNP like to cut?

It is impossible to know where the LNP is coming from. The government is well aware that the cost of living is a big issue. That is why we have a massive job creation program, which the LNP opposes at every turn. The LNP does not want us to create jobs. It does not want us to raise revenue but it does want more of everything.

I am proud to be part of a government which is committed to doing whatever it has to do to provide a good quality of life for Queenslanders, sometimes in ways that require politically difficult decisions. I commend the initiatives of the ministers for transport and main roads to provide a world-class system for Queenslanders.

Mr RICKUSS (Lockyer--LNP)
(8.17 pm): I rise to say a few words in the debate on the Transport Legislation (Fees) Amendment Regulation (No. 1) disallowance motion. I am glad that you are sitting in the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker O’Brien, because I am sure you will understand what I am talking about here. I refer to how disadvantaged rural and regional Queenslanders are by those opposite being so reluctant to assist car owners. Those opposite seem to hate car owners, and particularly V8 Land Cruiser car owners. I am sure there are a lot of them up in the cape. The registration cost for these vehicles has gone through the roof.

The RACQ says that the running costs per year for a V8 Land Cruiser have increased by $1,445 under this government. These are your poor, battling constituents that these blokes hate. They hate the poor battlers in the cape. They hate the fact that they drive V8 Land Cruisers. They have to drive V8 Land Cruisers because they do not make anything else. The four-wheel drive Land Cruisers do not come in anything else but V8. They are more fuel efficient than the six cylinders. Those opposite are taxing them out of existence. I can see the Deputy Speaker nodding in agreement with me. He understands this issue.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr O’Brien): Order! Member for Lockyer, what you are saying is a reflection on the chair. I am not agreeing with you; I am presiding over the parliament. Do not put words in my mouth while I am in the chair.

Mr RICKUSS: I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. I did not intend to make any reflection on the chair. I will reflect on the mob opposite that are hopeless. The government puts 75 per cent into every public transport fare.

Yesterday the member for Waterford said that he supported public transport, yet it is the poor battlers in Waterford and Beenleigh who are now paying extra registration fees because he will not help them. He is a disgrace for that electorate. Those people are paying more for rego and more in fuel tax. The poor battlers of Waterford, Beenleigh, Loganlea and Eagleby are the ones who are paying because the member for Waterford will not help them. The member for Barron River is a disgrace for those poor Far North Queenslanders who are battling away trying to pay their rego bills and trying to pay extra fuel costs. It is an absolute disgrace!
Mr WETTENHALL: I rise to a point of order. I find those words offensive and I ask that they be withdrawn.
Mr RICKUSS: I withdraw the words relating to the member for Barron River because I know that he is a disgrace to--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: No, you will withdraw unconditionally.
Mr RICKUSS: I did. I withdraw them.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: No, withdraw unconditionally.
Mr RICKUSS: Okay. I withdraw the words unconditionally. It is actually a disgrace--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: No, member for Lockyer. Withdraw your comments.
Mr RICKUSS: I did.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: I am not satisfied.
Mr RICKUSS: I withdrew unconditionally.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Okay; thank you. That is fine. Now you can continue.

Mr RICKUSS: The member for Barron River has sat there and carped half the night here about the increased registration costs that are being paid by his constituents. It is just a shame that he will not stand up and represent those poor battling car owners and those poor battlers who have to pay these increased registration costs and increased fuel costs. It goes on. The member for Morayfield has been just as bad, supporting him in carping here half the night. The member for Yeerongpilly is the leader of the choir, carping away at those poor battlers who are trying to pay increased registration costs.

How ridiculous is it that it is cheaper to register a triple trailered road train than it is to register a B-double? It is cheaper to register a road train that is 40 metres long than it is to register a 26-metre B-double. How ridiculous is that? There is no common sense in any of these registration hikes. It is just ridiculous! Transport companies which have a base in my electorate such as Nolan’s, Lindsay, Freshway, Mitchell and Rocky’s Own are being penalised by this government going over the top with registration fees and there seems to be no rhyme or reason for it. There seems to be no rhyme or reason for why a B-double would be more expensive to register than a triple trailered road train or a double trailered road train. A B-double will hold only 12 pallets on the first trailer and 22 on the second trailer whereas a road train will hold 22 pallets on all trailers--that is, 66 pallets. How stupid is that? It makes no sense.

Taking into consideration the statistics, B-doubles are very safe vehicles. I received some statistics recently from Victoria which show that B-doubles are miles safer than single trailers, yet the government is trying to increase their registration so that they go out of existence. I am extremely disappointed that the members on the other side of the House, even the member for Bulimba, are not standing up for the battlers in their electorates who have to pay these increased registration fees and increased fuel costs when the government is subsidising public transport to the tune of 75 per cent. How ridiculous is that? Anyone who lives outside the metropolitan area is being totally disadvantaged by this mob opposite. People just cannot believe the increases in rego and fuel costs. It just goes on and on and on. I hate to harp on, but it is a crying shame that this mob opposite do not have an idea what the real world is like. They talk about public transport, yet I am sure that the mob opposite--
Government members interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order!

Mr RICKUSS: I thank you for your protection, Mr Deputy Speaker. As we can hear by the carping coming from the other side, they just do not get it. They just do not understand how the battlers in Queensland are being ripped off. People in outer suburbs such as Flagstone where there is no public transport are being ripped off because they have to pay this dear rego. I just cannot believe it. This regulation should be repealed.

Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP) (8.23 pm): I, too, am pleased to contribute to the debate this evening on the disallowance motion moved by the shadow minister. I am pleased to contribute to this debate because the regulation we are seeking to disallow cuts to the chase when it comes to Labor’s economic mismanagement and it clearly portrays the alternatives that will face Queenslanders when they next decide who will govern this great state. Let us start with Labor’s economic mismanagement. This regulation will pass on another CPI increase to licence and vehicle registration fees. On its own this may appear insignificant, but on the back of last year’s 17 per cent to 22 per cent increase it is yet another slap in the face for Queensland’s struggling families.

Last year the LNP stood in this House and denounced that outrageous fee increase for what it was--a desperate money grab by a desperately broke government. A quick look at the RACQ’s analysis shows this. Let us take a four-cylinder car that in 2008-09 cost $263 to register. In 2009-10 that amount jumped to $308.25, an increase of 17 per cent. If we take a six- or eight-cylinder car, the increase is even greater. If we compare that to other Australian states, Queenslanders get a greater sense of the magnitude of this slap in the face. In New South Wales--the most expensive of the other states--it costs $245.20 to register a small car. In Victoria--the cheapest--it costs $178. What do we pay in Queensland? $308.25. The average across all other states is $191.29. What conclusions did the RACQ arrive at? It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Queensland Government portrays itself as low taxing compared with other jurisdictions. However, the data on registration costs presented in this FactSheet make it clear that vehicle owners in Queensland face the highest government-imposed fixed costs in Australia.

Queensland motorists have enjoyed the benefits of an 8.354 cents/litre fuel subsidy that is not available in other states. To some extent, this has balanced the very high registration costs in Queensland.
Should the registration costs increase further, and the fuel subsidy be removed, Queenslanders will face the highest vehicle ownership and operating costs in the country.

None of the proposed increase in revenue to the Queensland Government is dedicated to fund transport infrastructure or services. It will go to consolidated revenue, where it will replace other shortfalls in revenue due to the economic downturn, or other increases in government expenditure.
XML.Hansard-Body: And there we have it. The Bligh Labor government did remove the fuel subsidy. This Bligh Labor government continues to funnel more than a billion dollars in revenue raised through registrations into consolidated revenue, not into transport infrastructure, and this Bligh Labor government is yet again increasing registration fees. It finishes off a trio of blows that see Queensland motorists facing the highest vehicle ownership and operating costs in the country.

If that was the only cost-of-living increase confronting Queensland’s struggling families then perhaps it could be justified, but it is not. The vehicle operating cost increases have flow-on impacts on groceries and daily services, as businesses pass on their own increased expenses.

And then there are electricity increases and water increases. Just on that alone, constituents in Glass House--constituents who have used tank or bore water for the past 10 years--now pay $223 a quarter for that privilege. Where will it end? Kevin 07 and the federal Labor Party fought an election on cost-of-living increases and his commitment to reduce the burden on Australian working families. But after what Queensland has seen since, one must ask: was that the fake Labor Party? Has the real Labor Party stepped forward at both the federal and the state level over the ensuing three years?
