Queenslanders know that the answer is a resounding yes--the real Labor Party crippled by economic mismanagement, the real Labor Party stumbling from one failed initiative to another, the real Labor Party forced to raise taxes and fees to offset its mountainous debt repayments, the real Labor Party that does not care about cost-of-living increases after all.

That brings me to the alternative being offered to Queenslanders. When it comes to reining in cost-of-living increases, only the LNP has a plan. The LNP, upon restoring the state’s AAA credit rating, has committed to reinstating the fuel subsidy. Only the LNP has committed to freezing registration costs for cars, boats and light trucks during its first term in government. Whether it is the federal election this Saturday or the state election due before March 2012, Queensland’s struggling families have a decision to make: do they vote for the real Labor Party, which will do and say anything to win their vote, which will continue to tax and levy them to make up for its economic mismanagement, which will force cost-of-living increase after cost-of-living increase upon them; or will they vote for an LNP that has a proven record of economic management and a commitment to put a freeze on registration cost increases like the ones contained in this regulation?

Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (8.29 pm): I rise this evening to contribute to the debate on the disallowance motion moved by the LNP. The purpose of the disallowance is to highlight this state Labor government’s ongoing gouging of motorists in Queensland with high fees and taxes. The subordinate legislation provides regulations for about 16 acts. However, our concern is the Transport Operations (Road Use Management--Vehicle Registration) Regulation 1999. The LNP will use this disallowance motion to highlight its policy that is designed to ease the burden on families in Queensland, unlike the bleating of federal Labor’s working families and downward pressure on interest rates--all from Labor governments that go bust in a boom and turn the coalition’s surplus into a spendathon.

We are seeking to challenge the government to adopt our policy and freeze car registration and give people a break. The LNP will freeze for its entire first term in office the registration fees for cars and light vehicles, along with recreational boats, trailers and horse floats. In the past two years, registration has increased by a whopping 27 per cent, putting further pressure on struggling families. Car registration and the removal of the fuel subsidy will add an additional burden to Queensland’s struggling families who are under threat of further economic pressures bought about by a Labor state government that has gone bust in a boom.
As reported in the Brisbane Times website as far back as May 2009, motorists would bear the full brunt of this government’s mismanagement of our economy and I quote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Queensland motorists face a double-barrel blast of fuel price and vehicle registration increases this year...

The peak motoring body also accuses the state government of being coy about the true impact of rises in vehicle registration already announced by the Bligh government and due to become effective on July 1.
The government touted the rises as between six and 11 per cent.
Car owners will be paying between $45 and $113 more for registration from July 1...
The increases will net the government $194 million towards a $14 billion shortfall blown in the state budget...
After July 1 it will cost $627 to register a large car in Queensland, compared to $178 in Victoria and $246 in Tasmania.
We’re currently the most expensive state or territory in which to register a motor vehicle--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: according to Mr Fites from the RACQ.
XML.Hansard-Body: Electricity bills are also up, as reported on Saturday, 29 May 2010, and I quote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Queensland households will pay around $200 extra on their annual power bills following a decision to jack up electricity prices by 13 per cent from July 1.
Energy Minister Stephen Robertson says he won’t use his veto powers to overrule the increase.
The independent Queensland Competition Authority ... announced on Friday electricity prices would rise by 13.29 per cent.
The jump will see a household average bill of $350 per quarter rise by $46.50 to nearly $400.
XML.Hansard-Body: Water bills are also up, as quoted by David Olsen on Monday, 28 June 2010 as follows--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Queenslanders can expect to pay on average $2.05 more per week under new pricing from Queensland Urban Utilities in the South East Queensland region.
XML.Hansard-Body: Boat registrations are also up, as reported in the Courier-Mail as far back as 30 May 2008, and I quote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Queensland’s 200,000 recreational boaties are set to be slugged with higher fees in the next State Budget, with registration to rise by up to $360.
Leaked Treasury documents show registration fees will rise between $15 and $360 a year depending on the size of the boat.
Under the changes, the registration of tinnies up to 4.5m will rise to $50.35--up $15. But owners of 20m-plus craft will pay $598--an extra $360.
XML.Hansard-Body: Car and truck licence renewals are up, as reported in the Brisbane Times on 12 May 2010 as follows--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The price of a new five-year licence will initially rise from $73.30 to $96.05, before escalating again to $152.50 in 2014.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That is an overall increase of a massive 108 per cent. The article continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The cost will be even greater for truck drivers who will need a separate heavy vehicle licence under the new system.
The price increase is the latest hit for the state’s drivers, after hefty registration cost increases came into effect last year, while the government scrapped the fuel subsidy.
XML.Hansard-Body: Labor has done nothing to reduce the burden on Queensland families. Labor ministers sit in their ivory towers without a care in the world for the struggling families and senior citizens of this state. Registration has gone up a whopping 27 per cent. So we would expect road funding to increase accordingly. But it has not. Funding for roads is down in this year’s budget by $250 million. It will be no surprise to anyone in this House that roads are the biggest issue in my electorate of Mudgeeraba--and I am sure members will hear about that further this evening.

Mudgeeraba was a marginal Labor seat for eight years and the entire area was repeatedly ignored by a government that never expected to hold the seat for as long as it did. The residents of my electorate are sick and tired of this arrogant, out-of-touch, on-the-nose Labor state government, which pinched money from the Howard government and upgraded the M1 in Labor seats in Brisbane. We have a Minister for Main Roads who will not face locals on the hard issues. He will not come down to listen to residents or their state representative.

Registration costs go up, but when the money needs to be reinvested in better roads for Queensland, our roads see none of it. Queensland once had the proud title of being one of the cheapest states in which to own and operate a motor vehicle. That title is long gone and we are now the most expensive state in Australia in which to own, operate or register a motor vehicle. On top of that, every time ordinary mums and dads fill up their vehicles with petrol, it costs them more now than ever.

Under Labor, when it deregulated the electricity industry, we were promised that electricity prices would not rise. As we now know, that is not the case. Electricity prices have gone up. That is another broken promise. When this Labor government took control of South-East Queensland’s water assets, once again residents were told that prices would not go up, but they did.

The fuel tax is another broken promise. This Labor government has failed to plan for the tough times. During a period of great growth and income it has wasted millions and millions of taxpayer funds on dodgy deals and projects that could have been run more efficiently by a five-year-old. The LNP’s policy to freeze registration fees for cars and light vehicles, along with recreational boats, trailers and horse floats, will at least give residents some hope and comfort that they will not be getting hit in the hip pocket year after year.

The LNP is well aware of the hardships being faced in the community and it will deliver on its promises. That is the difference between the Liberal National Party and Labor. We are the true economic conservatives. We know how to run business and we know how to stick to budgets--unlike the others, which went bust in a boom, lost our AAA credit rating and are more spin than substance.

Mr WENDT (Ipswich West--ALP) (8.35 pm): I rise to oppose the motion of disallowance moved by the member for Maroochydore. Despite the speech from the member for Maroochydore, I believe that the motion that she has moved and the arguments that she has made are short-sighted and, as such, typical of the approach that the LNP would take to governance in this state. That is because, in its most basic form, this disallowance motion means $63 million would be taken out of the budget bottom line.

I would now like to concentrate my comments specifically on issues associated with the motor registration and CTP initiatives which were announced earlier. It is quite plain that this government has never taken lightly the cost of living pressures that Queenslanders face. That is because we know that every dollar counts. That is why in this year’s budget the Treasurer announced a reduction in the CPT insurance levy for all motorists of $24, which will be effective from October this year. However, that is not all; it should be noted that the current government also provides significant levels of concessions for vehicle registration to qualifying pensioners, seniors, charitable and community service organisations and, of course, our primary producers.

For instance, in Queensland, for holders of a pension concession card issued prior to 1 July 1994, the concession benefit is a reduction in the registration fee portion to a flat rate and for holders of a pension concession card issued after 1 July 1994, as well as all eligible Seniors Card holders, the registration fee portion is reduced by 50 per cent. That means that in 2010-11 the Department of Transport and Main Roads will provide approximately $357 million in concessions, with an estimated nearly $92 million relating specifically to registration related concessions. That means that the government is using the fees collected from vehicle registrations to make a record investment in Queensland’s future. As such, we continue to invest more in roads than we collect in vehicle registration charges.

By way of example, I think it is worth noting that, currently, registration charges generate around $1.2 billion in income. However, the government provides $2.145 billion in funding for road construction and maintenance. Further, the government also spends more per capita on roads funding, which is different from what the member for Mudgeeraba said a moment ago. In fact, it is around $732 per person in Queensland and this is more than its counterpart in New South Wales, which spends around $382; in Western Australia, which spends $227; and in Victoria, which spends around $205 per person. I think that demonstrates clearly the level of commitment that we have to building a strong future for all Queenslanders. It shows how we want to keep investing in infrastructure and services while the opposition only wants to make cuts.

However, I am aware that one sure way to increase the cost of living pressures on all Queenslanders is to have high unemployment, because without a breadwinner families will face an uncertain future and many will be unable to meet the most basic costs. That why it is important to remember that the opposition took a plan to the last election that would have cut jobs in the public sector and destroyed jobs in the construction industry. If members remember, the opposition’s plan was to halt our record building program. This, of course, would have been a job killer. By maintaining our building program and not cutting services, this government took the most responsible course of action in the face of the very real threat of recession.

We did not put our foot on the brake of the Queensland economy; rather we accelerated investment and created jobs. In view of this, the member for Maroochydore’s motion tonight seeks to take $63 million out of infrastructure and services and I, for one, cannot support this as it would mean more job losses and more families facing an uncertain future in my electorate and right across Queensland. I suppose this is typical of their approach to government. As we have already seen in this federal election campaign, a similar plan from Tony Abbott and the coalition government would see cuts to services and a refusal to invest in infrastructure, with more jobs lost and more families under pressure. I cannot support this motion.

Mr DOWLING (Redlands--LNP) (8.40 pm): Tonight I speak in support of the disallowance motion for the Transport Legislation (Fees) Amendment Regulation (No. 1) 2010, which is subordinate legislation No. 100 of 2010. I find it interesting sitting here listening to the debate from both sides of the House. It is almost like the two worlds have crossed over somehow. We seem to be defending the battler while those opposite, who built their platform and their party on supporting the working class and the battler, have completely left them out in the cold.

This disallowance motion is important in trying to put some kind of brake on to help people draw breath. Instead of having people treading water, members of this government are currently standing them on their heads and drowning them. It is not helping our community. My office is in a shopping precinct and when I look out the window I notice that the number of people has visibly declined, and it is because of the knock-on effect of all the fees and charges. Government members talk about registration being capped to CPI. That is a myth. It is simply a headline that the government has manufactured through its spin doctors. That is about the only thing that Labor does have that works in an amazing fashion. That CPI is only for this year. When one compounds it with last year, we see there is a 27 per cent average registration increase. That is unacceptable. When one looks at car ownership, as we have repeatedly heard tonight, we see we have gone from being one of the cheapest states in Australia to own and operate a motor car to one of the dearest. That hurts people. Queensland is a big state. We are probably more reliant upon our motor vehicles than many of the smaller states and Western Australia, which is centrally focused. In Queensland a car is not a luxury; we see it is a lifestyle necessity.

This government has historically targeted the motor car. Look at the tolls. I have had a number of small business operators come to my office. They own small rigid-body vehicles, such as single axle flat-tray towies, concrete trucks, small furniture removal trucks or small courier vans. They have now been bumped up a class. Their increases have been astronomical. They have gone from being classified as a motor car to being classified as almost the equivalent of a semitrailer. It is absolutely bizarre. These are small business people who employ people locally in South-East Queensland. These are the ones who are not able to employ people. These are the ones who are going broke. We heard earlier today the level of bankruptcy of small business in Queensland. I think it was 47 per cent that I heard from the member for Southern Downs earlier this morning. They are jobs. Those opposite talk about jobs and pretend to represent jobs but that is completely wrong. They have been completely flat-footed. They have been causing bankruptcies. They are driving people into the poorhouse because registration and fuel prices have gone up.

The government was very quiet about that in the run-up to the election, I hasten to add. It talks about keeping costs under control. All of the tolls on all of the motorways and all of the fares have gone through the roof. Labor is about driving up the cost of living. It is inflation. The cost of water, the cost of electricity, the cost of every single thing that people do under this government costs a fortune. When I look into these shopping arcades in my local area around Victoria Point I can tell members that the stores are trading very low. I can tell members that the people who used to go there and shop do not have that disposable income anymore. I can tell members that those retailers are letting people go. I can tell members that those people are now unemployed.
Ms Grace interjected.

Mr DOWLING: Those opposite can harp on all they like and close their ears to this. These are real people that the government is supposed to represent. All we get is empty noise, just rabbiting across the chamber. There is nothing behind it. The air comes in one way and out the other. Those opposite have clearly lost the plot as to what it is to represent the people of Queensland who are getting penalised and completely done over every single time.
Ms Jones interjected.

Mr DOWLING: I take the interjection from the minister. Did the minister know that the jobs in the call centre of GreenSmart housing have gone to Melbourne? I do not think so. The outbound calls are all going to Melbourne.

Ms JONES: I rise to a point of order. The honourable member is misleading the House. What he is saying is not true. He knows that that is not true. I have corrected the record on that. I ask him to withdraw it.
Mr DOWLING: They are going to Melbourne. I have that categorically from GreenSmart housing. I believe that the point of order is out of order.
Ms JONES: I find it personally offensive, because the call centre for the ClimateSmart Home Service is based in Queensland.

Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms Farmer): Order! If the minister finds it personally offensive I ask the member to withdraw. The other issue is a matter of process that will need to be referred through the chair.
Ms SIMPSON: Can I ask you to clarify in regard to the standing orders how that is a personal reflection?
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: If the member finds it personally offensive I ask the member to withdraw it.

Mr DOWLING: I did not hear that--that it was offensive. I simply stated some facts that have been challenged and I wait for that to run its due process. But I will clarify the point for you, Madam Deputy Speaker. There are two call centres, one in Queensland and one in Melbourne.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! I warn members not to make frivolous points of order. In this instance the member has found your point personally offensive and I ask you to withdraw unconditionally.
Mr DOWLING: I would ask which point was offensive and I will happily withdraw it.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! I ask you to withdraw unconditionally.

Mr DOWLING: Withdraw unconditionally. Queensland is now the most expensive place to own a car, with costs going up $220 per vehicle. That is clearly unacceptable. The government is hurting this community. We hear a lot from those opposite about this side of the House being a policy-free zone. Those opposite choose to hear some things but not to hear others. We have a very clear policy that, when we win government at the next election, we will freeze rates. I throw down the challenge here tonight to those opposite to adopt our policy and freeze registration and start listening to those people who are struggling under the weight of this incredibly oppressive brutal regime that is this Labor government. It is completely destroying the fabric of small business and destroying this community. The best that we hear tonight is that there has been a reduction in the CTP. The government has not put its hand in its pocket for that CTP. It is actually coming from those service providers and the commissions that they pay. They are making those unlawful. The government has not stepped up to the plate. It is not helping the community. It is not listening to the constituents that it pretends to represent. I again throw down the challenge: adopt our policy here tonight and freeze registration.

Mr EMERSON (Indooroopilly--LNP) (8.48 pm): Queenslanders are hurting from increases in the cost of living and nearly every day they are confronted by another example of the Bligh government hitting their back pocket. Labor is making sure every Queenslander pays for its incompetent economic management. Labor seems to view Queensland motorists as its cash cow. In contrast, the LNP recognises that Queenslanders are hurting under Labor. That is why the LNP will freeze registration costs for cars, boats and light trucks during its first term in government, but there is no freeze from Labor. Labor is forcing motorists to make ever-increasing contributions to the state budget to make up for its failures.

Queensland has become the most expensive state in Australia to own and run a car. The fact is that the Bligh government is taking motorists for a ride. Both welfare and motoring groups have warned that motoring costs are escalating beyond the reach of many Queenslanders. As RACQ spokesman Gary Fites said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It is fair to say motorists are getting close to the breaking point as far as the cost of motoring is concerned ... but the State Government has motorists over the barrel because cars are a necessity for Queensland households.
XML.Hansard-Body: Last year most vehicle registration fees rose by 17 per cent and this year they will go up once again. In the past two years alone, the revenue collected from motor vehicle registration has risen by 30 per cent--from $1.014 billion to an estimated $1.31 billion in 2010-11. Since 1 July, it has cost $627 to register a large car in Queensland, compared to $178 in Victoria and $246 in Tasmania. Vehicle registration fees now account for 13 per cent of the government’s total tax take and are one of the largest single-source tax revenues. While motorists pay more, the government is allocating less of its resources to the road network. This year spending on roads will fall by 6.6 per cent, which is down more than $232.5 million, while motorists will pay an extra $50 million in registration fees.

One of the clearest examples of how much Queensland motorists are hurting is how many are late in paying their registration fees. Hundreds of thousands of Queenslanders were hit with more than $27 million in late fees for failing to pay their annual vehicle registration bills on time. Motorists paid about 600,000 late payment fees of up to $48.05 each in the last financial year, funnelling in excess of $73,000 into the state coffers every day. This is a record number of defaults. This controversial fee, initially $40, was introduced by the state government in 2003 and rises annually. From 1 July it increased to $49.15 for vehicles and $12.22 for trailers and recreational ships.

However, it is not just the registration fees that are increasing the cost of living for struggling Queenslanders. Queensland motorists have gone from paying the lowest petrol prices in Australia to the highest in the year since the Bligh government’s fuel tax was introduced. Monitoring by price watchdogs FUELtrac and MotorMouth showed that in July Brisbane had the highest average unleaded petrol price of all mainland capitals, at $1.27 a litre. Let us not forget that this is a fuel tax that the Bligh government ruled out. On 3 June 2008 in parliament, Premier Anna Bligh said of Queenslanders--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I will not kick them--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: that is, Queenslanders--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: when they are down and I will not abolish the petrol subsidy.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: On 16 January 2009 in the Courier-Mail , Treasurer Andrew Fraser was quoted as saying--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Make no mistake about it. We’ll be delivering a fuel subsidy scheme. It will stay in place.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Of course, after the state election, in the 2009-10 budget, the Treasurer scrapped the fuel subsidy, costing Queensland motorists an extra 9.1c a litre in fuel.
XML.Hansard-Body: In this financial year the burden on South-East Queensland motorists has increased further, with the government lifting tolls across the Queensland Motorways network. A single Gateway bridge crossing is up 30 per cent, from $2.95 to $3.85. From 1 July 2010, tolls for the Gateway Motorway increased by 30 per cent. The toll for a private car or a small truck rose from $2.95 to $3.85, a spike of almost $1. The toll increase is being used to drive up the revenue base for Queensland Motorways as the government pursues its sale. Higher revenues mean that the government can seek a higher price for the asset. The Bligh government has also developed a detailed proposal to charge distance tolls to use major south-east roads, including charging motorists 12c a kilometre. The government has ruled it out, but can it be believed? It also ruled out scrapping the fuel subsidy.

The new smart driver’s licence is supposed to be cost neutral, but instead the cost of a five-year licence will jump from the current charge of $73.30 to $96.05 next year and $152.50 by 2014-15. That will be the equal highest cost in Australia. The Queensland Council of Social Service’s board president, Karyn Walsh, has said that the increasing cost of living was putting pressure on the 400,000 people living below the poverty line. She said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There are a significant number of people who are underemployed so the predictability of their income is a challenge for their expenses.
There are many people who don’t have the luxury of a choice between public transport and a car--a car is an essential in a lot of communities where there isn’t the infrastructure of public transport.
XML.Hansard-Body: Even if they can access public transport, Queenslanders have been hit by an increase in the cost of living. From 1 January 2010 go card fares rose by about 20 per cent and paper ticket costs are climbing by around 40 per cent. Fares will jump by 15 per cent annually from 2011 to 2014. Whether it is the costs of registration, petrol, drivers’ licences, road tolls or public transport, this Labor government continues to increase the cost of living for Queenslanders.

Mr McARDLE (Caloundra--LNP) (8.54 pm): With the election of Tony Abbott on Saturday, in Canberra we will have a coalition government that will know how to balance the books, as opposed to a Labor Rudd-Gillard government that took us into deficit and continues to take us into debt on a daily basis. That government has completely wrecked the economy of this nation and then claimed the credit for the hard work done by Howard and Costello. That government is mirrored by the government in this state. Every day that we come into this House we see Labor members cloak themselves in the garb of helping and aiding the working man. They say that they defend the rights of the working man and working families, but at the same time they tax working families out of existence. This is one more example of it imposing heavier and heavier financial burdens on working people right across this state.

This government has a long history of making commitments and then breaking them. The government’s decision to sell Queensland assets never went to the people or the polls. The Treasurer made no comment about it and neither did the Premier. Then suddenly we find that the assets of this state, which generate income for the coffers of the state, are being taken away from the people of state. Day in and day out, electricity prices are increasing. I can recall Premier Beattie standing in this House and saying that competition would ensure that prices went down. Does anybody in this House believe that their power bill has gone down since Premier Beattie handed over that asset and capacity to private enterprise? The prices have gone up, even though under the act the minister has the power to regulate the increases. However, week after week, month after month, the minister has sat in this House and done nothing, even though the act allows him to control and regulate electricity prices. It is an absolute disgrace.

In this state the costs of water have been passed on to ordinary taxpayers because of this government’s incompetence. The burden of its need to pay debt is now being borne by households right across Queensland, including those on the Sunshine Coast. Now registration charges are in the firing line. This government endorses the role Julia Gillard played in knifing Kevin Rudd in the back. He was the working man from Queensland. He worked for the Labor government. He worked for Wayne Goss. He is a Nambour boy. If that is how the Labor Party treats its own federal parliamentary leader, it will have no compunction in sticking it to ordinary, everyday, hardworking Queenslanders. There is no doubt that they do not care, so long as they stay in power. It does not matter who they whack, who they fire, who they charge up, as long as they stay in power. They cloak themselves as the servant of the working man, but that is an absolute joke. On a daily basis they stand in this place and claim to be there for the working men of Australia, but all they have done is increase charges, increase taxes and increase registration fees. Registration has now increased--
Honourable members interjected.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms Farmer): Order! I can barely hear what the member for Caloundra is saying.

Mr McARDLE: And it is worth hearing, Madam Deputy Speaker. In the past two years, registration charges have increased by 27 per cent. For ordinary householders, that means a little less money for food, for luxuries, for rent and for other things that we take for granted.

It means an erosion on a daily basis of the core components that make up the family unit. It also means that there is a significant impact on small businesses which have to pay an increased registration because this government is simply trying to craft back more income to pay its own debt. It is very interesting to look at the added cost of the petrol rebate being removed. Queenslanders are paying $500 million more each year because this government did not get its sums right and this government has dudded the state of Queensland and the people in it. There is no doubt that this registration is simply an impost on Queenslanders to raise additional revenue.

The member for Bulimba raised the issue of public transport. I can say this to the House now: I wish we on the Sunshine Coast had the luxury of complaining about public transport because the CAMCOS rail corridor--that thing that goes on and on and on forever and will never, ever be built--is costed at something like $2 billion to build and it will go on forever and ever. I would love to be able to say we have to consider public transport on the Sunshine Coast, but we do not have any. We still have to pay the other costs associated with this government trying to make things work for it and trying to pay its debts.

I now go to Unitywater. What a marvellous entity that is! It was formulated by the government to try to assist the people of the Sunshine Coast to deal with the issues of the water crisis that enveloped this state. The government has put in place this entity to try to resolve those matters but no-one can get through to them, no-one can contact Unitywater. My office has been inundated by people who have been waiting on hold for up to 45 minutes on two or three occasions. You cannot get them to return a telephone call and you cannot get Unitywater to answer their telephone, let alone deal with the concerns customers have got. This is causing an additional great distress to the people of the Sunshine Coast and right across Queensland.

Residents are making it quite clear that the water bills imposed by this wonderful Labor government on the residents of the Sunshine Coast are two or three times what they paid in the past. Their bills have doubled or tripled, and this is a direct result of this Labor government’s inability to deal with the issues of its own negligence and its own neglect of the financial capacity of the state to pay its own debts.

At the end of the day, it comes down to one very clear point. This government has failed the people of Queensland. It is trying to graft every single cent it can to cover the black hole that the Treasurer and the Premier have gotten us into. We have lost our AAA credit rating, we have lost our capacity to borrow at a minimum level, and we are now slugging the taxpayers of this state in an endeavour to recoup that loss.

I hope we will toss Gillard out this Saturday. The next step is to make certain that this state government, which is rotten to the core, is tossed out of this state and we get in place a government that will balance the books, produce the infrastructure, produce the capital works and make certain that we go into the whole of the state, not just the marginals that the government tries to protect.

Hon. DM WELLS (Murrumba--ALP) (9.02 pm): Honourable members from the opposition side of the House have treated us tonight with an extraordinary ebullience and an extraordinary farrago of rhetoric, but I think the keynote speech came from the honourable member for Redlands. He set the tone of the debate. He said that it was an unusual debate; the term he used was that the parties seemed to have crossed over and the LNP was defending the battler. There lies a certain unconscious admission that it is not actually their historical role to defend the battler. When you hear the LNP purporting to defend the battler, then anyone with a normal judgement might very well wonder what is actually going on. Is it really just a theatrical performance that is going on? Is it perhaps something that might have a certain touch of insincerity about it? The extent to which they extrapolated their quite unreasonable rhetoric perhaps gives some verisimilitude to the proposition that there was some insincerity involved in it.

The notion from the honourable member for Redlands was that this was a brutal regime of taxation and the remarks of the honourable member for Maroochydore were that we were ripping the last dollar out of the pockets of the battlers. These pieces of rhetoric go far beyond any reality that anybody could possibly have a grip on. When you remind yourself of the remark of the honourable member for Redlands about how they have crossed over, you can also remind yourself of the remark of Shakespeare, which was designed exactly for people like the honourable members opposite that the devil can quote scripture for his purpose.

Let us have a look at what actually is happening here. The things they said would have moved me to tears had I not some more substantial grip on reality. This is the reality of the charges. In 2010-11 in Queensland, the cost of a five-year driver’s licence is $96.05. Compare that with every other continental state: in New South Wales, it is $151 compared to Queensland’s $96.05; in South Australia, $150; in Western Australia, $116; in the ACT, $145; and in Victoria, $158. Over a period of time, the Queensland driver’s licence will increase. By the year 2014-15, it will get to $152. That is what it is in New South Wales now. By then, it is likely that the driver’s licence cost in other states will have gone up and it will preserve Queensland’s position at the bottom of the pile of the continental states in terms of charges.

So when you look at the relativities of it, the relativities of it put it in a completely different category from the ones that the honourable members on the other side were expatiating about. The horrors and the Scrooge-like Dickensian cruelty that they were attributing to the government are actually not happening. If you take a reality check--and that reality check is the figures that I have just read to you--it is not as they were suggesting.

We would expect that an opposition might want to oppose an increase in fees and charges. Obviously, it is good politics to oppose an increase in fees and charges. Obviously, you would not want to say, ‘Let’s put up fees and charges,’ or at least you would not want to be out there at the front saying that if you were the opposition, but if you were the opposition and a responsible opposition that gave some thought to your long-term credibility, you might want to provide some kind of rationale for your proposition that we should not put these charges up by this amount now. You might want to say, for example, why it was that you wanted to keep Queensland’s rates low in terms of this particular tax--unless of course you were going to give up taxing altogether. I do not think even the most extreme of the rhetoricians from the other side of the House--not even those who tore their hair and ranted and waved their arms in the air as they were arguing against any increase in these fees and charges--want to stop taxing everyone on everything. So they would have to be selective about what taxes they froze.

They were saying they wanted to freeze this tax for some reason perhaps. Was that reason just because it was the tax that was in front of them at the moment? Surely they are not opportunistic like that! What was lacking from the opposition’s argument was any sort of rationale as to why these particular taxes should be frozen and, in cases like the instances I have just given, at a level lower than the rest of continental Australia.

A responsible opposition would have provided that kind of rationale. Let me ask a question: what benefit would there be at this particular turning point in history in keeping registration motoring costs generally so low that it artificially reduced the attractiveness of the alternative means of transport, which was public transport? How responsible would it be to adopt a policy that made it disadvantageous to choose the public transport option?

What would a responsible government do? Would a responsible government give motoring its real actual cost--the cost that it would have on a level playing field--or would a responsible government do what members opposite are saying and artificially make public transport disadvantageous by putting all sorts of unrealistic brakes on the kinds of increases which are happening in other states to motoring? At this turning point in history when if we have not had peak oil we will have it soon, at this turning point in history when fuel shortages will be a reality very soon, at this turning point in history when we do not have infinite fuel available to us to run the internal combustion engines that we now have, it would be folly of the grossest kind to make it seem artificially that motoring was an easy option--because it is not. It is not an option that we can have sustainably forever at a cheaper rate than reality dictates.

I would have thought that a good conservative opposition would take the attitude that the father of modern conservatism, Edmund Burke, took. I would recommend his thoughts to honourable members opposite because, if they are determined to be conservatives, they might as well be logically consistent ones. At the declaration of the poll in Bristol, Edmund Burke said that your representative owes you not just their diligence but also their judgement and they betray you, rather than serve you, if they abandon their judgement to suit short-term convenience. I would recommend those thoughts to honourable members opposite to come out as an opposition and say, ‘Yes, we support these price increases.’ It would be courageous for an opposition to come out and support these price increases. It would show judgement; it would show responsibility. However, given the limited reserves of these virtues that the honourable members opposite have, perhaps it is as well that they should conserve them for some more important occasion.

Mr HORAN (Toowoomba South--LNP) (9.12 pm): As motorists pay their increased registration and pay their 10c a litre extra on fuel and as they try to manage their household budgets with the ever rising costs of running their car, electricity, water, gas, stamp duties and everything else, I am sure the esoteric rumblings of the member for Murrumba and words like ‘vicissitudes’ and ‘farrago’ really come to mind as they endeavour to meet their weekly budgets in the working class suburbs of Brisbane.

We on this side are a bit more pragmatic. We do recognise that people are struggling and that people, particularly those on low and fixed incomes, find that the longer the Labor government is in power, the harder it is to make ends meet. Tonight’s debate on this disallowance motion is all about the costs of running a vehicle. It might be nice to think that people can use public transport, but that costs money too and those costs go up all the time. However, most people need to get their kids to school or pick them up from school because of where their workplace is located or to drop the kids off at sport on the weekend and it is absolutely essential for modern life to have a car.

Under this government we have gone from having the cheapest registration in Australia to now having the dearest registration in Australia. We were the only state that did not have a fuel tax, and after the deceit and the deception of the last election we now have a fuel tax. As the member for Indooroopilly pointed out, in the month of June we had the dearest fuel in Queensland. So all of our advantages of cheaper registration and cheaper fuel, which helped small business, which helped keep down the costs of freight--and every single item that goes into our supermarkets is delivered on the back of a truck--have dissipated.

We heard the member for Murrumba selectively talk about the comparisons between the cost of a driver’s licence in our state and other states. However, he did not mention the cost of registration or that just a couple of years ago this government jacked up the stamp duty on cars to such an extent that someone buying an old, second-hand Falcon worth about $16,000 would have to pay an extra $200 in rego. If a tradesman needs a LandCruiser ute to conduct their business or take heavy loads, that is going to cost them another $2,000. That adds to the cost of doing business or running their rural or city operation.

This debate tonight is another chink in the armour of the Labor government as Queenslanders come to realise what has happened since 1998. The profligate spending, the waste, the disregard for proper control of costs, the billion dollar blow-out in the original cost of the western corridor recycled water pipeline, the hundreds of millions of dollars lost on the aborted dam at Traveston, the money lost on the blow-outs in prices on the Tugun bypass--the list goes on and on. The wastage has been obscene. That wastage is the wasting of precious taxpayers’ money. It is not the government’s money; it is the hard-earned money of the people of Queensland who have paid their taxes to the Commonwealth government. Some of that money then comes back here to the state. Those people are paying all their fees, levies, registration and charges. It is their hard- earned money that the government holds in trust and spends. That is the money that has been wasted by the hundreds of millions of dollars to the point where we are approaching a debt of $85 billion. What has the government planned to pay that off? Apart from selling off our state-owned assets--cashing them in--which bring in more income than the interest they will save, the government does not have a plan. Its plan is to just lose the election, walk away, take no responsibility for the $85 billion debt and leave it to someone else--the LNP--to manage because it is too big for them to manage. They have built it up and then they will just walk away and say, ‘Oh well. Blow it. We will leave that to someone else.’

There is no plan for the capital repayment. There is no plan for the payment of the interest. We have reached the disgraceful stage of being the only state in Australia that has lost its AAA rating. That costs us hundreds of millions of dollars a year in penalty interest over and above the normal interest that we have to pay on that massive and ever-growing debt. It is the people who pay. The government accumulates the debt and the people pay it off because the government, in effect, is the government of the people, but it is the people who are going to have to pay.

That is why the sentiment, the anger and the angst during this federal election campaign in Queensland has been so strong against the Labor Party. People living anywhere in Australia know that the consequence of profligate, wasteful, disinterested control of the finances, of just throwing money around willy-nilly as though it grows on trees, is increases in the price of water, gas, electricity--basic things that every house needs and cannot do without--petrol and diesel, registration, cars and other charges that the government increases continuously, and it is the people who pay. They have to pay it every week. The people who are trying to put food on the table, trying to put the kids through school and trying to just survive and be good hardworking people in the suburbs and towns of Queensland are the ones who have to pay for this power grab by the Labor Party and its wanton waste and mismanagement.

Tonight’s debate has been all about the transport industry, the car industry and so forth, and there is another item that I want to bring forward. That is the massive increase that this government has put in place on the registration of B-doubles. Semitrailers have virtually been usurped by B-doubles and B-triples because they provide a more efficient and safer way of transporting goods on roads. As I said, almost everything that moves around Australia travels by truck. Honourable members only have to travel the Warrego Highway up to Toowoomba to see this. Every day 4,000 trucks, nearly all B-doubles, traverse our main street.
Mr Moorhead: Sixteen sets of traffic lights.

Mr HORAN: Yes, 16 sets of traffic lights. I take that interjection. It is a disgrace that one of the very first things the Rudd government did when it came into government was rip out the $700 million that had been allocated for the Toowoomba bypass. It will be forever condemned in Toowoomba for that short-sighted and cruel action.

The cost of registering a B-double annually is going to rise to $15,340. That is about $4,000 more than the registration for a double road train. It is $2,000 more than the registration for a triple road train. That means that people who have been running B-doubles, which are safe because they can brake more safely, can be driven at the legal speed limits on our highways and are far safer than a road train configuration or two trailers together, are going to tempted for sheer economic reasons to look at going back to the less safe system. I think that is not only a short-sighted move by the government but also one that could be quite dangerous.

This government says that this was a national principle agreed through COAG. When this government is ruled and controlled by debt it is only too happy to accept when COAG says, ‘We should jack up the costs for registering a B-double.’ It makes business harder and harder. It means that people have to put up their freight rates. That hits the people who buy these goods in our shops.

It is easy to find examples of this. We are talking about people who do the majority of the carting of the vegetables out of the Lockyer Valley and those who cart the cattle down to the meatworks in Dinmore or Brisbane or the Brisbane Valley which supplies the south-east corner. All their cartage costs in providing for our economy are going to go up. Not only will electricity, water and registration costs increase for low-income earners and everybody else; the cost of their food and essential items is going to go through the roof.

That is what this debate is about tonight. In the budget debate the LNP has made a number of major policy announcements. These add to the ones we have already made. One of those was that we would freeze the cost of registration. The member for Murrumba said, ‘Why that?’ It is because of the arguments that we have put forward with regard to how important cars are to people and families in Queensland.

We know about the massive costs of motoring in Queensland imposed by this debt-struck Labor government. We know that families need to be able to afford to operate their cars. The transport industry needs to be able to afford to run its vehicles. That is the greatest thing we can do to keep costs down for average working families in Queensland. I give all my support to this disallowance motion moved by the shadow minister. It is about time Queensland got some relief from Labor’s costs.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind) (9.22 pm): I rise to support the disallowance motion on the Transport Legislation (Fees) Amendment Regulation (No. 1) 2010. I oppose this regulation not because we are going to have a federal election in a couple days and not because I need to justify the actions of the Liberal National Party or the ALP federally but because we have 78 pages of increased fees and charges to Queenslanders. There is no other reason.

I think it was the member for Ipswich West--and I am sure he will correct me if I am wrong--who highlighted the fact that if this disallowance were successful there would be $63 million taken out of the budget and mostly from rural and regional Queenslanders. That is a lot of money out of the budget. But, more importantly, it is a lot of money for people to find in increased fees and charges. As other speakers have said, many of those charges relate to B-doubles and heavy transports.

Over the years that I have been in this place we have seen a fairly constant change in the method of transportation used in Queensland. It used to be that most of our commodities--not bulk commodities but commodities in general--were transported by rail. Over time that has been diminished so that only bulk commodities, such as coal, were encouraged to be transported by rail. All of our foodstuffs, grains and animals are transported on our roads. The increases that are proposed in this regulation will significantly increase the cost to transport vehicle operators. It is a concern because that is passed on to consumers.

There were a couple of comments made by members in the chamber that I want to comment on. Some would have been recorded by Hansard and some would not have been. The member for, I believe, Morayfield made a comment when the member for Gaven was speaking. The member for Gaven was talking about the removal of the fuel tax. The member for Morayfield--and he has only been in here this term--said that Howard introduced it. I am concerned to hear that because it is misinformation and a misunderstanding.

The fact is that nobody changed, per se, the status of any of the states in relation to fuel tax. It was determined by the Federal Court that the allocation of fuel tax by the states was ultra vires--that is, it was outside their legal ability. That meant that the federal government then had to levy taxes on fuel and tobacco. Queensland was the only state, I believe, that did not have a fuel tax. Therefore, the fuel rebate in Queensland was a recognition of the fact that Queensland did not have a fuel tax.

The angst, I guess, for voters in Queensland was that we had no fuel tax and we had a rebate to recognise that. The state Labor government went to an election and said that that rebate would remain and straight after the election removed the rebate, effectively making us a fuel-tax state. So John Howard did not do anything about the fuel tax. He was merely a facilitator to ensure that the Federal Court decision was appropriately administered. It was this state Labor government that removed the rebate and effectively made Queensland a state that levied a fuel tax.

I think it is important that we remember that in the south-east corner there is significant, sound and well-subsidised public transport infrastructure. I think people in my electorate, in the electorate of Nicklin, in the electorate of Nanango, in the electorate of Maryborough, in the electorate Mount Isa--indeed in any of the country electorates--would love to have a public transport system such as the one that is in the south-east corner, but we do not. We do not have buses or trains that can carry us to all of the services that we need. We need vehicles.

Any increase in the cost of running a vehicle for individual members of the community or any increase in the cost of running a bus or truck is a direct cost to us as individuals. We live in a diversified state. All of those costs add to our cost of living. These 78 pages of increased costs are going to add to the cost of living for families in this very diversified state.

If people live in Brisbane they could probably do without a car, providing they were very organised and were able to catch a train or bus to do their shopping, to attend medical appointments or to do school runs. I lived down here for my last year or so of high school and I caught a train to school. People who live in Gladstone cannot catch a train to school. Indeed, in some areas they cannot catch a bus to school. They have to have their parents or a car pool arrangement to take them there. These increased costs will add to the cost of living.
Mr Wellington: It’s just another tax.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: Another tax. I do care that we are having a federal election in a couple of days time, but in terms of the debate tonight--indeed, in terms of the debates that we had at 4.30 and 5.30--I have found it offensive that we are using state parliament time to debate such politically motivated motions.
Ms Grace interjected.
Mrs CUNNINGHAM: Not tonight.
Ms Grace: You moved one last sitting.
Mrs CUNNINGHAM: Not tonight.
Ms Grace: I was not talking about tonight; I was talking about last sitting.

Mr Wellington:
It was a good motion we moved, too.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms O’Neill): Order! The member for Gladstone has the call.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: I am supporting the disallowance motion simply because this will add to the cost of living for families in our communities. If you live in the south-east corner the impact is probably less, unless of course you drive a truck or some kind of heavy vehicle. If you live in rural and regional Queensland, these costs will impact. There are also increases in the cost of shipping. There are also increases in the cost of access to the ports of Gladstone and further north such as Weipa and other places, and I would acknowledge that the commercial entities are probably better able to absorb those costs. The cost of piloting is going up according to this amendment regulation. All of these 78 pages of regulation changes will add to the cost of living, particularly for those people in rural and regional Queensland who have no other alternative but to run their own vehicle.

Mention was also made about CTP insurance and the $24 rebate to Queenslanders. I am not going to comment any further than that because there is a bill before the House, but from my perspective and from the perspective of people in my community we are very sensitive to price increases. These fees are not the only ones that are going up. Electricity has gone up. We have already had debates about that. The cost of water is going up. Rates are going up. It needs to be recognised that the cost of living of families in Queensland is not isolated to each individual item. It is an aggregation of items. It is the cost of living in relation to motor vehicles, to trucks, to food, to water, to electricity. It is a cost impost on families who are finding it very difficult to survive, and it is on that basis that I support the disallowance motion.

Hon. RG NOLAN (Ipswich--ALP) (Minister for Transport) (9.31 pm): This is a motion to disallow Transport Legislation (Fees) Amendment Regulation (No. 1) 2010. Should this motion be passed, the fees that would be disallowed cover tow truck licences, smart card licences, the annual levy for marina berths which are calculated by length, operating a commercial ship as a ferry service, operating a commercial ship to transport goods, personal watercraft licences, recreational marine licences, taxi service licences, limousine service licences, driver authorisation for taxi or limousine, the annual taxi industry security levy which goes towards the security cameras that exist in taxis, and vehicle registration.

It is, as such, a far more comprehensive regulation than has been widely acknowledged in this debate. At the outset the member for Maroochydore made the point that she had no choice but to disallow all of the provisions within the regulation. This quite simply is not the case. Section 50(1) of the Statutory Instruments Act 1992 provides that the Legislative Assembly may pass a resolution disallowing subordinate legislation--that is, a disallowance motion may be brought. But section 50(5) of the Statutory Instruments Act defines subordinate legislation to include--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: a provision of subordinate legislation.
XML.Hansard-Body: As such, the proposition that has been put to the House by the member for Maroochydore that all of the fees and charges which I just outlined must, by definition, be disallowed in an attempt to disallow certain provisions of the regulation is quite simply not true. Therefore, this disallowance motion is quite simply flawed from the outset because the motion which has been moved does not in fact reflect what the member for Maroochydore claims to the House was her intention. There is a fundamental flaw at the heart of this motion.

Nonetheless, I think it would be generous of the House to apply the principle of charitable interpretation. Because the member for Maroochydore was unable to bring forward a motion that did what she said she intended to do, let us in this debate discuss what it is that the member for Maroochydore said rather than what exactly the member for Maroochydore did. The member for Maroochydore in speaking to the motion which she put forward made two arguments. She argued that she wished--not that she did--to disallow the provision which related to heavy vehicle registration because she thought, and the member for Toowoomba South argued along similar lines, that changes in heavy vehicle registration fees were unfair and in particular she thought that some of the variances between different kinds of heavy vehicles would lead to distortions in the freight market. The second point that the member for Maroochydore argued was that she wished to implement an LNP policy to freeze ordinary vehicle registration charges for a period of three years.

Let me deal with heavy vehicle registration charges first. Members should be aware that it is the case that in Queensland heavy vehicle registration charges went up from 1 July. However, members should also understand that Queensland is a signatory to a national scheme whereby truck registration is consistent across every state in this country. Why is that? The freight industry, as everyone would expect, operates across state borders. The trucks that start at Hoepners in Ipswich or at Nolan’s at Gatton, as the member for Lockyer said, travel to Sydney and to Melbourne and to Adelaide and sometimes to Perth. So the first principle is that for heavy vehicles there is a consistent national scheme of registration charging.

How would things work if there was not a consistent national scheme? Of course what would happen if there was not national consistency for heavy vehicle registration is that from year to year all of the heavy vehicles being mobile would register in the state with the lowest charge. It would be like the Panamanian registered ships--that is, all of the heavy vehicles would be registered in one place. If one state had its budget first and then the next state undercut its heavy vehicle registration charge, that state would lose all of the heavy vehicle contribution to that state’s roads. When you have a heavy vehicle industry that operates across state borders, it is quite simply for obvious reasons necessary to have a consistent national charging regime.

The second point that I believe the House should understand is that the heavy vehicle registration regime we have in this country, not just in this state, operates on the principle that trucks pay for the damage they do to the roads. So it is the case that in the last national agreement B-double trucks changed to a different extent than did different kinds of heavy vehicles, but that was because there has been extensive research undertaken at a national level which showed that the existing relativities were not right and that B-doubles were not paying the full cost of their damage to the roads. I thought the member for Gladstone made an interesting point. She argued the case for rail freight, and I entirely agree with her. I think that in this country what we should see is more rail freight wherever practical. But we cannot get that if the trucks are not paying for their damage to the roads, because if the trucks are not paying for their damage to the roads that means that taxpayers and other motorists are subsidising the trucks and that the trucks are being unfairly advantaged in relation to rail freight. So this charge ensures the integrity of the national regime and, in so doing, ensures national consistency so that there is the same registration charge from state to state. It also ensures that the trucks pay for the real cost of their damage to the roads.

The second point that the member for Maroochydore argued was that it was LNP policy to freeze the cost of car registration for the term of a future LNP government. I am the member for Ipswich. I understand, I reckon much better than the member for Maroochydore or the member for Indooroopilly, who has just lectured this House, what it is to represent people who in many cases struggle to make their budgets meet day to day. I understand what it is to represent people who genuinely add up the pennies every day and every week. I also listen very closely to my constituents when they tell me what they need to get by and one of the things that they say is that they need better roads so that they can drive to work in a job which in many cases is part of the state government’s building program, which enables them to make a living.

The LNP brought to the House a completely unfunded policy proposition. The LNP walked in here tonight and said, ‘We have this policy and we are going to freeze registration.’ Does any member here recall in this debate tonight the LNP telling us how much this policy would cost?
Government members: No.

Ms NOLAN: No. They came in here tonight, as usual, with a whacking great unfunded promise. They have done it on the day that Tony Abbott walked away from his own election costings. What happened today in the federal campaign? The LNP at a national level brought down its financial costings for the campaign and Tony Abbott did not even front up to the press conference. What happened in here today? On the day that Tony Abbott walked away from his election costings the LNP in Queensland did not even bother to try to produce theirs. They came in here with a hundreds of millions of dollars commitment and they did not even bother to put a figure on it. What kind of economic management is it to walk in here with a funding promise that would cost hundreds of millions of dollars, a funding promise that is not new, that was originally made in the budget some months ago, and not even bother to try to put a figure on it? That is economic ineptitude of the highest order. It is typical of what we see out of the well-funded, well-resourced but completely lazy and intellectually bereft opposition. It is what we see in this place every day of the week.

What was the smoking gun that the member for Maroochydore brought to the table? She trotted in here and put on the table a letter that was released, to my recollection, in the election campaign--a year and a half ago--that said, shock horror, the registration money is going to go into the Consolidated Fund. Golly! Do you know what? Every year in Queensland we spend about twice as much on roads as we collect out of registration. Should we adhere to the principle that the member for Maroochydore would appear to advocate--that there has to be a direct correlation between registration collection and roads spending--Queensland’s road budget would halve. This year in Queensland this government will spend $732.39 per person on better roads for my constituents and yours. New South Wales will spend $382. Victoria will spend $205, and Western Australia--a state much bigger than this one--will spend $227. I understand that people save this money, but this money goes into better roads for Queenslanders. What the LNP has done is come in here with a hundreds of millions of dollars commitment that it has not even bothered to cost.
