XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (9.53 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the House do now adjourn.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SORENSEN (Hervey Bay--LNP) (9.53 pm): I rise to pay my respects and send birthday wishes to Mrs Miriam Schmierer, who turns 111 years of age on Friday. Mrs Schmierer is the oldest resident in Australia. Mrs Schmierer is a truly remarkable woman. Mrs Schmierer has written a message for us, and I am very happy to table her letter and read her words for you today.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Letter, undated, from Mrs Miriam Schmierer to Ted Sorensen MP, in relation to an interview for The Chronicle [ 2779 ].
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Mrs Schmierer writes--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Good morning all. I start my day with an upward look to our Creator and His lovely country loaned to us.
I gave the TV away over two years back and I glance the Chronicle 6 days a week. I look for the sad stories that have depth of meaning that I can understand at my age.

I tell people I have the world around me. That is because I stay in one place and hear a lot of travel but do not see the distance between places, therefore all countries are very close to my heart. I can see lots of little dots representing the different countries.
I love this little vision, it is good for my health in every way. Keeps me alert so I can enjoy my days and the effects it falls on others.

When I was quite a little girl I watched my father take the wheel off a vehicle. He had a red tin with grease in it. I think it was called axle grease and he put some on the bar where the wheel came off and said that it made it easy for the wagon to move and to make it easy for the horses to pull.
Now 100 years on this illustration floated across my mind.
You all know my faith in the Creator. What the grease was to the wagon wheel is what my Bible is to me every day of the week. God Bless you all.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Mrs Schmierer from a political sense writes to us and says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The day was when I enjoyed the evening news but not today. Too much debt and promises, my thoughts are we have run off the rails and are getting into knots we cannot untie. This is God’s world, not ours and his eye is upon us. The Bible is the most reliable source as it tell us of the past, present and the future.
God knows you all,
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I will also read a letter from the residential service manager of the Blue Care Masters Lodge who cares for Mrs Schmierer. She writes--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I find it a great privilege to provide care to this amazing super centenarian.
Mrs Schmierer is a wonderful role model for Australian citizens; her purity of heart, her infectious smile and her inimitable wit and wisdom should be known by all.
In allowing us to care for her, Mrs Schmierer has reminded us of the true meaning of ‘true blue’, being compassionate and respectful and being thankful for this wonderful land.

Always a lady, thankful for all she receives and never a negative word said, may God continue to bless her and keep her safe with us at Masters Lodge. Thank you, Mrs Schmierer, and happy birthday from us all.
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr CHOI (Capalaba--ALP)
(9.56 pm): A couple of weeks ago I was pleased to take part in the Shared Visions forum held recently in the Redlands. This was the second of 20 forums to be held around the state. The Shared Visions forums present an opportunity for people to have their say in shaping this government’s 10-year plan for supporting Queenslanders with a disability. The Bligh government’s vision is for a community where people of all abilities can participate and contribute, feel valued, follow their dreams and live the kind of life many of us take for granted.

The plan sets out 10 priorities, followed by a number of key strategies needed to help us get us there. Shared Visions forums have a tradition of positive, passionate and insightful discussion about where we should be headed. The Redlands forum was no exception. People with a disability face challenges every day, whether it is going to school or the playground, looking for training and jobs, deciding where to live, playing sport or going for a meal with friends. However, this government plans for the future. While some strategies can be implemented within three years, others are more ambitious and will need longer action over the life of the 10-year plan and beyond.

The plan will build on what is already happening and has already attracted a record investment in disability services in Queensland. On 2 June the Premier and the Minister for Disability Services announced that the combined Commonwealth and state budget would deliver a record over $1 billion for specialist disability services for the coming financial year. This is the first time the Disability Services budget has topped $1 billion. It represents an increase of more than 13 per cent on last year. A new $12.5 million package of recurrent funding for the new financial year will support a suite of early intervention initiatives for people with a disability, their families and carers. The 10-year plan will allow us to focus the funding so that more people with a disability have fairer access to services.

I would briefly like to touch on the state government’s report titled Building bright futures: an action plan for children with a disability--birth to eight years . The first eight years is such an important time for children with a disability and their families. We are determined to ensure that families are able to access supports and services in order to ensure their children achieve their full potential. That is why I was pleased to join disability services minister Annastacia Palaszczuk when she announced $30,000 in state government funding for the Horizon Foundation in Capalaba. The program offers children aged zero to five years with specialised play sessions to help them learn. This unique program recognises the strengths of family relationships and the importance of informal support networks. I encourage Queenslanders to get involved in the Shared Visions forums being held across the state. We will be listening to your ideas about how to create stronger communities and to achieve our shared vision.

Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP) (9.59 pm): Much has been said about the weekend that Splendour in the Grass hit Woodford. I will be honest and admit that I am not really into Wolfmother and certainly I have not signed up to the Scissor Sisters’ fan club. However, I was disappointed that I missed out on tickets to hear artists such as Florence and the Machine, Clare Bowditch and Megan Washington, not to mention Paul Kelly and the band currently on constant replay in my car, Mumford & Sons. There is no denying the festival was a massive success at its new, albeit temporary, home. However, it is not without some difficulties for locals. Quite frankly, despite the annual Woodford Folk and Dreaming Festivals, Woodford was not prepared for the enormous influx of Splendour ticket holders. To be honest, the uncertainty surrounding a festival of this scale was reflected in the conversations I had with locals in the lead-up to Splendour. I remember being at the Woodford Show in June, talking to the Woodford Show Society President, Doug Chicken, about his concerns. Locals’ fears appeared to be confirmed when many parents could not get through to their schoolkids on the Thursday afternoon, because the D’Aguilar Highway had turned into a car park.

But Woodford embraced Splendour in the Grass and the verdict is nothing but positive. The catchcry going around town is ‘See you next year, Splendour.’ Much of that has to do with the countless volunteers who kept up spirits in and around Woodford. Many volunteers gave up their valuable time, but I will mention just a few. Firstly, from the Woodford Show Society, Barry and Margaret Ferris, Peter and Bobbie Winkel and Ron Trim are incredible people who welcomed the Splendour campers with open arms, providing comfort and, at times, some much needed support to stranded young campers. Exhausted from being on and off their feet for the entire duration--Barry and Margaret actually camped on the floor of the show secretary’s office--not once did they complain. Instead, they enjoyed the experience of exchanging stories with the travellers, administering first aid to festival goers and learning new-age art from a talented young Scottish girl. They even got to know who some of the current artists are, even if they are scratching their heads or stifling a laugh at the more outrageous names. Ron described the guests as ‘a bunch of great kids’ and, in return, the campers showed nothing but respect to the Show Society people. All up, the Show Society is happy to have the campers back next year; it just needs to make a few adjustments to the facilities.

I also mention Councillor Adrian Raedel, his partner Kerri and Sergeant Jason Renwick of the Woodford police. Adrian and Jason spent the better part of four days responding to complaints about traffic and noise, as well as dealing with the logistical issues associated with tens of thousands of camping festival goers. In Adrian’s case, that was on top of his normal duties across division 12, which is one of the largest divisions in the local government authority. He and Kerri even found time to help the Woodford scouts with their manically busy barbecues. Until till next year, Splendour--and this time I am getting some tickets!
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Parliamentary Internship Program; Nuich, Mr J
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr MOORHEAD (Waterford--ALP) (10.02 pm): Sometimes as politicians we spend much of our time resolving constituent queries and working with local community groups and do not get an opportunity to research and consider some of the big issues facing Queensland in the future. Over recent years I have been fortunate to have had the opportunity to work with a number of young Queenslanders through the Queensland Parliamentary Internship Program. This program gives young people studying at university an opportunity to apply their research skills to real problems and provide members of parliament with an invaluable source of research.

This year I have had the opportunity to work with Queensland University of Technology student Jamie Nuich. For the information of members and the Minister for Community Services, who is in the House, I table Jamie’s research report titled Looks like a child, acts like a child, treated like an adult: human rights implications of the pre-adjudication treatment of seventeen year olds in Queensland .
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Parliamentary research report by Jamie Nuich, titled ‘Looks like a child, acts like a child, treated like an adult: human rights implications of the pre-adjudication treatment of seventeen year olds in Queensland’ [ 2780 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Jamie’s report analyses the treatment of 17-year-olds under Queensland criminal laws compared with that of their younger counterparts under the Youth Justice Act 1992 in the context that the international human rights framework requires both groups to be treated as children. The Children’s Services Act 1965 first established the definition of child for the purposes of youth justice as being 17 years. In 1988, the Kennedy review of Queensland Corrective Services roundly criticised Queensland’s juvenile justice system. In 1990, the Convention on the Rights of the Child provided rights for children and defined children as persons under the age of 18 years. Even though Australia is a signatory to that convention, Queensland law continues to treat 17-year-olds as adults when it comes to arrest, prosecution, remand and release, and sentencing.

Jamie’s report is an informative and objective look at an important issue for Queensland’s justice system. Unfortunately, the political debate around juvenile justice has not been so informed or objective. The LNP and its predecessors have never stepped back from using young people as political fodder in law and order campaigns. We need to make sure that we can be tough on crime and tough on the causes of crime. That means we need to take another look at whether 17-year-olds, who are in grade 12 now and in a few years time will be in grade 11, should continue to be treated as adults in our justice system and in our prisons.

Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (10.05 pm): Tonight I rise to bring to the attention of the House the appalling lack of safety for workers and motorists during the M1 upgrade from the Nerang South interchange to the Gooding Drive interchange. The minister has publicly stated that temporary concrete safety barriers would be installed for the safety of roadworkers by December 2009, when the widening of the M1 was to commence. Since work has commenced, a large and deep ‘V’ has been cut between the north and southbound lanes which fills with water when it rains. Whilst some of the barriers are in place on the southern lanes to stop them falling perpendicular into a ditch filled with water, there are none on the northbound stretch. Motorists have only a small margin for error. If you are unfortunate enough to be in an accident, you may find yourself drowning in the ditch before emergency services have had time to free you. Emergency services, particularly the fire brigade, have expressed their concerns about having to cut a motorist out of a car with water swirling around them and that it would be nigh impossible to treat a patient who had to remain in the car in the case of spinal injuries, let alone have to cope with the prospect of drowning.

Since the commencement of construction works, there have been six accidents along this stretch of road. Some of those have been due to motorists having to avoid huge potholes in the road which are caused by the extreme weather we have been experiencing on the Gold Coast. Only last Friday I personally had to swerve from the outside lane into the inside lane northbound to avoid a pothole. Luckily for me, there was no-one in the other lane. However, I witnessed the driver of the car behind me do the same manoeuvre and almost sideswipe the car in the next lane. Only half an hour later there was a major accident on this stretch of road, between exits 77 and 75 northbound.

Compounding the issue is commuter arrogance and a total disregard for the safety of workers and motorists in this construction zone. Motorists, particularly semitrailer and B-double drivers, are ignoring the 80 kilometre per hour roadworks speed limit that has been posted whilst construction takes place and are being clocked travelling at well over 100 kilometres per hour. The lanes are very narrow and, with a truck passing you at 100 kilometres per hour, you can be literally buffeted off the small road shoulder. Countless numbers of residents and even my own staff have experienced this and been quite frightened by the ordeal.

As the newly dubbed ‘member for the M1’, thanks to the Gold Coast Bulletin , I call on the Minister for Main Roads to keep his promise of installing safety barriers along the north and southbound lanes immediately. Statistics released recently show a dramatic increase in the number of motorists slowing down substantially in areas with fixed speed cameras. The number of offences has decreased by 78 per cent in Southport and 41 per cent in Broadbeach. That is not about revenue raising--and I am pleased that both ministers are in the House tonight--but it is about protecting the lives of roadworkers and motorists alike. I call on the Minister for Police to install a fixed speed camera for the duration of the roadworks to prevent further accidents.

Ms van LITSENBURG (Redcliffe--ALP) (10.07 pm): There was a buzz at the Youth Space on Saturday night as 80 young people mingled with myself, the member for Petrie, Yvette D’Ath, Moreton Bay Regional Councillors Rae Frawley and James Houghton, Youth Space President Kelly Clancy and Vice-President Sarah McCartney, manager Jarryd Williams, staff member Ben Vanovic and Chameleon Community Housing Manager Carmel Reithmuller over cocktails and canapes as we answered the questions young people wanted to ask on issues important to them. This Youth Fusion Summit dinner was the culmination of a two-year youth engagement project funded to the tune of $40,000 through the Bligh government’s Youth Engagement program.

Resident youth caterers, Connections Catering, provided a fabulous meal to enjoy while the young people fired questions at representatives from all levels of government over issues dear to their hearts. Those included immigration and race discrimination issues, religion, transport, homelessness and housing, and youth participation in government. The questions were posed in a positive spirit, with young people listening actively and displaying a refreshingly mature attitude on all issues. Many of those young people had been homeless for many years and have worked towards tertiary education through Queensland government funded flexischools and youth services and have gained employment after participating in the Bligh government’s Skilling Queenslanders for Work and Green Army programs. The outcome of the evening was an agreement to come together to discuss the current important issues every six months. It is great to see that the youth services the Bligh government has put in place to support young people are enabling them to resolve their issues and move ahead to a meaningful and productive adulthood.

The Youth Engagement programs are an effective way for the Bligh government to listen to young people in Redcliffe and right across Queensland. It is one more strand in the Bligh government’s Toward Q2 plan to build strong communities, because the Youth Engagement grants enable young people to know they are listened to and they enable this Labor government to design responsive services for young people who become disengaged because of earlier life experiences. An effective, caring government is about allowing people to grow and shine, and that is what the Bligh government is all about--building strong relationships, healing families and allowing young people to grow into stable, responsible adults with a healthy outlook. That is a record the Bligh government is proud of.

To support these programs, it is vital that the federal Labor government is re-elected because the opposition intends to slash and burn if it is elected so it can have a black bottom line on its budget sheet. The Gillard federal government will ensure two levels of government working together will produce a better community for our youth, for all Queenslanders and for Australians.

Mr BLEIJIE (Kawana--LNP) (10.10 pm): I have received numerous complaints from constituents in my electorate relating to an increase in water charges imposed on them as a result of actions undertaken by the Bligh Labor government. The outrageous charges have added even further pressure and burden on many household budgets because this Labor government is a crisis driven government that is always on the back foot. The wasteful spending on the $7 billion South-East Queensland water grid, including the hundreds of millions of dollars wasted on the scrapped Traveston Dam project, has ensured that Queenslanders are paying more--a lot more--for their water.

Individual councils were initially responsible for local water infrastructure and distribution until the state government requisitioned them in what some described as ‘the great water swindle’. In legislation that was passed earlier this year, three new bodies were created for water distribution in South-East Queensland. Unitywater was established as the water distribution authority for the Sunshine Coast and Moreton Bay Regional Council areas. I have written to the CEO of Unitywater, Mr Jon Black, to ascertain a breakdown of the associated set-up costs and how these have impacted on consumers.

The Bligh Labor government has positioned itself to escape the blame for the higher water charges and continues to play the buck-passing game rather than own up to Queenslanders. While Unitywater staff and management cop the abuse from a hostile public, the state has washed its hands of the mess it created. The accounts that have been distributed contain a charge for bulk water, a state government charge to recoup some of the costs involved in wasteful spending initiatives. People are certainly going to have to be far more frugal than they once were and make use of water-saving initiatives such as water tanks, greywater and other water-saving mechanisms. I would also encourage people to keep an eye on any suspected water leaks because any misused water will be felt very hard in the hip pocket.

Community groups and organisations have received massive hikes in their water costs and for some it will simply mean the end of operation. Businesses, and in particular small businesses, have also been slugged with increased charges. While some may not be able to absorb them, the costs will end up being passed on to consumers, meaning it is a double-dip charge. All of this indicates that this increase in charges can be best described as a great big new tax on everything. My concern is how this will impact on the cost of living expenses for my constituents. Many people are under pressure already and those on fixed incomes such as pensioners will be the hardest hit, which is often the case with Labor governments.

The system was fine until the Beattie and Bligh Labor governments got their grubby hands on the water. I call on the Bligh government to end the wasteful spending and look at any measures it can implement to encourage residents to purchase water tanks and other water-saving mechanisms. The federal Labor government has been just as bad as our state Labor government since it took office in 2007. Between the December quarter 2007 and the June quarter 2010, the cost of living has continually risen under federal Labor. One thing Queenslanders can do to stamp their disapproval at these cost of living increases is to vote for Tony Abbott and the coalition on Saturday. Is it any wonder a gentleman at the people’s forum tonight asked a question along these lines: ‘Prime Minister, how can we trust federal Labor when we have been so let down by state Labor?’

Ms O’NEILL (Kallangur--ALP) (10.13 pm): The Pine Rivers Show Society held the 106th Pine Rivers Show on 30 and 31 July and 1 August this year. Attendance records were broken as 22,000 people flocked to the show. This was 106 years of bringing the country to the city, 106 years of sideshows, great music and performance artists, choirs, terrifying rides and outstanding exhibits. This was 106 years of bringing excitement, education and entertainment to the children and citizens of Pine Rivers. The 2010 Pine Rivers Show was bigger and better than ever. Ashton’s Circus appeared this year. The famous KAOS Motorbikes returned with not one but two backflip stunt riders, and there were fireworks. The ever-exciting pig racing was not to be missed. The Education Pavilion featured all of the school displays as well as the hotly contested colouring-in competition. This year saw the Pine Rivers High School F1 racing cars with their interactive demonstration; this was an amazing demonstration of speed and engineering.

I congratulate the show committee for an outstanding effort year after year. I especially mention secretary Toni Gilliland, who not only helps produce a great show but is also the President of the Pine Rivers Junior Rugby League Football Club, the mighty Bears. It just goes to show that the old adage that if you need something done give it to a busy person is just as true these days, with Toni being a perfect example.

The Pine Rivers Show committee has been innovative in keeping attendance high. It has developed a system of sponsorship which enables primary school children in free if they are accompanied by a paying adult. One of the sponsorship opportunities is to sponsor a piglet in the piglet races. I hasten to point out that these races are short and through a gentle maze with a reward for all piglets at the end of the race. As a proud farmer’s daughter, I was delighted to take up the sponsorship of a piglet for the last two shows. I am very happy to be able to advise the House that my piglet won the most races this year. This means I am the recipient of a handsome trophy proclaiming that I am the owner of the champion pig of 2010. As I said, I was delighted to sponsor the show, and this has led to me receiving my first ever trophy. So my sincere thanks go to the appropriately named MP Automotive Repairs of Petrie for its generous support of the show and for providing the trophy.

I commend the show society and all the volunteers who work so hard to bring us the show every year. I will be back next year with pleasure. I would also like to thank members Murray Watt and Carolyn Male, Senator Mark Furner, the candidate for Dickson, Fiona McNamara, and their staff and supporters for their assistance at our very popular stall.

Mr DOWLING (Redlands--LNP) (10.15 pm): Tonight I wish to raise with the Minister for Main Roads an issue in Redlands, and I am pleased to see he is in the House tonight. There are three intersections where roadworks have been promised and are certainly long overdue. These are the upgrades at the intersections at Beveridge Road, Ziegenfusz Road and Dinwoodie Road along Cleveland-Redland Bay Road between Cleveland and Victoria Point. They are roadworks that were promised at the previous election and each year before that, and they are long overdue. I have sat in this House and I have listened to the minister waxing lyrical in his ministerial statements that there are roadworks signs everywhere--roadworks here, roadworks there, signs everywhere you go. He is a fantastic performer in the House but can I tell the minister that there are no roadworks signs in Redlands. There are no roadworks signs in Redlands for two reasons.

Mr WALLACE: Mr Speaker, I rise to a point of order. The honourable member is deliberately misleading the House. There are millions of dollars worth of roadworks in Redlands. He is offensive and he is misleading the House.

Mr SPEAKER: Order! I would say to the honourable minister that it is wrong to accuse somebody of deliberately misleading the House. There is a convention that you cannot accuse the member of that. However, if you feel that the member has taken action against you personally, then you can seek the retraction, but I ask you to withdraw the fact that you believe he has deliberately misled the House.
Mr WALLACE: Thank you, Mr Speaker. I find those comments offensive and I ask the honourable member to withdraw.

Mr DOWLING: I withdraw, but there are no roadworks signs at the three intersections named--at Beveridge, Ziegenfusz and Dinwoodie roads--and I would be more than happy to show the minister that part of town and show him that the signs are clearly not there. These roadworks were due to commence about a year ago, but there were problems with tree offsets. It is almost like an episode of Yes, Minister , where there were two departments that could not work together and could not manage to work this program. The tree offsets were agreed and everything should have been done and dusted. They had let contracts and they have had to let those contracts lapse. They are now redoing tenders so that these roadworks can finally commence. I am hoping and praying that those roadworks will actually commence in September/October this year and be finalised about five years later than they should have been.

This situation is a complete disaster. It is a complete mess. It is a dysfunctional department that has oversight of this. Clearly, there are two departments warring with each other. Someone needs to wake up to the fact that when roadworks are carried out trees are going to come down and the offsets are going to occur. It is not that hard. It certainly should not hold up the project.

There are three schools located near these three intersections. They are Faith Lutheran, Carmel College and Bay View State School. The three principals are concerned that these roadworks are being delayed for far too long and those three principals, Anthony Mueller, Berenice McLellan and Peter Black, are all concerned at the delays caused by this government and the impacts they have had on these school communities. These three intersections are incredibly dangerous.
Mr Ryan interjected.

Mr DOWLING: I take the interjection from the member for Morayfield. I hope he is not threatening principals of these three schools with that tone. Will the minister accept the responsibility for student safety?
Mr RYAN: I rise to a point of order. I find those statements highly offensive and I ask for them to be withdrawn.
Mr SPEAKER: Member for Redlands, you will withdraw.

Mr DOWLING: I withdraw the statement. There is only one thing that I worry about, and that is the phone call that will come one day saying that one of my children has been hurt or one of the students at one of those schools has been hurt at one of those intersections. Will the minister accept responsibility for the safety of those students?
Mr Wallace: And you sat on that council and you did nothing. You sat on there for years and did absolutely nothing.
Mr DOWLING: I rise to a point of order. I find those comments offensive and I ask that they be withdrawn.
Mr SPEAKER: I call upon the minister.
Mr WALLACE: I apologise unreservedly.
Mr SPEAKER: Just withdraw.
Mr WALLACE: I withdraw.

Mr PITT (Mulgrave--ALP) (10.21 pm): In 2007 cardiovascular disease was the primary cause of death for over 46,000 Australians, representing one-third of all deaths that year. Despite major gains over the last 40 years, there is still a 50 per cent chance of a person dying with their first heart attack. Cardiovascular disease continues to have a major effect on the health of Australians.

For the last three weeks local patients have been able to have their heart procedures at the Cairns Base Hospital thanks to a $4.18 million investment by the Bligh government in the new cardiac catheter laboratory. Around 80 per cent of all local angioplasty patients will now be able to undergo their procedure close to home, without the need to travel to Townsville or Brisbane. However, it is not possible for the government to fund every piece of equipment. This is where organisations like the Far North Queensland Hospital Foundation are so valuable.

The foundation is a not-for-profit charity that works tirelessly on behalf of our community to assist the activities and services of the Cairns Base Hospital and the Cairns and Hinterland Health Service District. The Yellow Pages Cardiac Challenge is the foundation’s largest fundraising event--a three-day, 335-kilometre cycling event from Cairns to Cooktown. Since it began in 2007, the ride has raised more than $400,000 to assist with the purchase of state-of-the-art equipment and provide support services for the patients and staff. The foundation is hoping to raise in excess of $250,000 from this year’s Cardiac Challenge to fund more cardiac equipment at the Cairns Base Hospital. Coordinator Glenys Duncombe is to be congratulated on her ongoing efforts.

In previous years I have led the Cardiac Challenge as it left from Cazalys, Mulgrave Road, only to farewell the riders at Smithfield. But for 2010 I have taken up the challenge to ride the whole distance and have convinced my friend and colleague the member for Barron River, Steve Wettenhall, to join me. ‘Pittenhall Pedalling Pollies’, as our team is known, has been gearing up for the event, taking any spare opportunity to get in a training ride. I must thank my wife, Kerry, for agreeing to come along as our support team.

Last year the ride attracted more than 175 riders. Registration for the 2010 ride has exceeded expectations, with 264 people registered. This is well above the 225 rider target. With this number of riders now in training on our region’s roads, I ask that motorists take extra care. Last month the founder of the Cardiac Challenge, Peter McNally, was knocked from his bike. Peter had open heart surgery in 2003 and wanted to give back to the community. This bike ride is his way of helping others who also have heart problems. Peter’s accident is a reminder that all cyclists are vulnerable on the road, regardless of their experience.

Raising money for our Cairns Base Hospital Cardiac Unit is a great cause. To date, more than $132,000 has been raised and with 37 days, seven hours and 10 minutes to go until the start of the ride I hope people will take the time to get behind the ride before it kicks off on 25 September. Fundraising from this bike ride will help us improve the odds for heart patients in the Far North.
Question put--That the House do now adjourn.
Motion agreed to.
The House adjourned at 10.23 pm.
